number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												[Review written for 1.3]Short Review:Engaging RTS / dungeon management game where you get to play the bad guys.Negative reviews are primarily concerned with WFTO at launch. Game is fully polished and well-optimised now, which makes for a much more enjoyable experience. Worth the full price, extremely worth during a sale.(Very) Long Review:I backed this during the Kickstarter crowdfunding phase, and was an avid fan of DK1 and 2. Bias confirmation confirmed, but this review is as objective as I can make it.OverviewWar for the Overworld is the spiritual successor to the cult hit Dungeon Keeper, a series by Bullfrog (later snapped up by EA - which is why DK3 never. ;_;). You play as an 'Underlord', a wibbly wobbly non-corporeal being that seals its essence in a Dungeon Core (the room you start with in every game). Lose that and you lose the game; protect it at all costs.But in order to enact your will (and defend said Core), you gain access to an assortment of rooms, The Good - You're the bad guy!- Very polished. Backers and early buyers remember the... fiasco that was WFTO's launch (although they did explain why it released the way it did, which was understandable); it's come a long way since then. Virtually all bugs have been fixed, many quality-of-life features have been implemented/improved and the optimisation is much better.- Unique. Although a successor to DK, there's nothing else like this on the market at the moment. WFTO isn't a carbon copy of DK either; it has its own fantasy, creatures and ideas (most notably, Potions and Rituals). - Build your own Dungeon. One of the major attractions, you can build your Dungeon however you feel like (within the constraints of the map terrain, of course). If you want a massive open-plan ground, meticulously divided rooms full of doorways and corridors, then you can do it. (A more recent addition was Wall prop efficiency; to offset the fact you have less building space, rooms with reinforced walls will operate more effectively.)- Playstyle variety [outside of the Campaign]. Every game, you'll start with no abilities or rooms unlocked, spending Sins (points) in a three-column Tech Tree to unlock stuff. You can rush for a specific tree's Titan, or you can spread Sins across all three trees. That said, I don't think it's perfect (see below).- Entertaining. With Richard Ridings as your Mentor (the same VA for the DK Mentor) and the dark, tongue-in-cheek (and occasionally just plain silly) humour, it'll catch you out once in a while.That, with the excellent(ly awful) voice acting for the good guys makes for fun outside of the gameplay.The Bad- Hotkeys. Hotkey support was enabled a while back, but the lack of visibility is a significant issue to learn hotkeys, especially if you're trying to micro combat / efficiency. Could easily be fixed by displaying the relevant hotkey in ability tooltips.- The AI. It's alright, but once you get to grips with the game, it becomes a lot easier to fight against. Also, there's no difficulty mode for the campaign; although the early missions are newbie-friendly, the difficulty curve rises quite significantly, particularly if you're new to this genre.- Hidden / unexplained mechanics. Following on from the previous point, the game introduces many additional utilities you can make use of. That in and of itself is a good thing; the lack of introduction and usage of them isn't great. There's still a few rituals and potions I never make use of, while others are pretty overpowered for their investment. There are user-written guides that provide in-depth explanations, but it shouldn't really be the place of the community to tell you how something functions in the first place.- Meta playstyles Lack of depth to Tech Tree. Having tested a defensive strategy against Master AI, I can confirm that defensive strats do indeed work (Avarice + WDs, all I'm saying), though I can't see them being as effective vs players. Nevertheless, Although there are options and optimal choices do vary from map to map, I still feel more could be done to promote tech / build diversity. Possibly passive buffs (and nerfs?) for certain units when you invest into certain trees, or passives that only activate from speccing into multiple trees to complement your playstyle.- RAM usage. I have 8GB RAM (DDR3, meh clock speed), but on larger maps I will start to lag; it's still playable, but everything goes slower and commands won't always register. For optimal experience you'll want 12 or 16GB, but it's fine on small/medium sized maps.ConclusionCongrats for getting this far!Overall, I would strongly recommend picking this up (especially if it's on sale, but the devs definitely earned the money asked). Many of the negative reviews were released at launch, present issues that have since been addressed in virtually all cases. Most of the bad points are fairly minor, primarily to do with communication and visibility.Yes, it's not Dungeon Keeper 3; but that's fine. I personally believe it's better that WFTO is its own game, drawing inspiration from DK but not trying to become it.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2016
												To all you ex-Dungeon Keeper 2 players looking to reignite your love of the game....Buy this game! But beware things are a little different this time.....At first, I was weary of the deviations from DK2 (of which there are many), and wasn't exactly sure if I liked it or not, but over time, I've come to believe this game is actually an improvement on the original.Pros: +Relive DK2 fun in a new and challenging way.+Map editors+Great game mechanics (skills trees, mana locking, sanctuarys etc.)+MultiplayerCons:-Relentless AI (surely this can be toned down?)-The add crash or glitch (particulary on multiplayer)The single player is great fun, and a great way to learn how the new game functions. My main grievance is just how relentless the AI is. It really is ridiculously hard sometimes. Features such as mana locking and skills tree seem annoying at first, but you begin to realise that it's a mechanic that actually makes gameplay far more enjoyable in the long run.For me the multiplayer is the best (and sometime worst) part of the game. This is the closest I've come to reliving those glory days of LAN'ing DK2 with friends, so I can't recommend this game enough for this reason alone. My main frustration comes from the odd crash when a large battle starts (which lets be honest, was far more regular on the orginal DK2). The game is far less geared toward defence (compared with DK2), so rather than lengthly stalemates, games can be won/lost within half an hour or so.In short, this game is will delight those familiar with DK2, but will still provide a new challenge with it's tweaking on the mechanics. There are still the odd glitches which need to be ironed out, but these are few and far between, and don't effect the overall enjoyment of the game.

												A unique RTS that focuses on you building your dungeon and making sure its balanced, provides food, bed and other needs *cough*VAMPIRES*cough*  for your army of minions. Sounds easy but as the difficulty ramps up and more is added to the mix you may end up with somthing like three of your own animated gold statues that you built and trained turning on you because you cant afford the gold to keep them running, oh yeah there are enemies too.Its an RTS game with a twist. Your minions act however they see fit. You may influence their decision, but outside of the posession spell and the banner that says "Attack Here" you and your opponent have little to no direct control of any outcome in this game.For everyone who was a fan of the 2 dungeon keeper games this game is not only inspired by it but pays tribute to it many times, and thats just within the passive dialogue. Great game, Every bit as good as its predecessors but with more stuff.By the way. In this game. You are the bad guy. :)

								Review updates on 26th Dec 2014 :  the latest patch provides 3 campaign maps to play , a lot of improved texture on rooms and creature animation in general , with almost fully functional unit combats and rooms, the game is shaping up into an amazing dungeon management game that screams with the 'DUNGEON KEEPER SEQUEL ' vibe  . Missed the chance to pledge for the project on kickstarter , the moment it released on Steam I got it right away .    The developers of the game are really hardworking , they have updates on the game quite frequently and new information every week and often hold live stream sessions on twitch.tv to answer questions from the players . content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Great game. Especially fun if you like the Dungeon Keeper series. It felt like "Dungeon Keeper 3" to me, which I really consider a compliment!Pro'sReally brings you back to the good old days, playing the bad guy for once instead!Very original strategy game, trying to attract creatures based on certain roomsTakes many good ideas from the Dungeon Keeper series and improved on them or made quality-of-life improvementsConsCreature spawning mechanics and dictating which creatures you get are two things I still don't understand. Certain rooms attract certain creatures, but which ones spawn and how many you can get max etc. confused me all the way up to the endThere's no "priority list" like in games such at the Settlers where you can force certain actions to have priority over other. For example where to bring defeated monsters (to the crypt, or the prison for.. other uses? :D ).It felt easier than the Dungeon Keeper series. Then again I was younger when I played that so it could've been due to that, too.I would've loved if the game had even more rooms and "forces" you to decide on a certain build, like focussing on sorcery, invest heavily into beasts, conversion of enemies, traps & alchemy, or just raw muscle power via the training room. Right now you can do everything really well and I often ended up trying to challenge myself by picking one. All in all, an awesome game!

content:
Posted: March 22
												This is Dungeon Keeper 3.It retains the charm and familiarity of the original games; you tag the earth, imps mine out rooms, a host of evil creatures are attracted to your dungeon, plenty of heroes are killed (or tortured) and the always welcome tones of Richard Ridings (the mentor from DK1 & 2) will once again guide you on your way to conquering the underworld.Only there’s more of everything this time around. More creatures to attract and convert, more rooms, more traps, and the addition of potions, rituals and constructs. There are more game modes alongside the main campaign, including crucible mode where you can fight endless and increasingly difficult waves of enemies, there are sandbox and scenario levels (and you can create your own in the map editor) and multiplayer and skirmish levels.And the developers are still working on more, pet dungeons have been announced and are going to be added soon and who knows what might come after that.

content:

Early Access Review
								Early access done properly and a game that is respectful of it's influences. Regular updates, assets and game play done to the highest standard. This is one of the few games on Steam I can recommend picking up early. However, I wouldn't recommend playing it early - what is there presently s very solid and produced to a high standard, but developing a game properly takes time and this is more of an investment in my eyes. A game that is shaping up to be fantastic but due to a focus on doing things properly and promptly as opposed to just quickly, functionality is still lacking compared to what the final product should offer. That said, patching and updates are both regular and frequent and what is already in place is very enjoyable and picking it up on the cheap now is a definite good call.If you enjoyed Dungeon Keeper - and who didn't? - this is well worth your cash-moniez.

number of helpful: 20 of 34 people (59%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												HelloAs someone who liked the old dungeon keeper games, when I saw this game go on kickstarter I was very excited about it. This genre of game is unique in a sense that you are the evil. You build a kingdom but you cannot control those who join your cause and your style of building defines what archetype of mobs join you. I must say that for a game that has just released it is to be expected to have a slightly buggy experience, however in this case there really are bugs everywhere. The game feels unfinished. When you open up the menu after installing and click multiplayer the first thing that prompts up is, this will be patched in. The same happens when you click survival mode, and when you click skirmish there is a shocking three maps. The only fully functional mode as of right now is the campaign. This was already a huge letdown, minutes after finishing my download.I didn't let it phase me and I went for the campaign. Now from the very start I ran into bugs and problems. As a former dungeon keeper player and with many games behind my belt I have a good idea on how to play games. Now this is very important because the tutorial is horrible. They barely scrape the surface of what buildings do, there is no explanation what so ever how the controls work. I was unable to move my camera, had issues with targetting. You'd figure okay, I will read the tooltips but frankly, there are no useful tooltips anywhere in the game to be found. Mostly there are placeholders from an early alpha build. "shrine prop siege" doesn't tell me what it does? The big thing for this game is the micro management of the buildings, however there is no explanation on how the sizes of your exhibits have to be in order to recruit units. The props are invisible. And you can slap units but there is no real talk on how it affects efficiency. So I went in completely blind. Now the early campaign maps are fairly easy, straightforward objectives and simple tasks. With no time pressure that is good. The only problem is that you cannot build anything else while you have a certain task. Build a X on this tile. Then you cannot continue to do what you were doing, it forces you to do something specific, some of the cutscene 'talks' appear to be unskippable and this is just tiny annoyances everywhere. I pushed onward, in a quite bad mood now. And then I encountered many little bugs. I summoned a vampire, it went mad. Started killing my units but I had no idea how to fix that. Everytime I cast a scouting ritual my pc froze up completely. Now I have a really expensive modern pc less than two months old. That is just bad scripting. Lag, delay and crashes occurred regulary. I had units bug into the wall and frankly no idea what half of the spells, flasks or shrines are for. The possesion spell, which was a huge thing, is completely broken.So yes. I did finish the campaign. It took me roughly 12 hours. I only had to restart one map which I failed on my part. So through the buggy experience I can say that the campaign has a good design, it is versatile and interesting. The small storyline has a funny plot to it. But its so dissatisfyingly short, and the experience was a chain hindrance of little problems that I can't say I fully enjoyed it. There was no map that was challenging in the entire campaign and by the time most buildings and plots are revealed you are done. I then decided to take on the AI in skirmishes just to see what the full experience would be like. Considering I hadn't had that strong opponents in the campaign. Now I took on every AI setting on master, they were challenging. So I will say that the game definatly has potential. It is fun in design, fun in concept and I'm sure that with some more patches and content this will be a good game. For those who have seen the totalbiscuit WTF video, what he says is very true. This game looks like it will be worthwhile, in 6months or more to come. As of right now, I cannot recommend this game. I personally found it fun, but I am dissapointed in what I consider a premature release and I hope the developpers will put effort into this game, and make it great. As I think it can be.

Early Access Review
								As a massive fan of the Dungeon Keeper games, I cannot express the joy I felt when stumbling upon this.It's everything I wanted to see in a new DK game, and more. New rooms, new creatures, new game mechanics, and of course not to mention new graphics, it's really exciting to see where this project is going because they've done a damn good job this far in development already.Those unfamiliar with the game-style in question should consider researching the Dungeon Keeper series (or just watch a gameplay video) for this is no ordinary RTS, it is one of the few games falling under the category of RTS/FPS hybrid: feel like touring the layout of your dungeon from the perspective of your minions? Well go ahead and tap right into their skulls! Admiring the detail the developers have clearly put into the various dungeon rooms from up close is a feeling no other game can replicate for me, a particular reason which makes the franchise as a whole so unique.I would buy the game twice I'm that happy with it, but I'm broke and have no need for a second copy therefore I will not be doing that

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												So far, this game is mostly what I hoped it would be. I waited until the bumpy release to buy it, and so far, I haven't run into any bugs other than an occassional spike in lag when I use the ritual which reveals the whole map at once for ten seconds. The art is mostly pleasing, though I tend to like how the hero faction's theme was designed more than the standard Underlord theme. The game so far does a good job at introducing you to key concepts without making the tutorial seem dull, even for an RTS/Dungeon Keeper 1/2 player like me. The campaign can be challenging at times, but a little easy at others. As of now, there are few skirmish maps, but there will be a patch soon that will supposedly add quite a number of maps, which has me pleased. The best thing, though, would be to release a map editor to conjoin with the steam workshop or something so that the game makers can allow the community to create their own maps. For personal tastes, I like and have a hard time accepting this game at times. I like how diverse you can make your forces on the campaign, but limiting things in skirmish maps based on technology (Sin) trees seems silly in the sense that if I play long enough, I'd like to have access to everything available, rather than be limited in what I can do longterm. Along with that, I have a problem with the types of available creatures in the game- nothing seems to be like an "end-game" level creature other than the super-creatures, which you can't upgrade or train at all, and you can only ever get one. While I LOVE the hero units because I like the idea of having my own super minion, I'd like for the "1" on their HP flower to be a non-number icon, or to allow the supers to level to 10. This would clear up confusion like how I had when I spent a massive amount of time on XP potions in an attempt to level up my Eternal minion. Continuing on this creature-focused section, I think there should be more "high-end" creatures. Right now, the best creatures at the further points of the Sin tree are mostly casters or support-type creatures. The exception to this are the Shadow/Bafu, which in all honesty are not THAT beefy (I'm thinking Black Knights from DK2), and are difficult to train since the Beastmasters can't train the creatures as quickly as some of your intelligent minions can train. To be fair, though, it seems that the beast talent path is designed for aggro strategies, which means their high-end units won't be that incredible. The neutral tree basically only offers casters, which are all nice to have at times, but they don't offer a real frontline other than with the horde of ghouls your Necromancers can build up over time. That being said, the necromancers themselves are incredibly vulnerable to well-placed lightning strikes from your opponents, which can make all of the hard work from your ghoul farming go to waste in a matter of seconds. The defense tree offer the Augre, which is as close to a true tank of a non-super minion. Even so, they are not exactly what I was hoping for. What I hope for in the future, is an addition of the variety of creatures in both theme and purpose. Right now it seems that the main design of the creatures is "beast/beast humanoid," with a couple of demons and a human and a couple of undead for spice. While I love the addition of the beasts and all, it would be great to have more "dark humans," demons, and undead to accompany the beasts abd beast-men.~~~~~~TLDR:Pros:-Keeps the Spirit of DK2 gameplay-Campaign has good pace for the most part-Few Bugs now-Gameplay is mostly funCons:-Rocky release-Lag when using a very specific ritual-Lag if you keep the game runing on the main menu for too long (occasionally)-No map editorWould be cons if they weren't being fixed:-Low amount of Skirmish Maps (adding more soon)-Bugs in Survival Mode (fixing soon)Personal Preference Stuff:-Creature diversity seems to be off (Too many beastial types and not enough demons/humans/undead/other)-Narrator sounded better as a snide aide/friend (DK2) as opposed to an arrogant, omniscient demon god-The narrator can be hilarious at times-The voice acting on the enemy dungeon lords is very good at times-The graphics are pleasing

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I have been seeing alot of negaite reviews for this game, so I decided to post one that I think is fair.The first question I will answer is if I recommend this game to others: Of course I do. I have supported this game for a long time and watched it grow. If you are looking for a dungeon management/ rts like game, then this si the one you should get. The voice acting is fantastic. Some of the quotes in the game caught me completely off guard while I was playing, for instance he says, "You did buy this game right?" while I was taking forever to clear a campaign level. Also, the AI in the game has a great range for all skill types. You can put it on easy as you learn the game, and there is even a specific AI that was built, which opperates in the rules of the game, that is near impossible to beat. Thus, there is challenege for all players. I have just finished my forst 10 hours of the game and I cannot wait to put many more in.Now to talk about how everyone is complaining about the bugs in the game:Yes , there are some bugs in the final release and not all modes are fully functional and in prototype phase. The game is fun to play now, reguardless of bugs. Also, the dev's for this game are amazing. It has only been out for a day and there has been 4 or 5 updates in fixing to fix the bugs. Yes, some people are frustrated with the bugs, but I feel as if the game is very enjoyable even with them. Some features like survival are still in prototype and will be fully functional in the near future. I wanted to comment on the fact that I have played the survival prototype and it works very well as is.  Overall, this is a fantastic game and it was worth the few years wait in order to enjoy this game. The dev's are great with their community and I see them respond in the forums daily. Do not walk away from this game just because of a few bugs. Buy it, enjoy it, and tell others the same so this game doesn't die due to others throwing a fit over a few bugs.

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												Avid Dungeon Keeper fan, started playing it just 6 years old. I've owned this game since it first dropped on the workshop, I've followed it's progress throughout, occasionally launching the game to have a quick peek then waiting till it was done. Finally let myself play the campaign now I figured it would be polished enough months after release.Bugs, just bugs everywhere. First impression, stutter before the menu loaded, then the button disappeared whenever I hovered over them, then when I finally manager to change screen resolution I had to force shut the application and restart to get it working again. On load the second time menu items white checkerboard everywhere, glitching and lagging into the campaign menu. I so want this game to be good.Into the first level, seems fairly okay, dialogue lines are being repeated randomly, adnimations are a bit wooden, but whatever, nostalgia overload - graphics are pretty awesome and Richard Ridings sounds awesome - I could see it being stellar. Second level, well I had to play the first one again for whatever reason, but when it eventually loaded the first condition of with selecting a "Vein of Evil" couldn't be done because it wasn't an option on the panel, trying to exit the game I had to force quit because once again the menu wouldn't load.I can't believe after a couple of years this game is still unplayable. I've seen how much work the devs have put in, but I just get the impression it launched too soon (maybe for cashflow reasons), and it's several revisions in and still pretty unplayable, at least for me.I want this game to be good, guess I'll check back in after another few versions to see if it's sorted yet.

												i was a huge fan and put many hours into Dungeon Keeper. that being said.. i love what's been done so far, but MAJOR elements (imo) are still missing. you need to be able to beat your minions into doing things they'd rather not. you need to be able to lock them in a room and have them keep working in fear of more beatings, even as they starve to death. like a good minion should. it may seem harsh, but this is the mind set every good dungeon keeper should have.i only got 4 stages or so in so far.. but none of my knocked out creatures are being dragged back to their beds to heal. i can't toss creatures i don't want, right back out the way they came in.. in hopes of getting a different creature etc.i can't hand feed those worthless little ♥♥♥♥♥ as a reward or to keep them working. i can't bribe them with riches either.all in all though, i'm really glad this game was made.. though hoping certain things are added, i've had fun playing it.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												I put off buying War For The Overworld for a very long time, principly because I believed there was no chance in hell it could live up to the legend that is Dungeon Keeper.I was sure it would just be a cheap imitation of a classic game with no original thought or work put into it, just ideas and concepts stolen from Dungeon Keeper, reskinned to look "original" and packed into a half baked game not worth its price.Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥was I wrong.It's pretty damn great. Some minor problems concerning visual glitches and momentary freezes but otherwise it lives up to the reputation of Dungeon Keeper. The only major problem I have with War For The Overworld is how Mana works, I much preferred the mana system in Dungeon Keeper 2 where you are rewarded with a faster mana income from aggressive expansion but leave yourself vulnerable to attack. Sadly there is little strategical advantage you can get from amassing a large mana pool because there isn't a "quick" way to get it.The Developers clearly knew what they doing and what they aimmed to achieve with this game, and they succeeded in leaps and bounds. There's more than enough new concepts and game mechanics to make this title stand out from it's inspiration as a true spirital successor.Well done.

												Hello,This game really kicks in after the 4th campaign mission; at least for me it had a very good first impression, than it went to "omg, they did it like 40 times more complicated compared to the original Dungeon Keeper" and started hating that (during the first missions they teach you all about constructs/defenses/spells/rooms/creatures/orders, even the creatures are divided in beasts and other kinds and it all feels like they complicated everything and they often give you not only all these news but special "rooms" you will not see in the next levels anymore, so I let you guess how it felt compared to DK that really comes easily in your hands), but really you need not more than 4 levels to feel that you somehow understood everything, that you somehow are starting getting more fun with these "defenses" that you ever had in DK, that you somehow love the possibility to re-create walls for a huge gold's cost, you recover the first impression and these little details do not bother you anymore and a few even kicks in perfectly to improve it.Also the graphics and animations are so improved from the first time I playied the alpha (a few hours and than I waited till now, when the majority of peoples informed it was fine and I also reported and helped witht he last bug which they resovled the day later I gave them the steps to reproduce it directly in this steam forum), this really seems completely on AAA level.I feel this really is the 3rd DK, I only miss the old creatures for now, but I'm still at 1/3 of the campaign and I still need to meet so much, but I already feel that I jumped the worst obstacle in liking this game.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit (12 June 2014): Since version 0.4.2 the OS X build and the Linux build are working well again! The game is also much more stable as it was when I wrote this review. The developers now also actively involve the users of WFTO in testing the game; they now often release previews in which the newest features and fixes are available at a seperate beta-branch at Steam. WFTO also works well if you have a low-end-machine, so don't worry about that. And if it does not work right on your low-end-machine; the developers will do more optimatization to WFTO in the comming versions, so it even runs faster as it already does! :)This will maybe be even better then Dungeon Keeper; it now has a lot of rooms, many characters and very nice graphics. The 20 euros are worth it! The developers give everyone even acces to pre-beta, so you can test the newest content and maybe even report bugs to help the developers finisching this game ;) They publish at least once a week news on their main website about the development progress and answer a lot of questions on their forums. Never saw that kind of developers with so much humor! :)They have fixed many bugs and crashes in the last months; I can surely say it's playable, you will sometimes maybe see a tiny little bug or a very rarely crash (got a few ones so far,) but you can play the levels like a charm. WFTO even contains a debug mode and debug console with which you can mess around with the game :)There are known problems about that you can only play an old version of WFTO on Mac OSX at the moment, but this is not caused by WFTO itself; it is a bug at the Unity side and the Unity team is working on resolving this issue for everyone, so you will probably soon be able to play the latest version of this game on MAC OSX soon! See here for more updates on this: https://forum.subterraneangames.com/threads/488-osx-version-of-the-game-is-not-up-to-date.4981/They are still working on polishing the UI, AI, graphics etc (but you can play it very well at the moment!). But it's worth to buy it now already and help the developers to finish the game, but the game is now also a little bit cheaper then after the release!!! Grab your chance now and get this game Keeper/Underlord!

												Any fan of the Ol' Good Dungeon Keeper series MUST play this game.Anyone who have waited for DK 3 MUST play this game.The developers have brought back what DK series were shining at, and brought everything back with the original playability, with crisp gorgeous HD graphics.The original evil concierge voice that was in DK2 is here, with occational fun punch lines during play - although they tend to repeat what is said not 5 minutes ago.The graphics and in-game props are almost similar to that of DK2, along with the same pickaxe holding hand. - But in higher polygon count and higher texture quality, and the devs. have managed to have the feel of DK series.The game play goes same, from the ol' trusty imp slapping, lightning spells that fries whatnots, to that of 5X5 tiles which bother those with OCDs (like myself).Well made, well played.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												As others have said: I really hoped this game would be good, being a huuuuge Dungeon Keeper fan myself. But even after roughly a year, and patch 1.5, it still feels very buggy and incomplete. I just finished the campaign and feel somewhat dissatisfied...The game is ambitious, as it comes with a big load of extra tactical depth - at least in theory. It has the Dungeon Keeper feeling but in many many occasions it does not feel thought-through, as there many many features (potions, contructs, creature types, war bands, rituals etc etc) that just rise and do not shine because the gameplay is too hectic and chaotic. Eventually you'll just zerg-rush anyway.E.g. after 13 (short) levels I still have no idea what the abilities of 95% of the creatures do, since the only way to figure them out is the use the (very very clunky) posession spell - which unfortunately is completely useless apart from that. I used basically only two or three out of the dozen potions/rituals/contructs/defences, simply because I didnt have to (and there was no space to develop a strategy anyway, since there is hardly any time to dig, explore and plan) All in all, It feels a bit like a dry and chewy Kobe-beef steak: At some point there were the perfectly right ingredients, but they did not manage to create something great out of it. Which is a pity

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Before we even get in to gameplay - I feel I have to point out just how much time and effort the dev team have put into this game since the days of early release. When the game first came out in beta - touted as the spiritual successor to DK2, it was full of bugs, glitches, frustrations and was pretty unplayable.Fast forward to now, and we have what's basically a different game to when it started; with huge patches, and now an official expansion pack. What a journey - and I have to give credit where credit is due to the developers, in regards to their time, effort, and the way they've interacted and responded to the community feedback.The game itself - in my opinion is everything we could have hoped for, if there ever was an official DK3. Updated graphics, new (very inventive) units, spells, skills; but of course all the original charm of the series we love, including the voice work! :)Really enjoying playing this, and presume I will contunue to do so for some time. To all fans of dungeon sims - don't hesitate. I don't think you'll be disappointed! Welcome back Underlords.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
War for the OversoldAfter sinking 10 hours into the game, I feel versed enough to textualise my 2c. Early Access and the like are quite clearly labelled which this game "was", now well past there official launch and 8 hot fixes later, it still very much is.The UI is cluttered, unusable in parts, I've not checked if there are keyboard shortcuts to offset this, but largely I don't really care - I have a mouse I want to use it. That's how I play (badly). There is a masse of technical text when hovering over just about anything, I am fairly confident some of this is to be masked. But it already should have been before the "exit" from Early Access.Little quirks soon become very annoying, the narrator loves to remind me that my Tavern is too small. Hats off you're probably right narrator, if I'd actually built a tavern. If not the tavern then micro piglets, yes that large football pitch sized pig farm is too small. Parts of the campaign are pure frustration, any amount of play testing would highlight this. It feels neglected, where I would argue the large appeal of a DK spirtual sequel would be the campaign. It is for me at least. Impasse flags disappear causing all sorts of problems trying to stop minions expanding too far - the whole point of the impasse system. I'd love it, if it worked 100%.I wrestled with L7 to be met with a very easy almost boring L8 which seemed bug as I killed everything in the map and no end game was triggered. My enthusiasm to try that one has twindled greatly. And was the triggering mechanism for me to write this review.Summary judgementAt it's roots this game has a great feel to it, reminding me of DK and DK2 but bringing little extras to the experience. Unfortunately all the good is drastically out weighed by small problems such as bugs or balance issues/AI, they all snowball into one and leave me feeling beat up about the whole thing.You cannot release a game from Early Access in such a state, it's just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I cannot say I will be following any further titles from this development studio.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. Being a big fan of what it's trying to mimic, Dungeon keeper 2. It falls short in every aspect that made the other game great. The base building in the campaign is severely restricted, indestructable blocks everywhere. It's way too fast paced, especially compared to what it's supposed to be the spiritual successor of. It has far too many gimmicky functions that just makes it more complicated than it has to without adding any fun to it whatsoever. The narrator talks constantly, to the point where you want to strangle him. A plus though is that it's the same guy who voice acted the mentor in DK2 just that he is now incredibly irritating instead of helpful and witty. You might like it if you have nothing to compare it to but if you're a fan of DK2 and you're expecting a DK3 you'll be disappointed.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												'Dungeon Keeper'. Yeah. You can't escape the fact that this is the game that you buy if you wanted a Dungeon Keeper 3 (or a decent DK2).  You will typically start the game looking for a creature portal, building rooms for sleeping, eating and training, and finding the starting gold vain. Nothing new there.But this game stands strong in it's own right. Obviously, it just isn't quite DK. Hating it for this seems to be a hobby for many fans. But the game deserves to be treated as though it stands on it's own: and it certainly can. If DK had never existed, this game would be hailed as an innovative marvel. Instead, it is simply a fun, workable game using the same formula. An early example of a nice little innovation is the Tavern building: Minions will pay some of their wages back to you for cooked food and beer, but you need to keep it stocked, giving an interesting strategic choice. Things such as this give the game a feeling of depth without making it micro-manage hell.The game is worth the money. You will have fun playing a dungeon-building strategy game. It is not DK. Get over it.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												First off, great work Stubterranean games! I've been a backer of this project from its inception, and other than the occasional 5 minute bout every six months to get a feel for how things were coming along I've all but avoided every piece of news about the game in the hopes that I wouldn't spoil myself for release.I'm a long time fan of the Dungeon Keeper series and fondly remember as a 10 year old sinking entire school holidays into figuring out how to deal with digging into clusters of level 10 Samurais. Dungeon Keeper has and always will have a place on my hard drive alongside many of the Bullfrog classics, back when Peter Molyneux could keep up with his big ideas. How the mighty have fallen! Anyway my review ;It's no secret that this game is a spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper, and while I want to keep in mind that it is it's own beast and I shouldn't directly compare for the sake of biasing myself, inevitably, and inescapably, this is something that will be part of this review. Thankfully whether that's right or wrong, WftO in my opinion has nailed the atmosphere extremely well. The background hum of dank dungeon corridors and the deep, thumping beat of your dungeon heart, alongside your insidious sounding, witty assistant has thrown me back to my schooldays. Dungeon design itself I have mixed feelings about. There doesn't seem to be as much of an incentive to place down traps or dig your dungeon out in areas to encompass rooms and a necessity to mine out entire areas to make use of the tiles you get is apparant. I feel like the actual map sizes don't compliment the number of rooms given particularly well, even if the rooms themselves are well thought out in terms of theme and function. Something as simple as converting particular rooms and their functions into room addons may be able to accomodate this where it makes sense - The Sanctuary's functions placed in the centre of a library with an expensive altar for example, or unlocking an arena pen to attract your Beast Master which you could then place on the grounds of an expansive and somewhat barren Beast Lair to fill it out. I would assume at least for the campaign, fiddling with map sizes would require a horrendous amount of work, so combining rooms with a usefulness that seems somewhat saturated would possibly be a good direction. Some rooms feel a little empty and as a whole the sheer number of room types doesn't translate well to the room you tend to have on each map.The maps themselves from a campaign standpoint are well thought out, the variation of mission types is welcome and I'm glad as it brings a particular flavour to each map which allows you to apply your creativity in different ways. Dungeon planning was always a big part of Dungeon Keeper and I feel like the variation offered in each map is similar enough to give you that "lets get to work, I got this" feel, without making everything too samey and keeping you on your toes somewhat.My biggest gripe is creatures and battle. I have found myself a few times leaving rally flags sitting up against an enemy keeper after all but wiping each other out, resulting in a 30 minute long battle that pumps every level 1 spawn on either side into one place until something ever so slightly tips the balance. It doesn't feel decisive enough to be satisfying, as does the level increases for each minion. Level 5 and 6 creatures feel somewhat irrelevent, especially when you consistently go up against them in the campaign with swathes of level 1s, and having a level 10 creature doesn't have that feeling of acomplishment that DK had. There is a feeling of overwhelming higher level units which again is not a good thing - I just feel like something is missing when it comes to how satisfying this is. I feel like more emphasis should be placed on the power of each level and battles should feel a little more decisive, in return I'd welcome a higher difficulty although I understand if some people would be put off by this.Another couple pointers is the minimap. More clarity would be helpful, as would a little more intuitiveness in regards to what's going on where. And the hand! The actual reference point is lost on the hand and I really feel this needs redesigned to better handle some of the UI. The rally flags on the left for example require pinpoint precision to the point where the concentration to do so successfully is immersion breaking, and I regularly find myself missing torture racks when I try to drop heroes, even when it feels otherwise.Bugs I don't particularly want to go into - Every time I check my downloads on Steam there's another massive patch and I'm quite happy to hold off negativity regarding this (which other than a restart of a map due to a broken ritual doesn't bother me. If you're playing this kind of game specifically to win the map you're on then I suggest you sit back, relax and enjoy letting your creativity run wild instead!), but it's nice to see so much work getting put into addressing issues that other players may have a harder time dealing with.All in all, WftO is a great spiritual successor to DK, most definitely one of the best, you can see from the outset that the team really understands the intricacies and have most definitely made it their own while paying homage. I love to see what happens next and all in all I'm very satisfied with backing Subterranean.Whether you're an old player or new to the whole concept, I suggest you take a look, regardless of whether it's for nostalgia or just for a new experience. I hold DK in a VERY high regard and consider Bullfrog part of a golden age which wasn't swamped by corporate fatcats, and true creativity was something to be welcomed and encouraged. I'm very happy to see a dev team capture the essence of this in a way that really pays homage to the concept as a whole. A modern DK has been a long time coming and I'm glad to say it's almost there. Just a little more work Subterranean, a touch more clarity and you got this.Keep up the good work, you won over a venerable Keeper!

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Pfffff okay, here goes.I played Dungeon Keeper 2 almost non-stop for an inconceivable amount of time. After which, I wondered if they were going to make a Dungeon Keeper 3. I was elated to hear that the answer was "yes and no". There would be a Dungeon Keeper 3, but it wouldn't be *called* Dungeon Keeper 3.This game lives up to and surpasses my wildest expectations. It's fun, comical, challenging, and intense. This studio did an absolutely incredible job on this game, and I highly recommend it.That being said, you should be prepared for a few bugs and glitches, at least at the time of this review. I am quite certain that they will get everything resolved at some point, but at the moment I've had to handle a few hair-pull worthy issues. At one point, when hitting the ESC key to save my game, the game froze and eventually crashed on me. In another instance, two of my minions appeared to be stuck in a lake. They were wandering around in circles incessantly, clearly befuddled by why their master had abandoned them. Not to worry, though. A quick spanking or three sent them back on their merry way.Overall, I highly recommend this game. I paid 36$ for the Underlord Edition and do not regret my purchase in the least, despite a few hiccups that are presently in the game.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												War for the Overworld is essentially a Dungeon Keeper 2 remake with a heavy emphasis on blitzing your enemy. At this point, I have made it to level 12 and have yet to actually enjoy making a dungeon as the game has kept me locked in with impenetrable rock and busy fending off attackers from minute one. I tried out skirmish mode in the hope that it would allow for more relaxed dungeon building, but yet again, the AI focused solely on blitzing my dungeon core before I even realized I had to unlock every room in my tool panel before being able to use it.If you loved Dungeon Keeper 2, and you love blitzing your enemy then this game is for you. If you loved Dungeon Keeper and enjoyed building dungeons, then Dungeons and Dungeons II are more your style but they are still entirely different games.Pros:Fairly Evil NarratorDK2 styleDark HumorCons:Blitz heavyDK2 Style InterfaceToo Much Impenetrable rockEnemies can dig through your walls

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												Core game is a pretty good attempt at a "Dungeon Keeper 3". Closer to DK2 than to DK1 in atmosphere, graphical style and gameplay. Core campaign is lackluster, level design is mediocre and it's very easy. Expansion campaign, however, is enjoyable and well thought out. It's short though, just 4 levels and still too easy.Monster abilities are not well presented and monsters have a lot less character than DK1/2.Balance wise vampires are too strong and leveling is too easy.Multiplayer is completely broken as clients crash after 20-60 minutes into the game. Defenses are too weak, you're usually dead if you lose a fight in multiplayer.Summary: This game is like DK2 for me, it's a good game but doesn't capture the same feeling as DK1. I recommend it but if you're buying it to play with friends then make sure they patched the multiplayer bug first.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Updated ReviewI tend not to like games that stay in early access for 2 years as this one did then gets released unfinished. It defeats the point of early access in my book. It is now July 2015, 4 months after War for the Overworld was released and it finally has enough Skirmish maps to make it worth playing in single player. An update to Unity 5 seems to have improved performance too.It has enough units, powers and spells to keep most dungeon keeper fans happy, and it brings enough of its own tricks to the table so it cannot be accused of being a straight forward clone of the old classic. If it has any problem it is that it has too many rooms and monsters for most maps, you will find your self without the room to the build them all. So your going to have to choose what you want and what you do not want.Previously I recommended this game but only just, stating a lack of maps and other unfinished features meant you would be left waiting to play it because it was not finished.Also, previously, I said 7 out of 10 on metacritics user score was about right, it is now at 7.3 and rising on metacritics because the game is finally playable. In it is current state it is worth about an 8. Though the campaign pretty much sucks with its timers and shows a distinct lack of imagination, mind you so do the new maps. What is it with devs these days and their symetrical maps ?Recommended.... finally...

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												Love this game, feels like the next "Dungeon Keeper" which players of the originals will notice the little nods to its roots.+Plenty of content+Home Realm (Build at your leisure and unleash waves of enemies)+Humor+Variant Underlords (Each once has a different look to it and the workers)-Fast paced-Skirmish maps included are small-Short CampaignThis is a great game, but I spent alot of time playing DK1 and DK2, and the way WrtO differs seems to be in its pace, more so in skirmish against AI, the thing I enjoyed about DK was the slower pace, once you got past the tutorial levels you would normally start on one huge map which you had to spend time gathering gold and leveling up your minions, where as this one kinda forces you to play fast and with limited space, so theres no extravagant massive rooms you can build since you really need to use the space you have effectively.The units themselves are very nicely done, but once again it lacks the content DK had, so if you dont know, on DK you had to manage your minions, and by this I mean there wasnt just a single minion per room so for instance in DK if you got a Fly and a Spider, you would normally have to try and keep them in seperate lairs because if they bump into once other when they arent training or using rooms they would attack and try to kill one another, this presenting a challenge if you wanted to keep both but served as something you really needed to keep an eye on, whereas in WftO there is just one type of minion per room and a empire version, none of your minions conflict everyone gets along very nicely.Now the "Vampire" unit I do like very much, having to keep a steady supply to keep them appeased and in return you get a very powerful unit, so here im going to refer to DK1 and you can proberly guess I mean the "Horned Reaper" which was the games icon, which the Vampire unit itself is a nod to, both units need 3 units sacrificed to get one in return, whereas the vampire just needs food to stay happy, the Horned Reaper, well he was undeniably the strongest unit in the game but came with the biggest price, if you held him for to long he got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if you slapped him he got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ if he was bored he got♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and he would begin slaughtering your own minions for the damn well fun of it, and a level 10 version of him would wipe out most of your minons, which would make you either decide on building a seperate mini-dungeon and lock him in it til you was ready to fight or having to get rid.Refering to the pervious point there was the "Temple" room, which you sacrificed units to make ones you needed or the Horned Reaper, but it served a second function, any creatures rebelling or Horned Reaper going on a rampage you could drop them on the outskirts of this room and they would pray and calm down over a period of time, now when they rebel in WftO you pretty much have to take them down, I could be wrong but at this present time I cant see anyway to calm them down, showered them with gold/food and they still wont revert from rebellion status.All in all the thing about these games is feeling like the bad guy, and DK did that great, WftO goes down the same road but doesnt give me that "Evil" vibe, aslong as you have food and gold, all your minions will hold hands and slip to battle, but here I am just remembering how much I loved DK, this game gets frequent patches and updates so who knows, maybe it will end up that way, but it is a great game and the closest ive seen to being a "Dungeon Keeper" for a long time  and is definatly worth playing, more so if you loved the DK games. TL;DRWftO is a great game, I ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan about how much I miss "Dungeon Keeper".  :D

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												So I've never played Dungeon Keeper before but have been hearing how great the game is. So I've played Dungeons 2 and have enjoyed it a lot and found the idea and gameplay intriguing. But reviews from Dungeons 2 also point to War for the Overworld, so I check this game out as well, since a recent Steam friend made a review of this game. Both Dungeons 2 and War for the Overworld are two entirely different beasts. Sure, they both try to follow one theme, that is, managing a dungeon, but the way both games play is completely different and is a matter of preference. I really recommend both games, but Wars for the Overworld is heavily focused on the dungeon aspect of the genre, very gritty, dark, but abnormally delightful. Wars for the Overworld is a little more serious than Dungeons 2 which is not a bad thing. The game is VERY polished in my honest opinion. AGAIN, Steam reviews are lying to me, I see all these little nit-picking and negative claims yet when I play the game it feels fantastic. You can tell there was a lot of work put into this game, and being a player who has no experience with Dungeon Keeper, I can safely say I like what this game has to offer. I've always glossed over all sorts of dungeon builders because 1) they usually aren't my thing, and 2) they are usually old and outdated games that will have too many technical problems to run. That is not the case with War for the Overworld, this is a very much a polished and stable game. Again, I have a decent rig, but this game surprsiingly runs well on my computer, so all those announcements and news of optimization by the developers is beliveable as the game is very stable. When I first viewed the screenshots I was worried that I would not be able to run this game because it looked gorgeous. In-game they are even better, and feel that this is a very good product. Something I held off for a long time because of all the bad games I've run into that have been released in 2015-2016, and marked this off something that was bland or uninterseting. Turns out I've been missing out all this time, and if you are reading this review, then yes, you are missing out on something good. This is a great game, I highly recommend you give this game a try.

												*revision*Patch 1.1 took care of most of the issues that were keeping me from enjoying the game; i'm having quite a bit of fun now.  i appreciate the continued attention to this game and i can now honestly recommend it!As with most people who own this game, I'm a huge fan of the Dungeon Keeper games and was looking forward to this one.  In it's current state however, i cannot suggest this game to anyone.  Clearly unfinished, this game has too many glaring issues;-terrible AI-glitchy/slow UI-crashes-walls/ dungeon setup becomes useless as fortified walls break down easily-Campaign levels are short in supply and lack difficulty; little strategy is needed to blow through all 13.WFTO has alot of potential but seems as though it was rushed to release once the developers hit the halfway mark.  With some tweaks and updates this game could easily be worth the $30 price.  At the moment however, I regret purchasing this game.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												It's Dungeon Keeper 3....and it's AWESOME!The good:War for the Overworld is Dungeon Keeper 3 in all but name! Richard Ridings (of the original Dungeon Keeper games) is back voicing the mentor, telling you to get building glorious dungeons to house your minions. The Empire is banging on your dungeon doors and you need all the help you can get.This all add's up to a lot of fun than fans of the original Dungeon Keeper games never thought we would see again all because a small but very solid dev team Kickstarted this game and I'm so very glad they did.There has been a constant stream of patches and interaction from the devs since I purchased the game and to be honest, they are putting big comapny names to shame in how fast they are to respond to issues.The bad:The game is still a bit rough around the edges and unfinnished in parts. Certain parts of the game have yet to be finnished fully (such as skirmish mode which is to be added later this year) and there is still a lot of ingame tweaking done by the devs. Save games can also be a risk as a quick patch can render a save file unuseable (though thankfully it only means restarting a level). It's also one of those games where you'll find yourself binge playing through the whole thing if you're not careful.So..should you buy this game? Most certainly. The main campaign is finnished and multiplayer works. The unfinnished parts are just..extras. It's great fun and it's one of those rare titles where the devs are acctually doing what they say they will do.Now get to work Underlord!

content:
Posted: July 21, 2016
												This game was originally started by people with a lot of heart, who had bitten of way more than they could chew in the year after their kickstarter campaign. And yet even when things seemed to go completely bust they persevered for the sake of their love for the game and their dedication to the community. And after a rocky release this has seriously paid off. This game deserves far more (online) players than it already has and can be considered complete enough. If you are familiar with either RTS or strategy management games you'll be able to learn this very quickly.For some actual reviewing:- A good story and a fun single player campaign.- Fleshed out game mechanics with good balancing.- Precious humorous gems provided, mostly by the beloved voice actor of one of the major characters. He has a voice men would sell their souls for.- Balanced and potentially pretty competitive multiplayer.Very much recommended!

												Being a Fan of the old Dungeon Keeper games from way back when might make me a bit bias when it comes to this game. It is exactly like those classic games that i dearly loved playing when i was growing up. Theres nothing more satisfying that slapping imps until they explode for no other reason than to simply do it. Because, your the bad guy, what do you care what other people think? but the raw perspective of this game is what i enjoy. build your dungeon, fight the hero's be the bad guy for once, and just enjoy the raw destruction you wrought. It's a great way to destress. (slapping imps really helps with that too. just sayin.) If, you've ever enjoyed games like Tropico, Sim City, Ceaser, and at the same time, enjoy a good old fashion RTS combat system. This is your game to play.The only thing this game is really missing is the hillariousness of the Original Dungeon Keeper games. Also where's my Casino Tile? I wanna make my minions gamble all the money i pay them away and refill my coffers the old fashion way.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Short version:Pros:-Same voice actor from the original Dungeon Keeper and Keeper 2, Mr. Richard Ridings, who does a great job!-Looks like a Dungeon Keeper game-Gameplay generally feels like a Dungeon Keeper game-Play the "bad guy"-Dig out a dungeon and stock rooms to attract creatures and then attack the enemy-Torture Chamber is fully operational-Devs are patching bugs and paying attention to player requestsCons (at the time of this review):-Some features are not available yet (sandbox mode & multiplayer)-Creature path finding can be somewhat haphazard-Rooms and creatures do not have enough detail about what they do (still calls things "prop x")-Possession can be difficult to control and once in possession mode no clear explanation about the controls-Memory Leak? Game tends to slow down a lot over the course of playing and occasionally crashes (devs stated they are looking into solving this problem)War for the Overworld is a refreshing change in the standard RTS genre given that you build a dungeon and attack the "good guys". As many know, WftO is the spiritual successor to Dungeon Keepers 1 and 2. This is the game I have been looking for since finishing DK 1&2 in 2000 (15 years!). I am sincerely happy that EA has allowed Subteranean Games to create this clear clone of the Dungeon Keeper franchise.Do not get me wrong, War for the Overworld is not just a facelift for Dungeon Keeper 2. It does have it's own story if you are a plot addict like me. However, the look and gameplay feels just like DK2 on the surface, but is a bit buggy with path finding which I expect will get ironed out. If you have been looking for another Dungeon Keeper look no further and pick this game up since it is what we wished that "Dungeons" was or "Overlord 1&2" were. It is certainly worth the $30 USD (half of what EA would charge if they made it, and it would not be as good) even though it does have some flaws as detailed above. I expect that these flaws will be polished away with a bit of time since these devs are extremely devoted to supporting their product and are enthusiasts themselves for the Dungeon Keeper series.Buyer with a low-end system beware (i.e. less than 8 GB RAM and less than a Quad Core processor running at 2.0 GHz) as this game is somewhat CPU and definitely memory intensive which manifests itself particularly during battles. I know this because I recently had to upgrade my system to run smoothly (I was capped at 3.25GB RAM and it bottlenecked my Quad Core AMD Phenom II @3.2GHz processor). If your system does not meet the minimum requirements, either upgrade or expect slow downs, stability issues, crashing, and even unplayability during gameplay, and don't downvote simply because your PC cannot handle it (I see this too often).All these things being said, I cannot recommend this game enough. WftO is exactly as advertised with regard to being the spiritual successor to DK 1&2. I played this game when it was in early access and enjoyed it then and now even more. This is the only game that I have ever been happy with after purchasing in early access, and I have purchased a fair few.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								At the moment I DO NOT recommend this game. However I see it's potential and over time I can recommend it. There are probably more cons so far than pros. Constant bugs, HUGE fps issues, no save, no multiplayer, only one mission. I know that the developers plan on adding more missions, a save, a multiplayer. However it has been over one year sense initial release of the beta and we still see no improvement BESIDES UI changes and more rooms/creatures. If you are a Dungeon Keeper fan you will love this game however I think you should wait till they properly finish this game. There are so many bugs and fps spikes its ridiculous and game breaking. (not sarcasm). At times every creature including your imps will freeze and do nothing, i tried all i can to get them to move. I picked them up, i slapped them, i controlled them, and they still wouldn't move. Also, once you build a large dungeon and have an army the lag is ridiculous. Even if you can handle skyrim on max settings you will have issues with the frames reaching a max 10 frames if you're lucky. However once you start a game you should have a solid 30 frames or more. Final Verdict: Save your money, get it upon release. To many bugs and problems at the moment.

												Being a Fan of the old Dungeon Keeper games from way back when might make me a bit bias when it comes to this game. It is exactly like those classic games that i dearly loved playing when i was growing up. Theres nothing more satisfying that slapping imps until they explode for no other reason than to simply do it. Because, your the bad guy, what do you care what other people think? but the raw perspective of this game is what i enjoy. build your dungeon, fight the hero's be the bad guy for once, and just enjoy the raw destruction you wrought. It's a great way to destress. (slapping imps really helps with that too. just sayin.) If, you've ever enjoyed games like Tropico, Sim City, Ceaser, and at the same time, enjoy a good old fashion RTS combat system. This is your game to play.The only thing this game is really missing is the hillariousness of the Original Dungeon Keeper games. Also where's my Casino Tile? I wanna make my minions gamble all the money i pay them away and refill my coffers the old fashion way.

content:
Posted: December 15, 2015
												I like the faithfulness of this game to the original. They kept the flavor of the original game, making it easy to make the transition. So far as I could tell, there's all the same elements of the original game, dungeon building, room optimizing, cheating your minions out of their pay, slapping and torturing them, etc. There's also some very good new features, like control groups and invisible-fence-for-imps, that were missing from the original. The graphical update makes it a very nice looking game, although by no means cutting edge or demanding. This does mean, however, that the game is not much of a change from the original. There's no radically new gameplay, just some tweaks, a graphical update and a new story. Also, the minimap is unnecessarity pixelated, and the game uses so much memory! It uses 2.5GB more memory than Tomb Raider 2013, and about 1GB more memory than vanilla Rome II. I can't imagine what all that memory is used for, since Rome II handles more units and has better texture. Given this and some other reviews, I'm inclined to think that optimization is not very good, and systems with slower/less RAM will stutter due to paging issues.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												As a game concieved in opposition to EA's embarassing handling of Dungeon Keeper, aiming to recreate the series before it's (mobile gaming) demise, War for the Overworld is pretty much exactly what you'd expect it to be.Conceptually, asthetically and mechanically, War for the Overworld is a like for like facsimile of Dungeon Keeper. Many of the rooms and creatures are nigh identical to their original counterparts in terms of function, being distinguisable only by name and appearence. (For example, Imps are now Workers, The Dark Mistress is now the Succcubus, the Workshop is now the Foundry).This also brings me neatly onto War for the Overworld's first problem. The art direction lacks the imagination and character of it's forebearer. Everything looks and works like Dungeon Keeper, but less interesting. The UI is also enormous and clumsy to use. Like every other part of the game, it attempts to mimic Dungeon Keeper; but Dungeon Keeper's UI was never very good in the first place.The biggest problem War for the Overworld faces, however, is it's often cripplingly poor performance issues. This should not be a technically demanding game, and on launch, runs perfectly. Sadly, usually at around 30 minutes into a session, things start stuttering and spluttering to a horrendous degree, rendering things unplayable and requiring a restart to rectify.I also encountered a couple of instances where campaign progress was blocked due to building related bugs, although these were also fixed by restarting the game.Now that I've gotten the bad things out of the way, onto the good. War for the Overworld does not EXACTLY mimic it's source of inspiration. The major innovation it adds is that of Beasts. Unlike your minions, beasts cannot work in your rooms and will not flee from combat, allowing them to serve as early game fodder to keep your dungeon secure as you build up better forces.Sound is also a high point. Ambient dungeon sounds and minion noises are all excellent and the hiring of Richard Ridings to reprise his role of narrator adds to the "Dungeon Keeper-y" feel of everything.All in all, War for the Overworld isn't as good as Dungeon Keeper or even it's slightly inferior sequel. I would argue that it's still worth picking up, though. Both for the ease of getting a Dungeon Keeper fix without having to mess around with DosBox or Compatibility modes and also just to support the passionate efforts of the Dungeon Keeper fans who made it.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Now, there's a decent amount of people who have played Dungeon Keeper and Dungeon Keeper 2 who also grabbed this game. I am one of those people. I LOVE the DK franchise.  Anyways, going to try not mentioning DK/DK2 from here on out. Well, until the end, anywayWar for the Overworld is a dungeon building and managing god game.  You create your dungeon, create rooms, get minions, and level them up to get an advantage over your enemies. You create room, traps, use spells and Constructs. Depending on what you like and what your playstyle is, you can use or keep from using certain rooms or minions in sync with your playstyle. Hell, you could go all turtle style on your enemy if you wanted to. This game also gives you a decent amount of defensive structures you can use, but from your limited resources, you won't be able to spam them all over the map. Which wouldn't be fun in the first place. Imagine a game where the enemy has turrets ALL over the map. Personally I'd just give the person a win and leave the current game. :PEvery game/movie/series has cliché's. This one is no different in that aspect. Lies, deceit, hero(es)/villain(s) gone batshit insane, plot twists, manipulation, 180 degree turn in personality, and so on and so forth. The usual. Though you can still get genuinely surprised by plot twists. Hell, I can see them coming miles away, and still get surprised. Must be the way the plot twists are handled. This game breathe new life into the dungeon creating and managing-genre, which were severely lacking since the before-mentioned franchise. Which is kinda sad, as this type of genre is very fun. Now, this game was officially released on the 4th of April, 2015. Personally though, I feel as if this game is kinda still in the "just came outta beta" phase, where they add content, fix bugs/glitches, etc. I love free stuff. Hell, even if it's paid DLC(as long as it's cheap enough) I will most likely buy it, though free DLC/content is always welcome, especially for this unpolished gem of a game. In maybe a year and potent and efficient polishing, this game could and will be a lot more than what it is now, and even more worth the money I spent on this unpolished-so-far gem.Now, onto pros and cons:Pros:+ Fun to play+ Real Dungeon Keeper(2) atmosphere, and graphics to match+ Hilarious voice acting (Love ya, Richard!)+ Very good camera options+ AI is fully capable of tearing you a new one+ Large creature/minion variation+ Can train minions/creatures to max level+ Infinite in terms of different plays you can do+ Pretty fun campaign, though not exactly jaw-dropping+ Did I mention voice acting?+ Cool soundtracks+ Devs are talkative AND are both responsive and positive with feedback you give them+ Updates are scheduled and released and regular intervals, unlike for some other games I know+ Very interesting map designs+ All kinds of different map tiles, and how you interact with them+ The devs and a lot of us are passionate about this genre, and are huge fans of the Dungeon Keeper franchise (Omg, I mentioned it, please don't hit me)+ The mouse is a hand, which truly every evil Underlord(Keeper) needs!Cons:- Lacking in terms of campaign duration- Not possible to change difficulty for campaign- Can be a bit difficult at times to select a minion/creature, or even simply hover over it to see status- Lacking multiplayer/skirmish maps- Only 4-players max currently, hoping/wanting to see more- Missing tooltip for when selecting AI's during skirmish, what their preferred strategies are, etc.- Seems laggy at times- A tad lacking in content, but this will come in time- Better minion/Creature overview is lacking- Kinda hard to select tabs at times because of small UI buttons (Rooms, Spells, etc.)- Some of the mechanics in the game are poorly described/explained- The mouse is at times hard to use, as the ingame hand you play with is a bit weird in terms of unit, room and environment interactionConclusion:This game is good, fun, and catches the DK/DK2 type of gameplay. It's not perfect. Nothing is. But if you are thinking spiritually, this game could one day become the spiritual successor of Dungeon Keeper 2.Anyways, this is my short review of War for the OverworldCheers,Yakamaru

content:
Posted: November 18, 2015
												As a huge dungeon keeper fan I was very excited to see a game produced which is clearly a huge tribute to an amazing classic. However at the time of first looking at this game it had mostly negative reviews, so I stayed away. Checking back recently I noticed that suddenly the reviews were hugely positive, with people praising the developers most recent updates (1.1 and 1.2) and saying the game was now polished and worth playing. Due to the Halloween sale I picked it up to give it a try. I am not disappointed!This game takes all the things that made dungeon keeper great and maintains the legacy. It felt so familiar to me that it was like playing dungeon keeper all over again. The campaign has some challenging levels to keep you on your toes and a great entertaining narrated voice over (From the same voice actor that did DK2!!) A small gripe I have is how insane the AI is, on skirmish they somehow always end up with 3-4x as many minions as you within minutes. I am not sure if this is because I suck or because the AI is just mentally good but it does make my desire to get all the achievements a huge challenge! Overall this game is very polished and any dungeon keeper fan should try it and love it! One thing I have noticed which makes me incredibly supportive (Supportive enough to write a review, which I have never done before) Is that the developers listen! every review I check the developers have commented saying that they will work on that, they seem to genuinely care for the player base, which these days is a rare thing! So Kudos devs for listening to players and actually acting on it! You have a happy customer from me and another positive review. Keep it up!

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Old Review: For anyone who has a love for the Dungeon Keeper games of old (not including EA's recent disgustingly obvious cashgrab with the Dungeon Keeper game for iOS) then this is the game for you.  They even have Richard Ridings doing the narration as he did for DK1 & 2!! It's like Dungeon Keeper all over again but without the soul sucking presence of a corporate publisher involved to make it suck with their stupid marketing surveys. Awesome!So I finally got around to playing the official 1.0 release of this game that launched back in April? I think, and I have to say that it feels pretty good to know that my original review during its time in SEA still holds up to the last twenty-ish or so hours of gameplay I've experienced in the past couple days.  Even though I've yet to encounter something that even comes close to the awesomeness of the Horned Reaper character from the original DK series, WFO is definitely the DK successor I've been wanting since my obsession with replaying DK2 ended so many years ago. One negative point brought up in the more critical reviews that I've read so far stated something like there were too many spells, rituals, constructs, etc and that they themselves only needed one or two spells to complete the game so every other option they didn't use at the time was considered to be unnecessary content.  I agree that there are a lot more options than there ever was with the previous DK series but all the same, I find that having a lot of variety helps the replay value of the game.  As much as I hate to say it, I do think that the narrator is a bit too chatty some times and as much as I love Richard Ridings from the DK series, it did get to be a bit much at times.   Yet all the same, I can't blame the developers for wanting to get as much mileage out of the legacy asset of RR's voice as they possibly could because so much of the DK vibe comes from his voice alone.So anyway, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the Dungeon Keeper series or to anyone who thinks the game looks interesting because it is really well done and I find myself easily losing hours while playing, which is exactly what I would expect from the spiritual successor of Dungeon Keeper.

												This game has a lot of potential, but in no way it is ready to be released. As much as I love DK series and this being a spiritual successor of it, I absolutely cannot recommend this game to anyone until it is at least playable. I remember playing an earlier release, and I thought that with the newest patches, at least some of the game breaking issues were fixed. On the contrary, new issues have been introduced. This time I cannot scroll left or right, so I have to use the silly WASD to move around the map. Some cutscenes freeze, such as the one about shifting bond in the fifth level and disable scrolling altogether. Have you guys actually tested scrolling? Was this part of your QA items at all??? Shame on you for using paying users as testers where it should have been your job in the first place. At least now textures do not flicker when you reload the game and the gameplay does not come to a grinding halt. Please test your product before releasing it.
