content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												This game brings back all the nostalgia from the good old Dungeon Keeper 2. It's close to release and the developers seems to be very determined to give their customers what they want. I've done my research and i'm safely putting my faith in Subterranean Games. BUT, it hasn't been released yet so i need to give you the present news of the game. There is little content and no finished campaign.You still have skirmish and a new mode (Survival) that you can enjoy but it isn't enough for 28€ in my opinion.The gameplay is coming out as fairly finished. I've encountered one or two crashes and maybe a few glitches but it's nothing that ruins your game completely, just minor obstacles that are easily fixed.I do hope that i will see more minions, buildings, spells and traps. Even though i feel that the current situation with your variety of building is enough i do want more. It may or may not be the way i want it to be but i'm going to recommend it. I think you should wait until the release of this game and see where it stands though. But as i said, i have faith in these developers (something that doesn't come easily these days).EDIT;The game has finally been released and the full campaign is open. However, the game still contains alot of bugs and a few unfinished touches. I'm sad to say that it wasn't ready for release just yet. They are releasing ALOT of hotfix patches though and that makes me a little happy. Since the release they've already released about 7 hotfix patches and that's great but it also gives you a perspective of how many bugs there are to be fixed. These 7 patches fixed alot of bugs but there are still alot more to be done! I would still recommend that you all wait a month or two to see where the game lies and how smooth the gameplay is.

content:
Posted: April 4
												This is a great game!I tried WftO right around release and was disappointed with how it turned out. I was hoping for a true successor to Dungeon Keeper and this was not it at the time. This style of game seems plagued with hit-or-miss difficulty that's either far too easy (Dungeons) or far too hard (WftO at release). There was a case to be made that WftO went too far into hardcore RTS territory and lost touch with what made the DK games so appealing. That's besides the lack of polish, bugs, and scores of QoL issues. The devs are responsive, however, and have worked incredibly hard to turn their initially flawed game into a real gem and it shows across the board.If you are worried that this game doesn't support the slower, meandering gameplay of the old DK series, don't be. The satisfying gameplay loop of slowly building up your dungeon until the layout is "just so" then using a variety of cool toys/minions/strategies to attack the enemy or draw them into traps is present in spades. There are faster-paced more demanding modes for those that enjoy that too.Which is another point, there's a LOT of content here for a low price. There are several modes favoring different gameplay (aggressive or slow), mutators to customize game behavior, numerous campaigns (normal, my pet dungeon, heart of gold, crucible) and even if you exhaust all of those, there's still a skirmish mode and a near-endless variety of Steam Workshop maps (thousands!). And that is excluding the upcoming AI revamp and one more large content DLC due this year or early-next.I bought it strictly for single-player (no intent to MP) and I cannot recommend this product highly enough. It's the new Dungeon Keeper!A few feedback points for the devs:- I was unable to start standard campaign without opening ports, the map was unresponsive to a click that would normally take me to mission lobby. This appears to be a known issue and was resolved online, but it may leave an unpleasant first impression.- Increased enemy variety would be great, Empire seems like it would wear thin after a while. It's not a dealbreaker but would be nice. Maybe even some neutral creeps, mini bosses, or areas where you can hire/build neutral units (if you control the spot, like an altar) would be cool.

number of helpful: 10 of 17 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
Introduction/Foreword:I am one of the many (or not so many? Dunno...) that owns this game since the Bedrock Beta so I can tell you pretty well some negative and positive things about this game, but mostly negative....First and foremost I must admit that the guys at Subterrenean Games are working hard and passionate, however there are - as mentioned before - some very negative things that destroy the enjoyability of this game for me and will probably also for you...About the Bedrock Beta:The Beta was actually an entire mess, there was almost nothing that actually really worked it even crashed regularly and gameplay lagged as hell...So that what was actually called a "beta" was actually a public alpha version, but this wouldnt be a major problem if Subterrenean wouldnt have rushed the game out.At release:The game has been hastly released with alot of bugs from the "beta", apart of the lack of optimization for systems other than the developers.  The next disappointment was that who purchased the underlord edition didnt got everything as advertised. The soundtrack for example was missing and there was also no advertised guide. The soundtrack was added later (you buy something but you dont get the product you paid for...), dunno about the guide and I also dont care anymore...After release:It took approximately 2 major updates (1.1 and 1.2) and several minor patches before, so that the game could be called "somehow" - and only somehow - a working game.The latest major update (version 1.3) with a retrospective view:Well, at release of the game (version 1.0) I've first started playing the single player campaign of WFTO, however I gave up on playing the SP campaign because the campaign wasnt very balanced apart of the bugged necromancer mission (I think that was level 8...).With 1.3 I was thinking about to give the SP campaign a new try, but before I wanted to play-test some skirmish matches against the AI because the long-awaited map-editor was also released with 1.3. That was a good chance to try both things...After creating my own map and playing it I've noticed a bugged minion and worker AI and a major slowdown of the FPS. I was really hoping with patch 1.3 that such performance and AI flaws would have disappeared but they didnt. Since the Bedrock Beta there were performance and AI problems. Of course they appeared less with every major update but the latest problems in 1.3 are enough for me, my patience is literally exhausted - especially if you go through this since the Bedrock Beta, sorry Subterranean but I'm fed up from this...To the ones who are thinking to buy this game (read the above and now read the below pros/cons):Pros:+ Richard Ridings as narrator+ Gameplay is almost the same as in DK1/2, although a bit faster than in the predecessors+ Sounds effects and sound atmosphere are very well done+ The AI is very efficient (but also see Cons)+ Different salutations by the narrator (Richard Ridings) at game startup, depending on the real computer clock+ Beasts are well chosen and animated+ (Patch 1.3): Map editor with mirroring functionCons:- Minion leveling isnt well balanced, there is also no visual difference between a lvl 1 minion and a lvl 10 minion except the number stating the minion level... a level 10 minion could really need some anabolica that should lead into a visual difference...- The skirmish AI is very efficient but NOT very smart, the skirmish AI is good in going on your nerves but if you counter the skirmish AI it doesnt really know how to handle this situation.- The skirmish AI doesnt use nor place any defenses (doors/traps)- The skirmish AI doesnt use/activates artifacts- I disagree on certain regular minions in regards of their look (chunder f.e. rather looks like a ugly thin toy and not big fat bad♥♥♥♥♥like a bile demon) but this "look" topic is a matter of taste...- There is almost always somewhere an AI bug destroying the enjoyability of this game and which also often leads into performance issues, although the campaign might be unaffected by this because the campaign is rather more scripted than based upon the skirmish AI...Conclusion:Let's sum it upBedrock Beta = Paid Alpha which was also known as Steam Early AccessWFTO 1.0 - 1.x = Paid - almost have it working stable but still being a - BetaWFTO 1.x - ? = Final stable release... (ETA?)All what I wrote sounds very negative but if you are a passionate DK 1 and/or DK 2 player and you still dont own WFTO you should get it in a sale. People that are interested in this game but never played a dungeon game like Dungeon Keeper before should wait maybe for the next 2-3 major updates. I will however start up the game again when the next major patch (1.4 maybe?) will arrive but until then I dont have the desire to start playing it again...

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												I tried this game back when it was Early Access and it showed some promise. Decided to revisit it after release for another look. Well, I have.This game is so poorly-optimized as to be unplayable. The UI lags about 2-3 seconds behind your interactions with it. The tutorial level told me to cast the "Call To Arms" spell, which the UI didn't even present to me. (Then a few seconds later, said, "congratulations!" as if I had managed to cast it.) Things like casting a recall spell on a specific minion are virtually impossible, as they move faster than the UI allows you to cast.Despite setting the game to open fullscreen, every time I run it it draws a huge 1080p-sized window *inbetween* my two monitors. Why would it do that? Why would ever want to play a game that way?Keyboard keys won't work for scrolling the map. The only way to scroll the map is by sticking the mouse to one edge of it. This might be a setting in the UI, but I didn't want to spend the 26 minutes it would have taken to navigate to the options screen.In addition to all of that, this isn't Dungeon Keeper 3. It's just an exact clone of Dungeon Keeper II, only very slightly more high-resolution. You might as well just buy Dungeon Keeper II on Gog.com and play it instead.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Like any Dungeon Keeper fanboy I was excited when news of this game reached my ears. Here was a promise to pay homage to a favorite game of mine from when I was way younger, a game that has had few of its like since it came out.This is what I expected: A dungeon building simulator where you build your lair, gather minions, train them, build defenses and then storm the opposition. To say that this is not what I received would be a lie but the thing is the game delivers things so clunkily that all enjoyment is simply sucked out of it. Yes, you do build your own fully functioning dungeon... assuming you can figure out the actual mechanics of the game, that being the logistics behind the rooms and how the minions interract with them. You can have lots of fun reading through half finished tool tips and placeholders and see if you can make sense of it.You do employ a workforce of diabolical minions... but again the game is not exactly forthcoming on details on how they function inside your dungeon and in combat which leads to cluster♥♥♥♥ combat scenarios in which you just pile your guys together and hope they come out on top.You do conquer realms and bring ruination to your enemies... but through a story that appears to be missing half of its cutscenes and animations and this is assuming that the game doesn't crash or go through constant memory leaks.I guess you could say that this game delivers everything that was expected, but it is done so badly that all the fun gets lost behind somewhere. There's a lot of good ideas here but the game doesn't take its time to explain how they work and some ideas never get used at all.

number of helpful: 27 of 51 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24
												Like several other reviewers I´m put off because this can hardly be called a strategy game anymore.Yes, the developers were extremely unlucky with their campaign, Heart of Gold and lots of Steam-workshop-levels are much better.But the major problem for me is that fighting Empire is just boring because it´s always the same. Gets worse if you encounter lots of traps: They don´t do much damage, but it takes you ages to get through if fortified with Ramparts. Personally, I just send my Archon there to destroy them, do something else and take a look after an hour or so how my attack goes. How about more trap damage and less resistance?Dungeon Keeper 1 was fun for me when I played against a good AI-keeper because different to Empire other keepers could surprise you. You had to be quick to get rooms, neutral creatures, gold etc. without letting your defences down. Of course, the Dungeon Keeper AI was just♥♥♥♥♥♥ But you could write a skript with events for each map to determine their behaviour, ressources and to let them respond to your strategy. WFTO doesn´t give you any of those possibilities. The AI will always try to dig to you and attack you, even if it is seriously weaker than you. No chance to set it to "builder", "defensive" etc. So it´s always the same: Rush to train your creatures, build rooms to get good fighters, wait to retaliate the first attack and then destroy your opponent. Very boring. Might be better if you played against 2,3 or 4 AIs, but I´m already glad the game runs more or less on my brandnew (!) system if I play against 1 on a medium map (basic system requirements far more than matched). The developers obviously didn´t want us to be able to turn off at least  some of the most ressource consuming features like light effects, smoke, distortions... So be really careful: Unless your computer was made for gaming and is rather new, you won´t be able to play at least two third of the maps here on Steam.But even on these small or medium maps the game play isn´t much fun. Personally I think it´s a good idea to have Siege Shrines that allow you to dig through enemy walls if you´re playing with Replacement Earth. Otherwise it would be really frustrating. But I simply don´t understand why you and the AI are able to dig through walls even without, provided a little time. And it finally gets totally ridiculous if an Underminer, a low (!) level construct, can wipe away enemy walls in quite a range. So just don´t bother with fortifying your dungeon, it isn´t worth anything. It´s arm-as-fast-as-possible and clash, no other way of playing possible.Building a dungeon is fun because of the nice graphics and challenges provided by the terrain. For me it´s the part I like best in WFTO. But I haven´t discovered DK-Features like "Lair Enemy" which forced you to build your dungeon differently according to the creatures you get in order to avoid deadly arguments. Would have been really nice to have Food Enemies, Tavern Enemies and so on instead of always building the same standard-dungeon. What ever happened to Sorcerers killing Imps so you had to place your Library really carefully?Different to DK you have more possibilities of micro management here, but I can´t really handle them: If I place a Cultist in the Sanctuary to pray for gold so I can build faster, it will often simply return to the Library and I only lost research time. Maybe I´m doing something wrong, but I finally gave up trying.Creature management is the next big issue that puts me off. Lots of different creature menues to choose, but no possibility to have the classic-DK-menue where you had an overview what your creatures were doing, who was idle and who fighting. Sometimes I´m unable to pick creatures from the menue if they are fighting. Earth tiles under the buttons get accidently clicked all the time. Impossible to keep creatures in your Hand of Evil while you perform other tasks. Absolutely no idea what to do with angry creatures: In DK I could put them into the Temple to cool down. Tried to give them gold, but my Hand of Evil is always in line of sight so I mostly miss. Couldn´t see that much difference if managed though. Now I just transform them into gold (most times accidently transforming innocent creatures around as well due to very laggy gameplay). So there´s no real motivation to level-up my creatures, it´s easier to replace them if needed. Therefor I finally gave up playing with Vampires, too: Bad enough that they kill your valuable prisoners if you´re not quick enough (or gameplay laggs too much), but I can´t find a way to keep them occupied without Guard Posts, so they always start feeding on my other creatures - and they complain all the time! No total number of creatures (own and opponent´s) to tell you if it would be wise to attack. Or to give you an idea how big your army is, because in big maps they do not all respond to rally flags. Even on small maps I can´t flip through my different creature types (due to laggy gameplay?): Menue always simply jumps from the first to the last creature. This way I can´t really play with Beasts because I can´t pick them up for the Arena.And, of course, no battle menue. The only thing to give you an overview while fighting in DK with the possibility to cast spells directly on specific targets. So now just hope you´ve got more creatures, send them to battle and pray to the Gods of the Underworld. Strategy? No, action seems more important. Lots of screams and lights and keepers trying to desperately hit enemies with lightning-bolts without any success because the game jumps more and more frames. How about hot keys for spells also? At least that would stop the screen from scrolling all the time you try to cast a spell and the game already lags like hell.In several posts the developers tell us that the game is so ressource-devouring because of all the waypoints your computer has to calculate for creatures. So it definitely was a good idea to have heroes not always heading for your Dungeon Heart but simply staying where they are. But on the other hand the developers take any chance from us to reduce possible paths - f.e. by making walls indestructible without a Siege Shrine or by my most favourite trick in DK: Build a Temple- or Guard Post-tile directly next to water or lava and the height distance will be too big for non-flying enemies. That way you can (provided with Lava or Water Traps) even create one-way-roads.  So how about a Step Construct?And if you want to have really thrilling competitions with other keepers instead of one big battle you should give us the opportunity to fight several small battles at once to weaken the opponent. WFTO goes a step into that direction by introducing shrines and Titans. But the game needs much more of that! Make a Titan Shrine as the only place where players can summon a Titan. Make shrines that greatly expand your mana or increase your mana regeneration. Make rooms that cannot be built but must be discovered. And then give us back the old Invisibility Spell for our Imps, so we can annect and instantly sell all these valuable rooms if not guarded by creatures who can detect invisible enemies! That would be a way to really bring DK into this decade. And, last point: What was the idea to make dungeons  almost completely independet from gold? Nice to have rituals and spells for gold in the beginning because they really speed up building your dungeon. But training creatures should always cost gold! Only then is there a chance to starve out your opponent. Only then you are forced to keep digging into new regions instead of just staying at home to build only Beast Dens and throw your beasts constantly into Arenas.  Obviously the developers expected very different things from a DK-remake than me, but I couldn´t find out what exactly, apart from impressive graphics and sounds. Looks to me like they had so many ideas that they lost their golden thread.

Early Access Review
								Remember the good old times when you could just slaughter pesky heroes who dared enter your domain, or just lure them into insidious traps and laugh at their sorrow? Well i most certainly do with the Dungeon Keeper franchise, Guess who made a spiritual succesor! Subterranean Games did. The time is nigh for some good old fashioned carnage! This message is mostly meant as a heads up to all the people who also enjoyed dungeon management and god game genres. This game (wich is currently in Beta phase) is showing high potential by combining key elements from games like Starcraft, Overlord, Evil Genius and of course Dungeon Keeper. Even if you have never heard of this sort of game and inflicting pain on good-doers then you have to look into this game!

												It's not called DK3, but it plays very much like what I'd like a DK3 to be-- rather than some pay-to-win mobile thing-- and there's that voice again, congratulating you on your evil deeds and chiding you for not killing the forces of good rapidly enough.  Welcome back, Keeper...I mean Underlord.Anyway, I've played thru level 6 under 1.1.6 without any significant issues.  The only thing I noticed offhand was that there is a pretty major pause at the start of some levels before the voice intro starts up.  Speaking of pauses, I want the 'Pause' key or 'P' or something to do a pause-- the esc menu sort of works, but you can't scroll with the esc menu active.Graphics quality with all the shiny enabled is looking pretty fine, and the performance seems solid-- no problems holding a steady 60FPS at 2560x1440 @ 60Hz resolution.  Wish I could zoom out a little more, though, or perhaps I'd like the UI elements around the edge of the screen to be a little smaller and not take up as much room.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												I bought this game with high expectations and hopes. Not only it didn't betray them but it even surpassed them! I would give it 10/10Before talking about the game first let me tell you that I'm one of the most hardcore strategy players (skip this paragraph if you don't want to read it). I've played AOE, AOE II, AOE III, AOM, Rise of Nations, Rise of Nations: Thrones and Patriots, all General games, WC III, WC Frozen Throne, The Lord of the Rings: The Battle for Middle-earth, Total Annihilation: Kingdoms, and pretty much evey strategy game online and on the phone. I've also played a lot of Tower Defense and similar games. I'm not trying to show off here but rather say I've seen what the Genre has to offer. So when I say "high expectations" I mean really high.This game offers a definitely unique experience. You can command your armies like a true Overlord, you can lead them into battle like a true leader or you can play tower defense with your enemies! LOL. But maybe you are into sneaking games and stealth operations: No problem. Just hand pick your few elite companions and take the enemy forces down one by one. But be careful not to think of your troops as mere npcs because they might make mistakes and they need sleep, food and good pay!This game's big difference with the other games I've played in that it lets you play however you like with an army as big as you want and for as long as you want but more importantly, you can play as the BAD GUY! There is almost no other game that lets you be the bad guy! But not in this game. You are literally a Demon Lord who is attacking the dwarf and human nations and wiping them clean out of existance. I mean I personally kept some of their talented sorceresses by making them an offer they couldn't refuse in my torture chambers, but you can kill them too if you felt like it. But after you've conquered the human kingdom and finished the Heart Of Gold DLC, you won't get bored cause there are countless player made maps you can try and the game updates regularely.Edit: I almost forgot. All your creatures can Level up! They gain more hp, mana and abilities as they lvl up. This is also something you don't see in a lot of games. WC III and Battle For Middle-earth had it too but only for hero units.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
												I found this game to be a lot of fun, and the Narrator, voiced by Richard Ridings of Dugeon Keeper fame, strikes the exact right tone for sarcasm and personality.There are actually quite a wide selection of beasts and minions for you to direct, all with their own unique role.The unlockable themes are worth pursuing, even though they are merely cosmetic changes. My favourite so far is the Arcane theme form the My Pet Dungeon expansion, but I think that Rhaskos' theme is worth getting.The DLC is worth getting. Heart of gold is an exploration based campaign and My Pet Dungeon adds 8 distinct sandbox levels.The problem with this game is that the main campaign tends to fall back to endless waves of enemies assaulting your dungeon and can be difficult for those with a more patient playstyle. The game does try to present these levels as something different each time. In one endless wave level, you have to reinforce an already breached dungeon before the waves begin, and another has you defending a second overlord from about 300 enemy minions. Ultimatley though, both levels have you attempting to outlast the timer.Overall, I do reccomend this game, but not for the base campaign. I am going to point out that I'm about half way through the main campaign and have about 70 hours of game time for War for the Overworld at this point. That's almost entirley down to the DLC and sandbox modes. The humour is very much apparent and the devs are still maintaining the game and listen to feedback about it. The campaign may feel rushed, but the DLC campaigns have the opposite feel and are the most fun I've had in an RTS for years.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												While I generally think this game is a thumbs up, I can't say I am entirely happy with the level of polish... or lack there of.It truly feels like a sequel or spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2, but seems to lack a little of the heart that went into that title. It has a similar sense of humor, but maybe a bit more drab than the old DK franchise. I can see that the devs loved DK and wanted to make this as close to that concept as possible, but in too many places it falls just shy of the potential.The old Dungeon Keeper games had some bad bugs in them that made them almost inplayable at times and unfortunately this game does follow that same trend as well. That being said, the devs have not given up on this game and appear to be trying to fix, improve, and expand on the game months after it's full release, so here is to hoping this game gets enough love from both players and devs over time.All said, it does feel like Dungeon Keeper 2.5... I just wish it had felt more like Dungeon Keeper 3. But still a fun game and if you want to try something new or something old that feels new again, give this game a try. Worth a play.

												I read many many reviews about how this game was just riddled with problems, which was disheartening for me, as I really wanted to see a great succssor to DK2.  When I saw the game on sale for a reasonable price, I decided to give it a go and I must say i was not dissapointed.  After playing the tutorial map it felt i was back playing DK2 with new minions and some great new features that were lacking from DK2.  One of my favourites is the ability to STOP those dam imps from wondering into enemy fire and it not costing you mana.  I haven't played very far into the campaign, but so far I am really enjoying the experience.  The developers have managed to capture what was so fun about DK2 and add some really useful features to the mix.  I can highly recommend this game as of today!

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												The great thing about this is that it is very similar to Dungeon Keeper in its basic design, but with some graphical updates and new stuff to play with. There are some minor refinements, like that the campaign never requires you to use the first-person "possession" mode. It's fun, and could absolutely pass for a sequel to Dungeon Keeper, so it's reasonably worthwhile if you liked Dungeon Keeper. And it supports Linux, which is the reason I bought it.However, it also has a small number of significantly annoying issues.There isn't that much content! As you can see, it took me 33 hours to complete the game and DLC, and I play slowly and restarted several levels. Maybe the multiplayer is good, but I have not tried it.Compared to Dungeon Keeper, the level design is a little bit rough with respect to discovering what you should do. In several levels I had to restart multiple times because there was some point on the map I was supposed to rush (because the scenario becomes unplayably hard past a certain number of minutes, so there is no time to  e.g. train minions) or NOT rush (because doing a certain thing causes every enemy in the level to pour down at once, or because it gets your minions wasted when the particular level provides no way to replace them), but no way to discover this without screwing up. This reduces the fun somewhat. The levels play significantly smoother in "Heart of Gold."A Dungeon Keeper game doesn't need an amazing plot, but this still suffered from writing issues. The "plot" was so overbearing and lame that I'd rather have just played the scenarios without any plot, and I did not find the humor up to the Dungeon Keeper standard. To be clear, I enjoy dark humor. It made the game embarrassing to play in the room with other people and if I knew a sequel had the same writing, I probably wouldn't buy it.There are also way, way too many confusing and irrelevant messages in-game, kickstarter in-jokes I guess; they feel almost constant and they are distracting and sometimes misleading. I really would have liked to be able to skip all that. The cutscenes aren't really skippable and it would have been nice to be able to check the text from these like a "mission briefing" instead of being forced to sit through the really slow pan-arounds (which were more annoying for the performance issues). This would have been less of an issue except that the content of the cutscenes was so lame.And there are some performance issues, nothing unplayable, but the game can get pretty choppy even on a fairly recent video card. I found myself avoiding the "reveal map" ability because it made the game unplayably slow.

content:
Posted: April 4
												I found this game to be a lot of fun, and the Narrator, voiced by Richard Ridings of Dugeon Keeper fame, strikes the exact right tone for sarcasm and personality.There are actually quite a wide selection of beasts and minions for you to direct, all with their own unique role.The unlockable themes are worth pursuing, even though they are merely cosmetic changes. My favourite so far is the Arcane theme form the My Pet Dungeon expansion, but I think that Rhaskos' theme is worth getting.The DLC is worth getting. Heart of gold is an exploration based campaign and My Pet Dungeon adds 8 distinct sandbox levels.The problem with this game is that the main campaign tends to fall back to endless waves of enemies assaulting your dungeon and can be difficult for those with a more patient playstyle. The game does try to present these levels as something different each time. In one endless wave level, you have to reinforce an already breached dungeon before the waves begin, and another has you defending a second overlord from about 300 enemy minions. Ultimatley though, both levels have you attempting to outlast the timer.Overall, I do reccomend this game, but not for the base campaign. I am going to point out that I'm about half way through the main campaign and have about 70 hours of game time for War for the Overworld at this point. That's almost entirley down to the DLC and sandbox modes. The humour is very much apparent and the devs are still maintaining the game and listen to feedback about it. The campaign may feel rushed, but the DLC campaigns have the opposite feel and are the most fun I've had in an RTS for years.

Posted: May 20, 2013
												This kickstarter game project is set out to make a game that will hopefully be a successor to 'Dungeon Keeper' by Bullfrog Entertainment.  It has even been given the thumbs up by 'Peter Molyneux'.The aim of the game is to build up your dungeon / minions and conquer the other dungeons while playing in a top down view.. or FPS if you have a possession spell to take over one of your minions.If you want an idea of the game concept then I'd recommend checking out "Dungeon Keeper" (not Dungeon keeper2) and then imagine it revamped to today's graphics.Edit: The game is still being updated with multiplayer now working (occasionally buggy)  and a map editor expected in the future, however right now there is the campaign mode and 'extra' unlockable themes which you can change the look and feel of your dungeon.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												A solid 7.5, maybe a 8I really liked the game, it captures most of the spirit of the original Dungeon Keeper games + some improvements and that alone is a feat that any indie game should be really proud. I was pleasantly surprised, because Im a total fan of the series.If I dont give it a 8 or 9/10 is because the "sim/soul" part of the game is still lacking compared to all the other things. The creatures are different in appearance and some even in combat, but what about personality's? In the DK games you had the bile demon wanting tons of food, the dragons lots of gold, spiders hating flies, wizards wanting silence in their library's, dogs fertilizing your cementerys etc... Those things not only made you think about how to place rooms or witch creatures try to summon for X or Y lvl, but added a lot to the feeling of your dungeon being "alive" and populated by creatures with desires and/or uses for non room activity's. The other thing is polish and pacing, but that is probably easier to fix with feedback and the experience the devs already gained by making the game. All in all, its a really good game that can be recommended to any DK fan.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												(Scroll down for pros/cons/verdict)I grew up playing dungeon keeper 2. My step dad originally introduced me, and I was immediately hooked. "It's good to be bad" was the game's slogan, and it held true to that. The third title was never released because bullfrog was aquired by every gamer's favorite company, EA. So when I heard EA was making a mobile dungeon keeper game a while back, I was interested, but extremely skeptical. Turned out to be freemium garbage as I expected. No dungeon keeper for like 15 years and you decide to bring it back as a cashgrab shell of its former self? Classic EA. There would never be another great DK game, or so I thought.Then I found out about WFTO. An independent group of people making a new DK game. Again, I had my heart crushed and stomped on before, so I was skeptical. When I first read reviews, it was from before the game's 1.1 patch, and they were rather mixed. Bugs, glitches, memory leaks, etc. I veered away at the time, but still checked up on it occasionally to see how the developers would respond. Over time, I started to notice that the developers were totally ontop of♥♥♥♥♥♥ They were working hard to fix everything, and genuinely seemed to care about making a true successor to DK2. I became more interested and waited for it to go on sale.When I finally purchased it and played, I was hooked. I played till like 6 in the morning. This totally felt like what DK3 could have been if bullfrog were still around. They even got the original announcer! It was easy at first because of being a DK2 veteran, but eventually started to challenge me a bit more. I got my  handed to me a couple times on level 9 (Belmourne's pass) and had to start working out different strategies. I played nonstop and got to the final level in about two days, which I could not complete because of a glitch. This was pretty annoying, and I messaged the moderators on their subreddit (/r/WFTO). They were quick to respond and said it would be fixed. A couple days later, they released a patch that fixed everything I had trouble with, and I was able to complete the game in about 15 hours overall.For those unfamiliar with the series, you play as an unseen and omnipotent underlord. You manage your dungeon from a top down perspective and carve out rooms to attract minions to your lair. You use these minions to wipe out the humans (or other underlords) kind of like an RTS. I have to state though, that this is not a traditional RTS. You do not have to micro tons of units, instead you place a flag and all your minions will rally there. They use their own abilities too, so again don't let your bad micro skills stop you from buying this. You can set up defenses, fortifications, cast spells, rituals, and create constructs. There's a ton of different ways to succeed. Once you've eliminated the campaign objective or the human/cpu player's dungeon core, you win.PROS:- Original Announcer from the old DK games - Funny- More content than DK2 - Countless ways to go about winning- Gameplay is unique from other RTS- Take control of a minion and join the battle in FPS mode- Satisfying to build things- Developers genuinely care about game - Multiplayer (Fight with or against your friends)- Campaign, skrimish, survival, sandbox, plus multiplayer. 5 Modes boys.- More content on the way- ChallengingCONS:- Ending is awkward and unsatisfying at the moment (They will fix)- You may run into a glitch or two (Again, they will fix)- Little pricey- AI still needs a little work (AI won't build traps or defenses guarding their dungeon core, so you can just send all your units directly at it and 90% of the time you'll win. This is mainly a problem in multiplayer/skrimish.)OTHER:- You might have to mess with the graphic settings a bit to get it to run smoothly- To host a multiplayer game may require port forwardingVERDICT:If you played the old DK games and liked them, I highly reccommend this. If you want a taste of the gameplay before you're sure, go get DK2 and play a few missions of that. While the campaign is great, I also reccommend getting a friend to buy it and trying out multiplayer.8/10.

Posted: September 24, 2016
												To reduce War for the Overworld as a simple intellectual property reskin  or modernised rehash of dungeon keeper 2 would completely undermine just how much further this game goes. The core mechanics, style and thematic approach undoubtedly are outright DK (imitation is flattery after all) even going to go so far as to use the same narrator, but a new gamut of bestiary, rooms, traps and mechanics are not only well thought out, but offer an invaluable greater range of depth to strategic gameplay and variety in playstyle. Most importantly though this game is just downright fun to play, whether you are playing casually, or meticulously masterminding your next misdeed the game just exudes a character that positively rubs off on you.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												So, now that WftO has had a few months to cook after its disastrous (and incomplete) launch, what do we have now at version 1.1?Well, if you're looking for a Dungeon Keeper 3 that actually works this time, WftO is now it.  The game takes the premise of its spirtual ancestor, and expands it with new units, tools, and various other goodies.  Not all of this is for the best, however; many units and tools still feel underdeveloped and underbalanced.  Again, however, WftO now stands out as the best and the brightest of the DK-alikes out there (although, with Dungeons 2 as its only real competitor these days --with maybe KeeperRL as a very distant 3rd -- that's not saying much).+ Tried and tested Dungeon Keeper gameplay with its own spin.  That's the biggest plus right there.  After many patches, the dev team pretty much nailed what makes the DK formula special.  This single plus pretty much covers up for the game's myriad sins:- Campaign needs another pass.  One big quibble is the way that new units and tools are dumped willy-nilly on the player, with no warning or explanation, as the campaign progresses.  DK made sure that new stuff was properly introduced -- and necessary! -- at the end of each campaign mission.  WftO doesn't.- Poor use of all this new and different stuff in the campaign.  You get a lot of different toys and units, but you will not end up using some of them at all in the campaign.  (See: stone bridge).  This may be useful when playing multiplayer, but it's just clutter in the campaign.  Even read a book that cries out for better editing, for elimination of dross and a better focus on what is important?  WtfO needed a better editor, as it were.  There's just too much redundant stuff in it.  DK2 stripped away a lot of DK1's units and tools, as was the better game for it.- Much more MP focused than the DK games were.  WftO was evidently created by folks who thought DK's MP was the high point of the game, which is arguable.  As a result, you get less of a contemplative, polish your dungeon to a high sheen gameplay in favor of... zerg rushes and click-click-clicky around the map.- I was wondering if the devs were trolling me when I "won" the game.  Abrupt and unrewarding to say the least.  Not as bad, say, as an old NES game that just displayed "CONGRATULATIONS" on a black screen, but close.- I hate timed missions in a game centered on building stuff.  The campaign has a few.TL;DR: WtfO is close, but not quite, for those who waited patiently over the decades for a DK3.  It's definitely still worth a shot, though.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												So this game has taken a lot of stick since its initial release in 2015 and I took a risk and funded Subterranean Games towards the games development. Why is this review positive you might ask? Well the game was initally buggy, very buggy but heck any new game is bound to be littered with flaws and funding companies to work on the game and iron the creases out is something I have not regretted.Over one year on and this game is a fantastic renaissance of what the old Dungeon Keeper series used to be. Personally, its everything and more to what I would want from a follow up to the DK Series. Its clear that the developers love this game and have lived solely to make it work for us the players. Any review that mentions bugs or glitches, please let me assure you I have come across none in the recent months of playing and I believe they have been resolved. A fantastic follow-up to a fantastic game series with a devoted community and great developers.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												Where do I start with this game? Ahh, yes... YOU ARE AN EVIL GOD! One of the best RTSs that I have ever played. Everyone has a secret evil side, some less secret than others... but that doesn't matter, AS LONG AS I GET TO HEAR THE PAINED CRIES OF MY ENEMIES AS MY MINIONS SLAUGHTER THEM ALL! The narrator is definitely my favorite character, he is hilarious. The best part of this game, besides being evil, is that it is an RTS that feels like it isn't an RTS, you actually have minions that need taking care of, they eat, drink, sleep, work, fight, and get paid (and get tortured). You literally have to control your own society, while fighting the empire. Plus, in my opinion the campaign gets incredibly difficult as you get to Mira's Dungeon. I will not inform you who Mira is, because that could be a spoiler. There is really only one thing that I don't like. Every other Underlord is completely useless, they don't do anything except mutter giberish. I won't get into too much detail as that could also be a spoiler. Overall 9/10.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Answer these questions with yes or no to see if it's a game for you:- Do you like torturing your enemies to recruit them into your own ranks and send them fighting their own brethren?- Do you think it's appropriate to slap your minions around your dungeon to speed up their work?- Do you think that itsy bitsy micro piglets are the right way to stop underworld hunger?- Do you characterize with some kind of higher being, e.g. a god? Loving, caring, just in a twisted kind of way?If you can answer these with a rightful YES, then go buy the game. If you're a Dungeon Keeper fan this is a must have.The developers are a quite small team but have delivered a high quality game, even though it is still a bit rough about the edges a few days after the release i'm sure these things will get patched up quickly. The price may look hefty at first but is ultimately rightful, as the game offers tons of quality content and delivers it in a fun way, especially if you dig the dungeon keeper "it is good to be bad" humour. However, you may want to wait until the price drops and more content is delivered / patched.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												This is very reminiscent of Dungeon Keeper 1 and 2, which are arguably the two greatest "Dungeon Creator's" of all-time.  In fact I would say that this is a pretty blatant copy of it, if the series hadn't been out of print for 16 years.This is one of many series that Electronic Arts killed when they started buying up companies and then metaphorically salting the earth where the more quirky popular series once grew.  Bullfrog had Populous, Magic Carpet, Dungeon Keeper and Syndicate.  Origin had Ultima, Ultima Underworld and Wing Commander.  Heck, they even killed their own Mutant League Sports series when they became a "serious company".TL:DR - WftO is a lot like Dungeon Keeper 1&2, this is a good thing and thank God someone brought back the classic gameplay since EA sucks at pleasing fans of classic titles they own the rights to.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												First of all I'd like to say - IGNORE THE METACRITIC SCORE!!!! It's only the score that it is because people started leaving reviews before the game was finished and before the 1.1 patch was released. This patch has been a complete revelation!I know what many of you are probably thinking as you trawl through the reviews left for War for the Overworld......"I thoroughly enjoyed the Dungeon Keeper games and I'd really hope that War for the Overworld would live up to my expectations, given that it's not exactly cheap". Well, as a long term Dungeon Keeper fan (I'm 28 now and played it daily when i was a teen, including a few play throughs as I've gotten older), I can assure you that you won't be disappointed. I actually felt quite sceptical when purchasing this game, simply because I enjoyed the original Dungeon Keepers games so much. I often hype up something in my own mind to the point where it will probably disappoint, but I've been very pleasantly surprised. This is about as close as you can get to a Dungeon Keeper 3. I think the creators have done a really great job of keeping just enough of the old Dungeon Keeper vibes to satisfy the DK fans (for example the resemblance of many of the units in the game - The 'Workers' are clearly Imps, the 'Chunders' who love to work in the workshop and have the ability to 'fart' as a weapon (much like my girlfriend) are Bile Demons and you also get a female unit that loves to torture your enemies in the torture chamber.....remind you of anything (except without my old favourite spell lightning). Your creatures still need to eat but have moved away from chickens and now prefer micropiglets, and some of your old favourite spells are still available like being able to create more workers, being able to reveal parts of the map for limited time, and also the 'Call to Arms' spell has a 'Rally' option too. I think what's really great about War for the Overworld is the fact that the developers etc have taken great care to only change or remove elements from the DK games that actually work to improve this game. Does anyone remember in Dungeon Keeper how if you had enough gold, you could build an unlimited amount of traps and doors all over your dungeon, while you sat back and used the sight of evil spell in conjunction with the lightening or cave in spells to kill all of the enemy units? yeh you can'y do that anymore, you now actually have to think a bit more and strategy plays more of a part. Your mana pool is actually now split between the number of workers you have, the number of traps you have and any spells that you wish to cast. This means that you have to find a balance between those things because you have loads of workers, you wont be able to lay any traps or cast any spells, alternatively if you have loads of traps, you won't be able to create many extra workers or cast many spells. This was a welcome addition to the game because it's makes things more challenging, but not too difficult. The graphics are nice and crisp, even if the frame rate can take an occasional hit on a very busy map (nothing that'd bothered me too much mind), the sound effects are very good and actually quite funny in terms of the things you hear your creatures randomly say, and there's more than enough content to keep you playing for a while with multiplayer, the campaign and a survival type mode. Overall I've been really, pleasantly surprised by this game and what I also think is great is that the developers are really looking after it when it comes to releases/patches/updates. They regularly make sure that they respond to requests from people in terms of improvements etc and they aren't just light touches either. When i first got the game, I felt a little sad that your workers aren't able to level up. After a few days they'd released another couple of updates which added the ability for workers to level and i noticed they'd fixed EVERY other minor bug that I'd experienced. You get exactly what you'd want and would expect from this game and the aftercare provided by the regular updates etc. It's fun, challenging, addictive and you still get to feel very nostalgic if you loved the original Dungeon Keeper games. If you never played those games and are instead just contemplating buying this game - do it, you won't regret it. Graphics - 8/10 (for what it is, i think they're great)Sound - 9.5/10Gameplay 9/10 (With several game modes and the fact that each time you play you can change your style - you'll come back to this time anbd time again)Overall - 9/10

 DISCLAIMER: This is a first impressions review, and NOT a full review, if you want a full review, then please read better reviews then mine Good evening Underlord, it's paydayI loved the classic Bullfrog Production Dungeon Keeper series, except the disaster of the "game" which is Dungeon Keeper Mobile. The basic premise of Dungeon Keeper was to build a dungeon and try and survive the human scum and I've always wanted a modern remake of the classic game, and thankfully there is, War for the Overworld!The game is mostly the same as the Dungeon Keeper series, you order your minions to build a dungeon and train your soldiers and such to prepare to attack the enemyThe graphics still too is mostly the same as the Dungeon Keeper series, as a matter of fact, there isn't any changes between the Dungeon Keeper series and War for the Overworld which is a shame as I excpected some new game mechanics to be introducedAt first, the game ran like poop, but after a while, the game ran well and I have no complaints with the AI although many people complained about the AI before I purchased the game so it seems as if the developers patch the game regularly and fixed the issues many people complained about before my purchase of the gameAnd of course, the original voice actor from the Dungeon Keeper series makes a return in War for the Overworld!War for the Overworld is a good game but for people who played the living hell (no pun intended) out of the Dungeon Keeper series, there isn't much difference between this game and Dungeon Keeper but for people who like strategy games then this is the game for you!Now Underlord, get back to work! content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												First of all, this game does still have some bugs.  If buggy games bother you a lot, maybe give it another few weeks.  The devs are working hard, and they're making a ton of progress, but they're not quite there yet.That said, this game is to Dungeon Keeper 2 what DK2 was to DK1.  If you feel (as I do) that DK2 was a drastic improvement over DK1, you're in for a hell of a ride with this game.So many improvements to what, at it's core, is the same system.  Take traps/doors, for example.  In DK1, they would build whatever they wanted, then you could place it.  Kind-of annoying, since they would produce all the low-level stuff first, so if you wanted, say, a Steel Door, you'd have to wait.  Then, in DK2, you could place a door/trap, then they would get to work on it.  Definitely an improvement, since it didn't waste resources, but if you didn't currently have a place that you knew you wanted a door/trap, your workshop workers would just be slacking off.  In WFTO, they finally solved it.  Workshop workers build generic parts.  When you place doors/trap blueprints, your imps bring those parts to where they need to be, and after enough parts are brought, the door/trap exists.  It doesn't waste anything, and it's perfect.Everything in the game is like that.  They took a look at the systems in the DK games and said, "How can we make this better?"  They've done a remarkable job.  Researching rooms/spells is done through a sort of "skill tree" so you can spend your research points as you wish.  You can fill back in places you don't want dug out; one of my pet peeves with my DK dungeons is when they could be ruined by intruders, and now you can fix what they did.  There are all sorts of entirely new systems, like alchemy, constructs, and rituals, each of which have a different purpose and interesting uses.All that, and I'd already be willing to pay more than the $30 MSRP.  But you know what else they decided to do?  Write a plot.  DK1 basically had none.  DK2 had a bit of one, but it was always, "Do the thing, this guy's trying to stop you from doing the thing.. yay, you did the thing!"  In this game, I'm only halfway through the campaign, and I'm already wondering what's going on and questioning the motives of certain characters.  Did you ever expect a DK-style game to have you questioning a character's motives?  I sure didn't!  It's a blast.So yes, I'd recommend this game, even in its very-recently-launched state.  Like I said, if bugs bother you a lot, give it a bit more time, but if you're willing to forgive a bit (and if you played DK2, you should be; that game was never 100% stable) then you should just pick it up now.

												I was a massive fan of the original Dungeon keeper, so i was really excited for this when i heard about it, and i am really enjoying it.Over the last couple of weeks the game has been hugley fine tuned and a handful of additional features added or existing ones built upon, so the comments saying the game is not finished, are misleading.The game is being polished and maybe two or three additional things added here and there, which i think people are mistaking for..."ITS NOT EARLY ACCESS AND THEY'RE ADDING♥♥♥♥♥♥STILL...OMG"....Ignore those people, it's fine tuning and one or two additional things being added to bulk up the game, but like any game, actually watch a video or two on it, read the updates to see how regularly things are happening, and make your own decision.10/10 would spark a potential backlash from the "Not Recommended People Again"=)

content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												I have tried a lot of hopefuls to the dungeon keeper throne over the years. Overlord, Dungeons, Impire; they all had their charms but none were quite what I was hoping for and I REFUSE to buy Dungeon Keeper 2 from EA after they butchered the whole thing. I was really timid about going into this game because I had been disappointed so many times before but I have been greatly impressed by this game, it has filled the hole in my heart.It's really easy to jump into if you've played other dungeon games, the skill trees are an interesting addition that makes multiplayer matches more dynamic. With the beast den, potions, constructs and rituals it feels like a genuine spiritual successor to those classics.The one and only complaint I have is the lack of a dragon-like monster. When I was a kid I always loved to craft a dungeon and populate it with like 30 dragons. Huge scaly firebreathing besties make everything better! who knows though, might be added in future DLC or something. XD...maybe a skin for the Auger, that would work! Now I have to look into moddingOkay I'm just rambling now so I'm gonna cut it here. In Conclusion: War for the Overworld is awesome and you should play it!

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												It looks like Dungeon Keeper, it sounds like Dungeon Keeper, but it doesn't obey your dark will like Dungeon Keeper.One of my favorite things of the Dungeon Keeper series was actually building the dungeon, fortifying it, training my host of evil, and THEN attacking with it.My least favorite thing in War for the Overworld is that it forces you to play the game at its pace, and doesn't allow you to dictate the pace of the game based on your own tactics.  You are often facing a ticking down timer, or faced with an AI opponent that has a fully built dungeon and starting minion compliment that happily bum rushes directly toward you within five minutes of the level loading with no reguard for its own level 1 minions.This means that for most of the campaign you're distracted from building your dungeon by having to deal with a constant horde of weak pointless minions constantly trying to make a bee line to your dungeon heart.  On most maps, save for the one the game specifically expects you to create them on defenses generally feel pretty worthless as well, not like you'd even have time to build them on later missions anyway since the game just devolves into planting the All Minion/Beast flags down and spamming heal monster as fast as your mana can support.I also don't like how once the AI has decided it is going to attack you, there is basically nothing else to do except deal with its suicidal tendencies since it somehow always magically has a full host of minions to keep pouring into your territory, no matter how many you seem to kill/capture.  You can't drive them back and take a breather to let your minions sleep, eat, and get back to their tasks like performing rituals, converting prisoners and raising the collected corpses.  Your only choice is to keep an unrelenting drive directly to the dungeon heart even as more enemy minions run their little level 1 legs into your minion ball.If I'm not mistaken, Dungeon Keeper had a finite minion pool available on each map, and each portal would only allow a limited number of minions through.  When a minion died, it was gone for good and not available to either you, nor your enemies any longer.  This is what made portals matter, prisons, graveyards and torture chambers vital and scavenging pits so annoying.  It also ment you could slap the ever loving♥♥♥♥♥♥out of worthless creatures and kill them (or sacrifice them in the temple to make something better) so they wouldn't be constantly taking up a slot a better minion could be filling.  This also ment you could win a war of attrition as long as you killed more than you lost.Still, I don't hate the game.  I just get frustrated with the way it makes you play it.  I wish Steam would introduce stars instead of just a Yes/No.  My feelings on the game aren't that binary.  But I guess at the end of the day I'd still say it is worth a try, as long as you don't go expecting pure Dungeon Keeper out of it.

content:
Posted: September 17, 2015
												War for the Overworld is the closest game you'll get to Dungeon Keeper 3, until EA decide to do something great with the property.It shares many similarities to the classic Bullfrog games, but with a lot of bells and whistles (spells, potions, devices etc), giving the game depth and better control over your army. If you want to play a great "Dungeon Keeper" then you'll love this game. The humour is there, possession, torture chambers, workers -- everything you loved.The campaign is pretty good. *Most* of the missions were fun, but some were either too easy, or boring. I don't think it reached the quality of the Bullfrog titles unfortunately.Pet Dungeon seems pointless without the ability to spawn enemies. Skirmish and multiplayer are fun, thanks to the SIn ( level-up ) system, that gives you different ways to play and try out. Imagine a RPG tree system for your rooms and abilities.Some technical problems; nothing game breaking, or causing the game to crash, but you might see weird stuff happen occasionally.If you want another Dungeon Keeper experience then buy it and enjoy. If you want a strategy game, you might find the games rough points distracting.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Anyone who likes Dungeon Keeper, is more than likely going to love this game. I remember when War for the Overworld had maybe two rooms and one or two creatures, and there really wasn't much to the game. After owning this game for over two years, and coming back to it after it's grown and matured more, and to be honest it has grown and matured a hell of a lot over two years, but it has shown phenomenal promise I'm not sure if the devs are going to call the game finished, it feels great, but doesn't feel 100% finished. I do hope that in the future Mods will be a possibility, as they could do a hell of a lot for this game. I've been playing the Dungeon Keeper series since the first DK game, and this game definitely qualifies as a spiritual successor. TL;DR best money I have spent on a game that brings back a lot of nostalgia, even down to the voice of your advisor. The only thing the game is missing, is full modding support, if it had that then it would be on a whole different level than Dungeon Keeper.EDIT: I should add that I do understand the devs decision to pull mod support for now. Unity doesn't make it easy to mod on their engine as you would need to build the mod tools from the ground up. At this time, something like that would more than likely cost more than it's worth.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												It's been what? 15 years since dungeon keeper 2? I really wanted this to be a worthy sucessor after bullfrog was torn apart, but instead we get something reminscent of it, picking up one or two jokes from the DK twins (micro piglets).The game itself works, but the dungeon keeping charms are just painted on - and they rub off quickly.Compared to the desaster that was dungeons 1 & 2, this is closer to the original series, but it's still not understanding it.Where you struggled in dungeon keeper to design your rooms for maximum performance using halls and hallways, you tear down everything in here until you happen accross a gold dig to fill your pockets - and the game suffers for it, as frame rate drops are happening all over the field.It seems the devs want you to make one huge hall, as the pathing system is really the worst part. Whereas the enemy goes straight for your heart whatever you do (often times right into stacked traps) as if scripted, your own hirelings are too stupid to find doorways and start complaining: No money, no food, no sleep, etc.The premise and promise is there, but the parts are too rough around the edge and won't fit together right, always feeling crooked and angled.Nostalgia is a hell of a drug, but this game will make your trip down nostalgia lane a bad one- you're better off going through your storage, looking for that CD with the red frog on the label.

												I'm trying my hardest to have fun here but it just doesn't have the same magic as the originals did, which I played immeditely before starting WFTOThey tried to make the narrator humerous like the older games but they seem to have flandarized him and made him more cartoonishly evil than something actually menacing. It's not terrible, but it's also not what I was looking for.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												A spiritual successor to the Dungeon Keeper series, War for the Overworld is everything you could have wanted and more! It does not try and reinvent the wheel, but instead keeps things as similar to the original as possible while adding some of their own (and community’s) great ideas. The initial release had several bugs - some major, many minor - but the team is currently hot fixing like crazy and improving the game immensely every day.Some people have complained about the state of the game upon release, and although their opinions are not without merit, it should be said that the team that brought you this game is a collection of DK fans. A team who loved the series and wanted to bring the franchise back to life and have worked tireless to do just that. They do not have some large studio behind them – just us, the community. And I actually see that as a good thing, lest we get a horrid game like the Dungeon Keeper mobile game that EA released!If you were a fan of DK then this game will satiate that burning desire to imprison heros before you torture them to death, slay princes and their kin, mine gold to stuff your coffers, and recruit evil creatures to your dungeon all in an effort to rule the Overworld!Richard Ridings: “It's great to have you back….Keeper.”

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												This is most certainly THE best attempt at following up on Dungeon Keeper 2 in an attempt to create the long sought after DK 3 which many of us had waited for.  You'll slip into a nostalgia coma as soon recognise every single component in this game from your previous DK experience.  They nailed it!  But this is also where the problem comes in.The game is a graphically pleasing, humour-filled remake of DK and not so much a sequel. Sure enough there is a bloody good load of newly added components, such as the titan creatures and a "leveling" scheme which allows you to unlock traps, rooms and the odd creature using points called "sins".   Heck, they even have the original voice-over from the old DK games! Nostalgia overload.  The campaign is "alright" and provides you with around 9 hours worth of gameplay - less if you are just one of those gamers who nail-it fast.  I completed the campaign a day after I bought the game and then, you are stuck with very few options.  The sandbox modes are pretty much blank maps with infinate gold that allows you to quickly dig out enough space and place all of your dungeon rooms and summon all of your creatures - provides you with around 30 minutes of entertainment.  Multiplayer is an excrutiating experience.  For those of you who have been playing games outside of steam's DRm, you'll remember those horrible tech nightmares where you had to go and mess about with your port settings, enabling UPnP on your routers and so on - the days we all thought were long gone since steam (and other DRM's) provided a platform that negates this.  Well, in the spirit of nostalgia you may well enough enjoy that experience in this game again.  Multiplayer is stock standard, once you get it working.  Play against other opponents and squash them.  Whether it is you and a mate vs the AI (the developer's definition of Coop...if you can believe that) or whether it is two of you vs two other dungeoneers - all modes we should be fairly familiar with.The actual coop which was hinted at during the kickstarter, though not reached, also seems to be not in the pipeline for the near future.  Now this does not mean it is off the table entirely, though it doesn't look to be soon.  The expansion, "Heart of Gold" (released two or three days prior to this review) adds about 4 - 6 hours worth of play in a campaign, some dungeon visuall candy for multiplayer and the odd spell here and there.  It's not an expensive expansion and therefor the little content can be quantified.  Overall, the game's base price vs what you get for it is not good at all.  This is the kind of game we should be looking for during steam specials.  You will barely get a weekend's worth of playing from both the game and its current expansion and multiplayer is unlikely to entertain you for very long if you get past the uneccesary setup hassles.  In summary:They absolutely succeeded in providing a nostalgic experience in the spirit of Dungeon Keeper. No one can compete.However, the game falls horribly short in providing an entertaining experience for more than an approximate 15 hours worth of play (more, maybe, if you really really like repeating the same actions). No Coop (and mplay coop 2v2 does NOT constitute coop at all).The game's development does not seem to be entirely finished and there "appears" to be some level of new content being planned.  This may very well be a boon to the current state of the game.  Though, if not getting this title on a good special I would suggest that you seek out the most recent reviews of newly added content on our usual trusty sources (i.e IGN, Gamespot, Gamasutra, Cooptimus).

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												An enjoyable spiritual successor marred by bad performance issues.I have a system with a GTX980, i7-4790K, 16GB of RAM and I have this game installed on an SSD. On the later campaign maps my FPS drops to 16-30FPS depending on my zoom level, changing the graphical settings does nothing but even if it did it still wouldn't be excusable. I get a better frame rate on Witcher 3 with most of the settings cranked up to max for goodness sake. I'd absolutely love to recommend this game but if I'm having these sorts of issues with a system such as mine I dread to think how this game runs on less beefy systems because even my fully expanded Pet Dungeon is averaging out at 20 FPS.Here's a quick list of things that stuck to me after playing the whole campaign in one sitting:The good news? - It's practically Dungeon Keeper 3, if you've played the previous games playing this will be like riding a bike.- Richard Ridings is as good as ever. - They absolutely nailed the sound design.The so-so?- Greater degree of micromanagement:- I really don't like how doors function in this game, there's no 'only open for my minions mode'. You either keep it open or lock yourself in.- Prisons offer a greater variety of choices but it's always a manual process as to what you do with them. If the developer insists on these not automatically turning into undead like before there should at least be a means to auto-allocate them to the torture chamber, crypt or turn them into gold.- Imps and traps are tied to a limited mana pool, ultimately limiting the number you can have of either but this also means too many imps affects the number of traps you can create and vise versa. Not only that, imps don't seem to get any sort of speed increase as they level up.The uh-oh?- Aforementioned performance issues.- Campaign is seriously lacking variety. Albeit, there are some call-backs to the sort of thing you'd see in DK1&2 but there isn't much of a sense of exploration and it's sorely lacking in surprises. You won't be running into ball traps or neutral rooms in this game. The maps also often feel a little cramped in regards to how much space they're offering you to build rooms of an acceptable size of quantity.- Unit balance seems all over the place and level 10 units feel weak. Battles seem to be about whoever has the most amount of units regardless of level.- And then there's some somewhat niggling issues like your minions getting upset and leaving a fight (or ignoring NPCs altogether) because they want to get fed or paid. I was warned that my minions were starting to revolt on the final level simply because there was such a prolonged period of fighting before you were granted the opportunity to send your minions back home.I really like this game and want to see it become the DK3 everyone wanted but it still needs some serious work. I certainly don't regret my purchase but these shortcoming need to be noted. If you really want your Dungeon Keeper fix but already played DK1 and 2 to death you still might get some enjoyment out of this. The core is all there, it's all the ragged edges that need smoothing out.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												Greetings, dungeon keep...err, I mean Underlord,I had been playing Dungeon Keeper II for a couple of decades when I heard about this game by chance, back when it was still bare-bones early access.At the time I bought it mainly to get some money to the devs in the hopes that they would actually produce a worthy sequel to the aforementioned Dungeon Keeper II and not just take me and the other early accessers money and run laughing into the hills. So I played the bare-bone version when I bought it, felt a bit ambivalant about it and then as the months passed I forgot completely that I even had it. Until now that is!So, coming back to the game now that it is more fleshed out, has a couple of campaigns and is generally a lot stabler I must say that I'm really enjoying it. It still has its issues but I cant tell if thats my now somewhat decrepid computer or the game itself; Units occasionally just freezeing in place and not doing anything being the most common and annoying problem. Other than that, it looks good, feels good. The narrator is spot on. The art direction pretty interesting and yeah, I suppose over all it just feels like I'm playing Dungeon Keeper III.Now this last part is both high praise and a bit of a negative critique in one; DKII set the gold standard for dungeon management sims so the fact that this delivers the same albeit somewhat updated experience is awesome. To an extent.Yes there are more mechanics to enjoy such as in game research, alchemy and rituals but it still feels almost like a reskinned carbon copy of DKII. Almost. Although maybe that's what they were intentionally going for. I havent read the dev blogs or anythign but if that is the case, kudos to them. They really nailed it. It would have been nice to see a tad more ambition but ho hum... Still, this is by no means a damning indictment of the game, just an observation. I wanted a spiritual successor to DKII and I got one. I haven't tried any of the other Dungeon Sims that has been cropping up recently so I can't compare.All in all, an enjoyable game to sate my inner dungeon architect. Because that's the most fun part right? Designing the actual dungeon and making it look all nice? Building up ingenious defences and watching the good guys crash and break against the bulwarks only to be dragged unconcious into the dark echoing interior to never see the light of day again, yeah?Well, it is for me in any case; in game as well as in real life... Erm...I may have said too much. Dungeon? I know of no dungeons, officer......Bye!

												I have waited with playing till major patch and version 1.1.15 out now in July, as an all time DKeeper/Theme Hospital player, what can I say after 5 levels of playing:- fruitful successor of DKeeper/Theme Hospital/Evil Genius games for both old fans and new people who likes strategic/management games- very nice up to date graphics, visual and audio effects - very atmospheric game - you will feel the decay and staleness of damp hallways as much as coziness of warm fireplace within your tavern- I have found no glitches, placehgolders or errors, game is stable and much less resource hungry than 2 months ago- cant stop playing, as the campaing is damn catchy - turtle/haste as you wish, spend half an hour with researching every single map corner or start fighting right from beginning...- next iteration of Dungeon Keeper as it should be - all those old good things with more options due to new potions, rituals, wall replacemets,...CHECK FOR YOURSELF, youre not gonna be disappointed!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												Greetings, dungeon keep...err, I mean Underlord,I had been playing Dungeon Keeper II for a couple of decades when I heard about this game by chance, back when it was still bare-bones early access.At the time I bought it mainly to get some money to the devs in the hopes that they would actually produce a worthy sequel to the aforementioned Dungeon Keeper II and not just take me and the other early accessers money and run laughing into the hills. So I played the bare-bone version when I bought it, felt a bit ambivalant about it and then as the months passed I forgot completely that I even had it. Until now that is!So, coming back to the game now that it is more fleshed out, has a couple of campaigns and is generally a lot stabler I must say that I'm really enjoying it. It still has its issues but I cant tell if thats my now somewhat decrepid computer or the game itself; Units occasionally just freezeing in place and not doing anything being the most common and annoying problem. Other than that, it looks good, feels good. The narrator is spot on. The art direction pretty interesting and yeah, I suppose over all it just feels like I'm playing Dungeon Keeper III.Now this last part is both high praise and a bit of a negative critique in one; DKII set the gold standard for dungeon management sims so the fact that this delivers the same albeit somewhat updated experience is awesome. To an extent.Yes there are more mechanics to enjoy such as in game research, alchemy and rituals but it still feels almost like a reskinned carbon copy of DKII. Almost. Although maybe that's what they were intentionally going for. I havent read the dev blogs or anythign but if that is the case, kudos to them. They really nailed it. It would have been nice to see a tad more ambition but ho hum... Still, this is by no means a damning indictment of the game, just an observation. I wanted a spiritual successor to DKII and I got one. I haven't tried any of the other Dungeon Sims that has been cropping up recently so I can't compare.All in all, an enjoyable game to sate my inner dungeon architect. Because that's the most fun part right? Designing the actual dungeon and making it look all nice? Building up ingenious defences and watching the good guys crash and break against the bulwarks only to be dragged unconcious into the dark echoing interior to never see the light of day again, yeah?Well, it is for me in any case; in game as well as in real life... Erm...I may have said too much. Dungeon? I know of no dungeons, officer......Bye!
