number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2013
												Dungeon Keeper was my most favorite game of all time, and I've been waiting a little under 14 years for the sequel that never came, until now that is.I'd recommend this game to anyone who appreciates the older, finer games that were common place a decade ago.-Edit-Now that the game has been fully released, I'll give it my 1.0 day 1 launch review. I'll review it again once there is a more stable patch.This game captures Dungeon Keepers essense without question, it is everything you can expect from a Dungeon Keeper sequel and more. It's unique style sets itself apart and is a breath of fresh air, but you cant help but think you're playing Dungeon Keeper. For this I can give the abiance, theme, gameplayand atmosphere no less than 11/10Now onto my problems with the game.The game feels very rushed, the skirmish mode is limited to 3 maps, limited to 2 players with a smallish map with little to it. It seems like they are placeholder maps, and it's not like the sandbox map is a small as the skirmish maps. I feel like for launch, 3 small sized 2 player maps doesn't cut it.In multiplayer, it is extremely buggy as the minions don't fight each other properly, the game is prone to crashing, I noticed when destroying another players dungeon heart, damage doesn't appear to be dealt either.The campaign is very prone to FPS drops, no matter the persons computer specs. It first appears in mission 3, or in any game where the enemey can attack your dungeon heart, as for whatever reason that drops FPS to unplayable levels, That isn't the end to the FPS drops as from mission 4 on, FPS drops are common and on mission 4, happen right at the end as you're mousing over the inhibiters and shrines and for the rest of the game once you have vision of that area.These will all be patched so I will edit this post once it has been fixed, but for those expecting to buy this game and play it over the weekend, this post is to warn you that the game is having a troubled launch as most games do.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												War for the Overworld has now been officially released with a story campaign I can play through and the love the devs have put into this project has become apparent.It's messy around the edges and could be perfect with a bit of tidying up, but here's my re-review for you:War for the Overworld has successfully put itself on the map as the best dungeon "god" simulator we've had for a long, long time. It is incredibly similar to Dungeon Keeper (so much so that I keep struggling to call it otherwise in my Let's Play for it!).Now, when I first re-opened the game, I was again annoyed that everything seemed a bit bland and grim around the edges in colour. A strange criticism for a game surrounding evil overlords, but one worth adding. I did however have a personal fix for this. One that I haven't had to utilize in years, outside of a horror game. I adjusted the gamma ... though I did so by a whooping 60% brighter.I can now see the detail the devs have put into some of the blocks, the rooms, the gold veins, the walls and more. It's a very, very beautiful sight to see and one that brings back many memories to the old DK games that WFTO was inspired by. It just seems such a shame that the darkness level is so off that I needed to adjust it by that amount to see the gorgeous detail (something I haven't had to do on any other game in my library or console, since Resident Evil 5 on the 360!).Would I recommend WFTO to an RTS friend or a friend new to gaming?As of this re-review, yes I would.Summary of Pros and Cons:Pros:Art team have worked incredibly hard on their designs, with only a few feeling "rushed" or in need of improvement. To perfect this, I'd recommend a DLC release of additional textured skins for monsters. Allowing players to see their succubi with the more traditional tail, wings and hoofs demon look, or the Cultist with an entirely different robe/without hood (take DK2's hero creatures and do one better, especially if you're charging for it!)Spells very potent and powerful, though mana caps left me feeling like a kid waiting for their pocket money (even with a limited amount of workers and traps!), as mana slowly trickled up again. It's a tough balancing act I suppose, though I'd rather cast more harmful spells with less damage, than a more potent one, waiting for the resources to do so. Dungeon Keeper 1's charging spells did a very good job of that, giving you additional options to take on your foes.The sound effect team have done an amazing job, leaving me without anything but praise in that department. Music wise, we could use something a bit more noticeable from time to time, with the most notable bit of ambience that comes to mind, being the beating of your dungeon core. Maybe have a track that brings more epic to large scale combat?Traps are simple, but effective and the rate at which they're constructed is lovely. Constructs are a beautiful addition that allow for a great deal of variety when planning both your attacks and defences and bring in a truly unique mechanic to the familiar game play style we have come to love.This now feels like a suitable replacement for the game-play style of the Dungeon Keeper games, though it has also put itself on the map with unique mechanics only found within WFTO.The animations that are in the game look very nice and flow very well! This is a bitter sweet bit of praise that I'll elaborate on in the cons section...Cons:Certain lines of dialogue appear time and time again and just aren't bold enough in their dark humour to be as funny as the standard we've seen before. The Cultist is constantly testing my patience and leaving me to consider home schooling my workers, simply so that I can hurl the cultists into the torture chamber, due to lacking a suitable means of gagging them. The narrator is especially bad for this, with introductions nattering on for far too long, quips being far too frequent and notifications severely needing a "Toggle Vocal Notifications Off" option.It's not that I don't appreciate him telling me that a Gnarling has entered my dungeon, but at times it almost sounds as if he's telling me "A Gnarling has picked his nose and flicked the snot. Just thought you should know." some things need a verbal notification, whilst others could do nicely with a quick icon to let you know.Animations! Where art thou? I want to see the creatures roaming idle around my dungeon, DRINKING in the tavern or playing darts! I want to see the creatures walking about exploring the halls, or performing a unique idle animation to give more character! You have amazing animators on your team, so I cannot stress how much this would add to breathe life into your key actors, the monsters themselves! Picking up minions, dropping them and by ALL THAT IS EVIL, give them a unique and satisfying reaction (for us ;) ) to being slapped!The right click is not being utilized as well as it could, and it would be nice to see a grand overview of the mini map, akin to DK's right click to enlarge and snap to location. Breaking out of possession should be a right click motion. You need to be given the ability to maim your enemy as quickly as possible through the eyes of your beast, so again, "Attack" should be your default ability upon possessing a monster.Placeholders. Ladies and Gentlemen, you know this is absolutely unacceptable for a fully released game, though I have no doubt at all that this will be updated in time.I now consider WFTO a fun game to play, that has delivered quality for the money I originally paid way back when. If you are sitting on the fence about buying this, I would say go for it. You will find a fun game full of love, though one that is currently in a late state of Early Access.Old negative review below:The contents below are from my previous experiences with WFTO which was originally a "Not Recommended" critique. I still have a critique to give, but I would recommend this game to a friend in its current state, even with a very cheeky release from Early Access.Prior to editing this 153/266 people (58%) agreed with the contents below, for an October 2014 Early Access review."This review is written as a review from an early access point of view.This game will attract people in pursuit of a way to sake their Dungeon Keeper cravings, but unfortunately the execution of War for the Overworld just seems very off to me and I'll try to explain why.The art style carries something that isn't all that unique considering its inspiration here, though inside the game it sadly follows the horrible dark pallet of muddy browns and snot greens. The original Bullfrog games carried a lovely sense of character behind their cartoony characters with a mix of gritty in there, though the monsters featured in War for the Overworld (Monsters being the most critical desired feature for this kind of game), all lack a true sense of personality and shine, with none of them really standing out and saying "Hey look at me! I'm a really epic looking creature! I'm the funny creature that hits like a tank!", it just feels lacking here.I bought the game very early on and have logged on progressively overtime to inspect the updates. After what seems like a year now, the updates have been far too slow and lacking in real momentum, especially considering the price tag and how early this early access game arrived.This game carries a positive review score currently, though from what I've seen of them, quite a few of these reviews are posted with the hope and praise that this game is the next Dungeon Keeper.Sadly, at the time of writing this, I believe this game is not a viable replacement for your evil sandbox and doesn't seem like it will be any time soon."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												*** NOMINATED FOR A STEAM AWARD 24TH November 2016 ***I purchased War for the Overworld Underlord Edition + Early Adopter Bonus (Early Access) on 22/08/2014.I put off playing until this month as I wanted to support the development and wait for a more "polished" game.Following is my review of my experience playing from start to finish (Avoiding spoilers and game play guides).I have been building, customizing and using personal computers and consoles since the late 80s.My system is:AMD FX 9370 Eight-Core Processor @4.7GHz32GB PC2200 RAMSamsung 850 EVO 250GB SSDWestern Digital Black 2TBPowerColor R9 290 4GB GFX CardRunning x64 Windows 8.1 EnterpriseStarting the game I found loading times to be a bit long.Once starting to play the experience was good.Each level progression was as to be expected and offered a more robust enemy, however, each level up to and including level 11 took no more than two attempts to finish. The hardest level from my experience was level 12. I took sometime to complete this level with at least five attempts being racked up.The final level was very easy. In fact too easy. The only reason I took more than three attempts to complete it was due to a bug that stopped me. This bug persisted through game save and load and system restart forcing me to start the level over on two occasions.The ending was disappointing. Leaving me, and others, to think the end cut scene was glitched. (I no longer believe this is the case).Bad:Loading times are long, especially when launching the game I often had "Program not responding" dialogs pop up. After clicking wait for program to respond the game would start.Lag, Lag and more Lag! The game lags a lot. Especially when big battles are happening.Still buggy in parts. Even though the game is now considered a "Release" product.AI can be very stupid. Good for us trying to beat it. No so good for over all game enjoyment.Sometimes mid battle you are healing or zapping trying to protect your core and.... ARRRRR.... A cut scene as a new minion enters your dungeon with no way to skip the bloody thing.Good:As a fan of the Dungeon Keeper games and having spent many, many hours playing them this game does not disappoint and keeps to the spirit of the DK sieris.Despite all of the "Bad" above the game is still well worth buying as I am sure with refinement via patches this will fix most of the issues.Bottom line:I would recommend this game if you are a fan of the DK games or if you are new.I score this game 7/10. (This is because I am a fan of the DK games and can over look the issues I had).I hope the issues are patched and if/when they are the game will be much better.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												See my full review here: 


YouTube™ Video: War for the Overworld - Heart of Gold: The Review 

			Views: 1,765		

			War for the Overworld - Heart of Gold: The Review WFTO: 7/10 | HoG: 5/10 Wanna know why? Watch the video. Be sure to drop me a link in the comments section to your own reviews so I can watch and give...		

When WFTO was first released I was really excited but having played it I was left a bit disappointed. But since then, the game has just gotten better and better with a lot of love and care from the developers, new features and bug fixes all totally free through patches, whereas most games would release them as DLC. So it goes to show that Sub. Games really care about their player base to give them some pretty monumental new features without asking for a penny. (I'm talking about The Map Creator, of course).It came as a surprise to me that the Heart of Gold Expansion arrived, it's something that I wasn't expecting at all and I was more than willing to pay the very reasonable fee for this content and I certainly wasn't disappointed, Heart of Gold gives access to some pretty cool new features along with a new campaign of 4 maps which pushes the story forward, this time playing as Kasita (A Dungeon Master you defeated in the Original Campaign), which had me bouncing with excitement.The new campaign is fun and challenging and well worth the money. I really look forward to the Next Expansion... Though I still don't quite understand what the heck happened at the end of the Original Game and indeed why "Daddy Pig" turned on us... Very confusing!All in all rating for WFTO: 7/10

content:
Posted: June 12, 2016
												Well. Where to begin.To start off, i played dungeon keeper 2, never really dungeon keeper 1. I LOVED dk2. Absolutely played the hell out of it.Obviously i cant play that anymore, so for ages i looked for a worthy successor to Bullfrog's games.This game will do.You can clearly see they've been inspired by the dungeon keeper series.You start off with your hand, a dungeon heart that you need to protect, and some imps. With your hand, you can mark tiles for your imps to dig and claim for you. Then you can make rooms into the space you've dug out like a library, a lair where your minions rest, or a pig farm where your minions can feed on succulent pig flesh (They make such a satisfying splatter noise when you eat them), or a workshop where certain minions can build traps and doors to guard your dungeon.As the game progresses, you get access to more rooms like the prison, torture chamber, graveyard or Sanctuary. You also unlock more defenses and spells, giving you more options during battle, planning your dungeon or keeping your gold up to level.The campaign by itself is pretty decent, here and there are a few bugs the devs havent fixed yet, but nothing game-breaking as far as i could tell. I would also recommend the Heart of Gold DLC pack for another campaign, as that one was also nice to play, and adds a few extras.Campaign however, is not the only thing you can play. You can skirmish against other Underlords, with AI that you can ramp up or reduce the difficulty of as you please, there are sandbox maps where you get a dungeon heart, lots and lots of space to build and dig and roomify as you please, with an inert hero portal and controls for it so you can choose when you want to have heroes banging on your doors.There are a few things that require adjustment, but i wouldn't say they make the game unplayable, just a bit annoying sometimes. Overall i'd say this game is a solid 7/10. Not as great as i had hoped, but it's not bad. Not bad at all.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2015
War for the Overworld is quite obviously the true successor to Dungeon Keeper 2.War for the Overworld perfectly captures the feel of Dungeon Keeper as well as standing up on its own, regardless of the clear ties to the classic title. It feels good, it plays good, it is good. AI is balanced and provides a genuine challenge. Story Mode expertly blends compelling gameplay with teaching you the game step by step. At the time of writing, I haven't personally tried multiplayer, but if it is as good as the rest of the game, it's good.I don't know what else to say. With EA being, well, EA with the original series, this is your next best thing. And it is an excellent second option.Plus the announcer for both Dungeon Keepers is the same for this.A masterpiece. 10/10 Asmodeus sent me an inbox.

Posted: June 26, 2015
												I have not had the time to play the game a whole lot yet.  What I have seen so far I really like.  I have played all the Dungeon Keeper games of old.  I do miss ol'Horny and the mistresses.  I realize that they can't do those for legal reasons, but it sure would be great.  I also miss the cut scenes from the original that came up between the scenerios. They were hilarious and gave the old games great charm.  But back to this one.  It is well worth your time and effort.  You can tell these guys actually care about the old Dungeon Keeper games.  I for one think they have done a great job so far.  Are there things that could be added  -- sure.  Are there things missing -- sure.  You have to not only give them time, but they also have a staff to pay.  Great games are not free and this one was started on a shoe string and has been done about as well as could be.I recomend this game for anyone that likes RTS's with a twist.  And for all those DK fans out there -- This one IS WORTH it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												War for the Overworld is a really well-implemented and polished reimagination of the original Dungeon Keeper games. The game is really good at keeping the gameplay and feel of the original games while improving both the UI and certain aspects like army management. The game features a solid campaign and tons of rooms, spells and other mechanics for the player to explore. Personally, I think the game might even have too many mechanics. You constantly unlock new stuff and I haven't felt the need to use most of it. While I generally like the game, there is one HUGE caveat, which is the ending of the campaign. I will not spoil it here, but I've never experienced such a cheap and annoyingly expansion-baiting end in a game before. It left me feeling really unfulfilled. Nevertheless, the pros outweigh the huge con in my opinion. If you've liked Dungeon Keeper, you'll enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												Greetings, dungeon keep...err, I mean Underlord,I had been playing Dungeon Keeper II for a couple of decades when I heard about this game by chance, back when it was still bare-bones early access.At the time I bought it mainly to get some money to the devs in the hopes that they would actually produce a worthy sequel to the aforementioned Dungeon Keeper II and not just take me and the other early accessers money and run laughing into the hills. So I played the bare-bone version when I bought it, felt a bit ambivalant about it and then as the months passed I forgot completely that I even had it. Until now that is!So, coming back to the game now that it is more fleshed out, has a couple of campaigns and is generally a lot stabler I must say that I'm really enjoying it. It still has its issues but I cant tell if thats my now somewhat decrepid computer or the game itself; Units occasionally just freezeing in place and not doing anything being the most common and annoying problem. Other than that, it looks good, feels good. The narrator is spot on. The art direction pretty interesting and yeah, I suppose over all it just feels like I'm playing Dungeon Keeper III.Now this last part is both high praise and a bit of a negative critique in one; DKII set the gold standard for dungeon management sims so the fact that this delivers the same albeit somewhat updated experience is awesome. To an extent.Yes there are more mechanics to enjoy such as in game research, alchemy and rituals but it still feels almost like a reskinned carbon copy of DKII. Almost. Although maybe that's what they were intentionally going for. I havent read the dev blogs or anythign but if that is the case, kudos to them. They really nailed it. It would have been nice to see a tad more ambition but ho hum... Still, this is by no means a damning indictment of the game, just an observation. I wanted a spiritual successor to DKII and I got one. I haven't tried any of the other Dungeon Sims that has been cropping up recently so I can't compare.All in all, an enjoyable game to sate my inner dungeon architect. Because that's the most fun part right? Designing the actual dungeon and making it look all nice? Building up ingenious defences and watching the good guys crash and break against the bulwarks only to be dragged unconcious into the dark echoing interior to never see the light of day again, yeah?Well, it is for me in any case; in game as well as in real life... Erm...I may have said too much. Dungeon? I know of no dungeons, officer......Bye!

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Are you feeling like a sad imp, unlike the proud Underlord you should be? Are you missing your piles of gold and minions to slap? Do not hesitate any longer, as worthy servants have toiled hard to ensure that you will have a new world to conquer. The original underground might have fallen under a terrible management, but this new world offers both a familiar kick of the old and a slightly different take on the whole slaughter, pillage, punish and so forth gig. Nostalgic feelings may arise from time to time, and you need to be aware Underlord, that your memory often serves a bit more gold on the old world than what it actually had. Speaking of gold, the effort the creative minions have placed into this is utterly incredible. Forced by the cruel constraints of reality, that often works better than any torture even you lord could imagine, they still persevered. From placing their hopes on the gold shrine known as Kickstarter, to working overtime in order to get things done and done right, their dedication and love for you Underlord shines true. I recommend that you give them some extra meat for that. I hear that anyone can be made into a great meal. As you embark on this new adventure of conquest my Lord, I hope you'll notice my familiar voice and enjoy what you have been waiting years for. Give it an honest chance and don't let the past be your guide. The Overworld needs a leader and he doesn't have time to weep about his lost dungeon.Welcome back Underlord, your kingdom awaits!

												i love this. it reminds me of my childhood favorite game dungeon keeper. i don't believe its made by any of the people who worked on dungeon keeper but it reminds me so much of it. i love it. games like this are very few and far apart, i give it a 9/10. heres whythis is one of the few games where you play as the bad guy. its a RTS that takes place in dungeons. you build facilities for your creatures, you feed them, train them, and in return they will defend your dungeon, attack another enemy keeper, attack heroes, research things like rooms, spells and traps. finally they will also do things like convert captured enemies, and make traps. sounds a little complicated but like the DK games, they slowly walk you through it. anyhow i love it, its more or less a blast from the early/mid 90s, remade for today and i would love to see more games like this

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2016
												One campaign, a look through the level editor and a rapid check of the multiplayer later, can I truly give this game a honest review ? Oberon help me, let's do this.WFTO is a labour of love, a game that was born from passion rather than a desire for money.It is the kind of experience that might be less polished than other games (the game could use a ton of bugfixes), but every inch of the game has been crafted with passion, and you've got to respect that. But there's a lot to say about this spiritual sequel to Dungeon Keeper.Graphically, the game is superb, and more importantly, it's memorable ! From the colorful rooms, to the dark creatures, down to the little details like the awesome logo (can't keep my eyes off that logo, it's pretty !) or the achievement icons, this games looks great. Kudos to the art team.Musically there isn't much to discuss, the music is very discrete, but the sound design and narrator voice more than make up for that silence. Too bad after 20 hours all I wanted was for him to shut up, because he never stops talking. Campaign is solid, a good tutorial that suffers from some ridiculous difficulty spikes at times. I rage quit some missions multiple times because some rival underlord's actions are very random and they won't behave the same way every time.In the end, this game could potentially become a worthy successor to DK/DK2, but it still needs some fine tuning and polishing. In terms of content, there's more than enough to keep you busy for months, but I don't really feel compelled to return now that i have finished the campaign (which is still something only 10% of the playerbase has done, so hurray !).Wait for the developers to iron out most problems, wait for it to go on sale, and grab yourself a copy of War for the Overworld.

content:
Posted: January 18
												A very good remake of Dungeon Keeper.  Nice graphical and UI upgrade over the original.  Building your dungeon is fun. However, this game suffer from the same flaw as the original, namely uninspiring combat.  You just pick your minions, drop them on the invaders and then hope for the best.  The rally flags aren't very useful, they could be improved by having one for each creature types.  Possession mode is still the coolest feature you'll never use.  Finished the main campaign in about 18h, mostly playing on easy (50% speed).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												One of the few game based Kickstarter projects I've backed and which have delivered. WFTO is an enjoyable game, with great audio and visual's, and is a worthy spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper. With caveats.DK2 remains one of my favourite games, but WFTO can't quite match it. With DK2, I am content to spend a very long time building a dungeon, training my forces and then annihilating my foes. WFTO on the other hand wants you to speedrun the levels as fast as possible. Combine that with some really poor performance problems, I ended up shelving the game for a very long time, only picking it up again recently to finish it off. (Also, as a sideeffect of being forced to "rush" levels, the game feels bloody short).As a Kickstarter backer, one of the perks I received was a custom dungeon skin - I have never even seen this as it doesn't apply for the main campain. Assumably then it applies to multiplayer (which I'm unlikely to play) or sandbox, which I'm likely to try once or twice. Plus, the game offers bonus skins for unlocking speedrun achivements. Not that I have done these, but again I don't see the point of custom skins if you can only use them in limited places.That's all my opinion, so may be different for you. I hope the expansion is a little more laid back though.

												Overall quite a decent game, though it isnt as good as the original Dungeon Keeper, i find it suffers the same problems as Dungeon Keeper 2 contrasted to the first one, with abit too much of humanoid-creatures as oposed to the monster-freakshow that used to be the first one, though i've enjoyed myself somewhat with it, and and in of itself would probatly recommend it if you're into the genre of Dungeon-Management or Theme-Hospital/Prison Manager type games.Negative, Major Irks.-Realy dislike the need to have to "Recall" your minions rather than picking them up heads off when they're off friendly terratory, especialy given the AI's tendacy to want to wander off without anything encouraging them to do so, and this point is what takes 1.5 points straight off the bat off my score, the recall-function is clunky and annoying and not very user friendly or nice-feeling when you have to swap to a panel (to spells) to even do it.-I miss, the hand actualy HOLDING your creature and watching some of them flail about within it's grasp, and feel like it's a loss of a dark-humor thing.-Lack of Hardware Cursor Option, the ingame "cursor" seems delayed and swaying and isnt very smooth to controll.-7.5/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Edit 27-07-2016I didn't grow up with Dungeon Keeper, in fact I had never even heard of it until I started watching The Co-Optional Podcast so there's very little in the way of nostalgia for me with this game.With that said, I absolutely adore War For The Overworld. The writing is funny, the characters are amusing, the visual aesthetic is perfect for what they're trying to achieve and the mechanics are thoroughly engrossing.It's not without its flaws, and I'm not entirely certain if this is a result of the Unity engine or not, but there are times where the game will stutter or "hiccup" and I can't pin down the reason as to why. My CPU is more than enough to handle this game and doesn't go anywhere near capping even during these odd little hiccups, but that's a minor annoyance rather than a dealbreaker.The original War for the Overworld campaign gives you several hours to play with and acts as sort of an extended tutorial, which may disappoint some but I'm happy to say that with 1.4 and the first expansion "Heart of Gold" there's more for you to do with fewer restrictions. A couple new mechanics are added in as well, so it's more than just an added campaign.I highly recommend War for the Overworld on its own merits, but don't expect a traditional RTS as it's more of a god game.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Pretty fun game. I really enjoy the atmosphere and the narrator is fantastic. Certain parts are fairly dumbed down compared to what you would expect in a typical RTS, but I don't consider that a bad thing (in fact I would say it works great in this kind of game). Your minions are mostly automated and will do their jobs and train themselves but as the underlord you can of course micro them as much as you want. I also find the idea of you as the dungeon master having a mana bar as a resource to cast spells, build defences, and hire workers pretty unique as well. Now that's not to say the game doesn't have some problems. Even though your minions are autonomous they are sometimes kind of stupid and don't sleep, eat, or get their paycheck quick enough and you'll often get messages that they're unhappy. This can usually be solved by just clicking on them and dropping them into the area they are lacking in but I don't really think you should have to do that when you don't have them assigned to anything. The worker flag is kind of irritating too because you can either force all workers to work on an area (sometimes I want like  2-3 still working on the other side) or you can let them decide what to prioritize and sometimes they'll just dig walls or run off to another task instead of placing all the floor tiles down while I'm waiting to make a room. Note that this may just be me not being good enough at the game to figure out how to assign workers properly.The economy system is kind of wierd too. You get unlimited gold from workers mining these "gold shrines" which are big rectangular boxes. I think if maybe gold acted like mana where you could mine a big chunk of it, but it wouldn't start recharging until you stopped mining it for awhile it might be better? I'm not sure. This isn't really a major complaint but it's something I dislike. Overall, the game does have a number of issues, but nearly all of them can be overlooked or are very minor. I do highly recommend trying out War for the Overworld because it does feel really unique to play as an actual bad guy for once. The gameplay is solid and so far the campaign has been a very enjoyable experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												I haven't played Dungeon Keeper in more than a decade but as far as I'm concerned this is the spiritual successor that definitely fulfills a niche that needed filling. The narrator has that wickedly eeevil sound, most of the maps are challenging, and the game is just plain fun. Initially I was frustrated with aspects of the interface and AI but after getting into the game a few levels then going back to the tutorial, I realized I missed a few things that were covered that were integral to playing. Some areas of the interface could use some polishing, like the war flags on the right (which in my opinion should be easier-to-click inlaid icons) but once you learn the keyboard hotkeys they stop frustrating you. The deveopers also seem to take an active interest in responding to the community and they're regularly putting out patches so thumbs up there. I'd say the biggest gripes I have is an inability to pause or slow the game; I'm not sure if you could pause in DK or DK2 but it just seems sensible that this should be an included function with rushing maps that have timed waves. I also wish happy minions would follow your build instructions in the order they were assigned rather that engaging in what seems random instructions. You have a wave coming at you in 2 minutes and they've decided to reinforce walls in a useless room rather than dig out the dirt. While you can specify an area for them to focus on, this function doesn't always work nor does it rate high on my useability scale.I should also add that I've experienced no performance issues whatsoever and the game runs like a dream on my i7 with nvidia GTX 970 with all settings maxed.

The writing is funny, the characters are amusing, the visual aesthetic is perfect for what they're trying to achieve and the mechanics are thoroughly engrossing.It's not without its flaws, and I'm not entirely certain if this is a result of the Unity engine or not, but there are times where the game will stutter or "hiccup" and I can't pin down the reason as to why. My CPU is more than enough to handle this game and doesn't go anywhere near capping even during these odd little hiccups, but that's a minor annoyance rather than a dealbreaker.The original War for the Overworld campaign gives you several hours to play with and acts as sort of an extended tutorial, which may disappoint some but I'm happy to say that with 1.4 and the first expansion "Heart of Gold" there's more for you to do with fewer restrictions. A couple new mechanics are added in as well, so it's more than just an added campaign.I highly recommend War for the Overworld on its own merits, but don't expect a traditional RTS as it's more of a god game.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												This game is incredibly enjoyable and really captures the old Dungeon Keeper spirit, while adding a few tricks of its own.I avoided the rocky, buggy launch at the start and have come in a bit later into the game. Boy was it worth hanging back, as the recent review score shows (81% as of writing this)The expansion is great, the campaign is fun (better then DK2 I would say as there's an emphasis on variation between missions) and the old sandbox and skirmish maps are there. What really made the old Dungeon Keepers stand out was the player made maps. Getting PCGamer magazines as a kid with the disks that contained the odd extra map, or downloading them achingly slow off of third party websites on dial up, all that fun. I'm glad to see the workshop in action to allow some great player content.I cannot recommend this game enough if you're after a real successor to DK3.

												I love this game, at first it was abit buggy (earlier versions) and with every patch they make this game better and better. There are still bugs yes but this is still in ALPHA/BETA and honestly I think they are doing a great job. They fix bugs more or less instantly when you report them and constantly add new content or improve old content to give it a better design via listening to users in the community. You know DayZ? Five years and only added one car and two new weapons? Yeah not these guys. Serious fans of the DK series and do their best to make this game the best it can be.Also if you do want to speak to the developers we have a Discord chat where the QA team and Development team are online constantly and always talk to the community in real time. Good luck finding another game with these kind of guys behind it, interact with the community, listen to you, and actually respond. I wish all developers were like these as they are so in-touch with their fan base.These guys/girls are a fine example of exactly how to develop a game from ALPHA and keep your community strong and enertained, and bring in new content very very regularly. Abit of effort and hard work - Well done to you guys, a shining example of how it should be.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Good, modernized version of Dungeon Keeper. The game has some flaws and is badly optimized, which can result in bad performance even on newer system configurations. The campaign is a good introduction into the game mechanics and often missions can be done in many different ways. The missions later on in the game will often appear undoable at first but once you understand what mechanic or concept the devs tried to teach in that mission/lesson, it will become a lot easier (good work on that). The campaign is a little short however and the story is generic at best. Great voice acting on the advisor which in my opinion is often a little too serious.You can tell that the devs have tried to trim the game for competitive multiplayer, which is why the game feels a lot more hectic and microintensive than DK. Unfortunately it is hard to find a multiplayer match, due to the lack of players.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I have to echo the lion's share of the complaints on here, "What is with that ending"? I mean I understand what it's trying to communicate, but it's just so inadequate.That being said, I loved Dungeon Keeper and this is more of the same. There seemed to be a little more in the way of help in Dungeon Keeper but once you ease in to WFTO you'll find nuance that never existed in the old catalogue. I will forever miss the comedic cut scenes between levels in the campaign of DK II but we can't have it all, can we?I do find umbrage in the way AI is handled. Specifically, I find it a little unbalanced that the computer players can produce the enitre contents of their dungeon in under a second while I have to slowly rally my troops or click them, ten at a time, to the desired location. This is especially frustrating in later levels of the campaign or when playing master difficulty in Skirmish mode.My glee returns however with the addition of new spells. Some of which feel spectacularly more sadistic, such as turning enemy captives into gold statues. I do like the new shrines and I am honestly one of those folks that wanted to see the ability to add walls.I don't see myself wasting as much time with this one as I did with DK, but is that because I already played DK? Is it because the content isn't there quite yet? This remains to be seen, but for now, A Solid Buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Review date 2016/01/03, version 1.3, Win OS, only 36 hours under the belt. DK fanboy. 7/10 if they fix the stuttering.It really does feel like you're playing Dungeon Keeper. It has a somewhat more serious tone than the originals, whether or not that's a good thing will be personal preference.They're apparently already working on patch 1.4. There are few issues  as far as I can see that would negatively affect the gameplay - the only one really that got under my skin was the stuttering on the larger maps. Decent graphics & music creates a nice atmosphere. The game is more fast paced than DK2 - I'd recommend setting the game speed to about 60-70%My single player experience : The first half has a distinct DK1 feel to it, while later on with the bigger maps it plays more like DK2.  The campaign was a little short for my liking but I would happily buy an expansion to extend that playtime. Some levels are pretty challenging while others are too easy.Minions : A lot of people didn't like that you had so many "human" minions in DK2 and I feel they have a nice balance here. When you upgrade your beast lair and build a fighting pit, you get 4 different types plus beastmasters who whip them all the way to the pit so they fight each other for xp, the beastmaster also gets xp from this. You have 2 rally flags, one for beasts and one for all your minions so you can use your beasts to ward of small groups without interrupting your minions. Beasts don't collect wages, just the beast master.Undead : Personally I like the way they handled it. Vampires are created by making 3 sacrifices and having a ritual charged. They eat live prisoners. Corpses from the battlefield, torture chamber & prison (after a vampire feeds or they they lie there too long because the prison is full) are taken to the crypt where your necromancers raise them as ghouls (skeletons) who then permanently follow the necro that raised them. Prisoners eat the rats and will not die in your prison.Potions : A new feature where at the cost of some gold you create potions to be used similar to spells. Build an alchemy lab to attract crackpots who will brew them for you.Another absolutely great new feature is the ability to create dirt blocks. In DK2 I'd often lose an hour of play because some dwarf decided to tunnel into my dungeon and I would restart the level. How I wish this was a feature in DK2.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												I really like this game.  It's more complicated than Dungeon II which I also really like.  I do feel that the tutorial in Dungeon II campaign is better though because it explains each little item as you go.  War for the Overworld does not do this.  For instance on Level 7 you really need to build the bombard traps and lots of them but the game does not teach you that you need foundries to get toolboxes to build defenses.  I had a lot of defenses but none of them were building so I had to watch a video online and not only did it show me that you need foundries but that you can pick up toolboxes and put them directly on the defenses to speed up their building.  The game also did not teach me how to use the screen that lists all your monsters and click on it to pick up guys.  I learned that from watching a youtube video.  On level 7 I found the lack of gold to be my biggest obstacle but using blood money and a big prison and turning all their guys into gold statues did the trick.  Infinite gold basically.  Actually it might be level 9 where you have the gold problems looking at my notes.     One problem I have with the game is that moving around on the screen does not work well with the mouse.  In Dungeons II the mouse moves around on the screen really well but in War for the Overworld you really need to use the arrow keys instead.  It works really well with the arrow keys.  Another problem is the game is a bit dark and so it's harder to see the screen.  I understand underground is supposed to be dark but I would really appreciate a little more light for visibility.  Overall the game does a really good job in that you have many minion choices from Succubus to Vampire , etc.    I guess I should be writing this review from the perspective of advertising to someone who has never played a game like this before.  In that case you build a dungeon to defeat the do gooders that come to destroy your dungeon.  You do this by carving out rooms in the underground and then putting things in them like vaults to store gold, Barracks to attract    low level monsters, Prisons to put enemies in, torture chambers for Succubi to convert them to your side or turn them into Ghosts, Beast chambers to attract beasts, etc.  Then you build an army out of these creatures to attack your enemies.  You can also use traps and doors to slow down the enemy or kill them.  All in all this is a very good game.

												This'll probably look ridiculous since steam doesn't track time played offline, but I've actually gotten every achievement except one and played through the original and the DLC campaign multiple times.If you're a fan of Dungeon Keeper this will probably be right up your alley. TL;DR Game is good

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I was really looking forward to this game, as a fan of the Dungeon Keeper 2, and held off buying it earlier on because of the bad reviews regarding how buggy it is. In it's current form, it seems quite playable besides the odd bug (I found on the last map, minions couldn't find food or their bed if my dungeon became too large, even despite my attempts to keep the layout simple.)In general, I have to say I'm disappointed. Being named "War for the Overworld," I expected it to actually follow on from the DK2 storyline and actually be a war for the overworld. However, the campaign just seems like a stale revamp of the original. There's any number of directions it could have been taken in and I was expecting new and exciting content, a new world, new storyline and new characters. The game just seems like DK2 with a new skin though, and little tweaks that just come across as a either a lack of imagination or, more likely, a lazy attempt to avoid copyright violations. If the developers were trying to honor their predecesor, that's one thing, but there just seems to be very little original content added on to what has been copied.I found the start of the campaign a bit tedious, given that the 'tutorial' is built into it, and I'm sure other old players remember enough of how to play to just want to get straight to the meat of it. Unfortunately there wasn't really any meat at all. The levels were very much in line with those from the previous game and the ending felt very anticlimactic and disappointing. There were no quirky cinematics and even the humour, which the previous game was iconic for, falls short of the mark. I'm not as much of a fan of PvP as I was in Dk2, and I'm sure if you are, you'll get more out of this game than I did. For those who prefer single player though, don't get your hopes up. The game just doesn't have any replay value as far as I'm concerned. When I finished DK2, I felt like playing the campaign again straight after. With WftO I finished the campaign and just felt like kicking the game into the corner and never looking at it again.There was also a lot of talk about adding new content to the game, but I haven't seen much at all. There are some new maps to play on but most seem to be coming from the the playerbase and are of course completely disconnected from the storyline. The updates are mainly bug fixes with the odd new (and boring) spell thrown in, and of course character skins (which you have to pay extra for.) The updates are also very slow for what they are. The one good thing I can say about this game is that the graphics are pretty decent. But given the time between now and when DK2 was released, you'd expect better graphics anyway. However, if you were to offer me this game as it is, or DK2 with updated graphics, I'd rather pay for the latter. No competition. There's just far too much lacking from this game for it to be labelled a "spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper" (according to Wikipedia.) I can appreciate if the developers have a lack of experience in game development or lacked imagination in making this game as a tribute. But what really irritates me is that they seem to be more focused on peddling merchandise than giving players a decent gaming experience. They took a scrapped gaming idea from another company, failed to fulfill its potential, instead opted to copy its predecessor and even failed to do that, and then took months to release patches to make the game playable because they were probably too busy focusing on their merchandise. It's pure money making by playing off the success of a far better game, that they had absolutely nothing to do with.TLDR; This is Dungeon Keeper 2 with better graphics but lacking in [dungeon] heart. If you haven't played DK2, buy it instead. If you have, buy something else that supports developers with more imagination (usually at a lower price too). And if you bought or are planning to buy one of the character statuettes on the WftO store, you need to take a long hard look in the mirror and ask yourself "What the hell is wrong with me?"

Posted: May 27, 2016
												As a huge fan of the original Dungeon Keeper series, I was estatic when I learned about War for the Overworld. The developers made some hefty claims, but they delivered. From hiring the original voice narrator, to the look and feel of the game, this game is spot on. The minions have a lot of character, although some are sorely missed (I'm looking at you Mistress and Horny), the updated gameplay and smooth controls more than makes up for it. For anyone considering this game, if you have a sense of humor, and enjoy any combination of stragegy, god-sim, or slapping imps, this game is definitely for you.A+

content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												Overall Rating = 8.5/10  This game will remind you of Dungeon Keeper almost immediately, and does a good job of keeping things fun and interesting, but it does need more content and polishing.  However, it is still worth the purchase right now, and I'm convinced the development team is dedicated to improving the gameplay and world, especially after reading their state of the game updates.  Give these guys a chance, they really "get it" and aim to please all dungeon keepers out there.  I mean... underlords! :)What really needs improvement?-Large scale battles on large maps like the Campaign map "The Kenos" are still choppy.  The game seems to be very RAM intensive on larger maps, so efforts to correct this are very highly recommended.  I have a very high end machine with 32GB of 1600 DDR3 RAM, i7 Quad Core 3.6GHz, and 2x GeForce 780ti's in SLI, and it was choppy for me.  Most likely this has to do with how the game handles memory/processor usage.-Possession combat is wonky currently.  It's hard to really control the attacks, and you can barely tell if you used one of the creatures abilities or not.  The animations are not prominent when you attack during possession.-Need more reason to possess a creature, as currently it doesn't seem to make any difference in combat whether you possess a creature or not?-Not sure if heros or evil heros are implemented or not, but that would be a no-brainer for possession mechanics, assuming it will be in the game at all.-When building structures like pig slaughter, lair, barracks, etc.. it would be nice if there were visual queues that helped the player visually understand how much bigger their barracks needs to be to increase the army size.  If i build a 3x3, and I have a 10x10 slaughter/lair, maybe when the user mouses over the barracks, it shows them what they are missing by just having a 3x3 barracks?  You get the idea, even if maybe I used the wrong structures in my example!What would be nice to have?-I think the game needs a more elaborate sound track/sound effects, as while there is music, it's not dark and dungeony enough for my taste.  I like the current feel of the game, goofy and dark, just continue that theme with more dramatic music during attacks from dwarves, or the discovery of artifacts.  While it's cool to hear the guy say "You have discovered an artifact" maybe a prominent noise specific to artifact discover would be nice, because you tend to tune that voice out after awhile.-I'm not sure if there is a hotkey system, but if there is, make it more obvious via the tutorial.  I'd rather bind things to my own hotkeys menu, especially the rally flags for minions and beasts, and reveal fog of war ability, lightning ability, etc.-Add more randomness to digging blocks of earth.  Maybe occassionally I discover a trapped worker from a previous underlord, or a passageway to another area filled with secrets (that appeared as ROCK via reveal fog of war), or stout dwarven enemies, or neutral merchants that sell potions, whatever.  Fog of war should not be able to tell you everything you need to know before digging - add that element of surprise, as it makes the overall game mechanics of digging itself far more interesting.-Tooltips could use improvement, as when I first started placing blade lotus and defenses, it was not immediately clear to me via the game's user interface, or mouse over tips, that I needed a Foundry to provide the defensive parts to my structures.  It would be nice to recommend building a Foundry, similar to the suggestion above about adding more visual queues to gameplay/building for ease.The Final Verdict?Overall Rating = 8.5/10-This game will be great eventually, and right now it is still very good.  If you want to wait for a more polished game in a few months, you can because the development team is determined, but this game is already very playable in most cases, and is a lot of fun as is.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												For anyone who remembers at the end of Dungeons Keeper 2 watching the Reaper going out in the overworld at the end of the campaign and still sheds a tear thinking about it and those glorious days.... Look no forward! After few not really worth ideal successors here is a game that takes exactly where the gone Bullfrog left and improves it adding many more features and diversifying your arsenal. I'm just at the beginning of the game but I had to stop because tears of nostalgia were blinding me. I've finished the first few missions that introduce you to the game: you are a dungeon lord that explores a subterranean world and attracts minions and terrible creatures to work in his dungeon to search for new powerful spells or build traps and doors to protect your dungeon from rival keepers or from those awfully pretend-to-be-heroes that wants to stop you from recovering your realm. Didn't try multiplayer yet and many other features that are available other than the single campaign, but I love more the solo options, so my review even when updated in future, will reflect this.At the moment I can say I am really impressed by this game I followed through updates from the beginning of the early access and I was really waiting to install it (bought long time ago and never played as my library is quite full...).To all Dungeon Keepers fan: do not hesitate! Just remember to keep your social life alive.To all other younger players: it's a funny and easy to handle game, it's worth more than a try.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												For anyone that is a fan of the Dungeon Keeper series, this is a wonderful spiritual successor. Been playing for a long time, and they've come such a long way since early access. It plays, feels, and sounds just what I would expect a DK game to be like now. Lots of new rooms, abilities, spells, creatures - everything. There's still some slight bugginess (as of 12/16/2015) - mainly just some minor issues with the GUI (IE: if you slap a minion too fast, it will only show the animation for the first slap)Campaign is a lot of fun. It's well designed. I'm about halfway through it.I'd highly recommend this game if you're looking for a Dungeon Keeper fix.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												I really dig the whole tower defense genre. Compared to TD games, WFTO is a bit more chaotic with so many things happening in so many places - but it's a lot of fun, and unlike some TD games a single error won't ruin your whole gaming experience. There's a seemingly endless amount of possibilities how to play the game - i for one almost never used the alchemist, but focused on building prisons and torturing people to join my worthy cause.The missions (WFTO and the heart of gold expansion) are a lot of fun to play, there's also a sandbox/skirmish/multiplayer mode - however I did not find them that interesting.Overall, this is a great game and I'm looking forward to the next expansion!

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												Needs alot more polish, but as far as features goes, this game has it in spades! I'm confident this game will shine when the devs have put some more effort into it. It was released to early, but this game feels like a passion project, and that is why I believe it will eventually get to a state where it is a must have for any Dungeon Keeper fan. Every problem this game has is fixable, and beneath the bugs is a faithful spiritual successor.Pro: - Loads of features        - Great looking        - Good sound assets        - Dark humor        - A developer that cares about the community and the gameCons: - Too many bugs at this stage          - Missing tooltips          - No Bile Demons or Horned Reaper ;)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This game is a great follow up to the dungeon keeper series! Lots of new features and creatures, many things to like about it... However, this is most certainly a not quite ripe yet situation. I think as long as the devs keep regularly fixing and improving the game (ala Keen Software House) this game will be amazing. Short of that it will be another tragic effort to reproduce the game we all remember and love. I picked it up to support them in there effort and even in it's current status it's good fun. This has a lot of potential and i am looking forward to it being more polished. Buy now to support them, buy later if you want a fully finished game.

												I have yet to really get into the meat of the game given the limited time I have played it, but I would definitely agree it is a great game with a lot of potential.  As most would attest, it is the closest game to Dungeon Keeper there is right now and fans of that game should definitely consider this one.  My only complaint right now is the game always displaying on the same screen with dual monitors.  It would be nice if there were a feature in the in-game options to select the desired display for the game.  I simply project to the primary screen in order to get around this.However, game-wise, this one is definitely a winner in my book!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												This game has come a long way in the years since I played the original early access alpha. I replayed the game a few times as it was updated to get a feel for how it was progressing, and I must say I am quite impressed with the state the game is in now compared with just 6 months ago. The game is well balanced and the progression is smooth from start to finish on the campaign (and in a skirmish). It's not just feature complete but feature rich.... way more content than ANY Dungeon Keeper game ever made. And from what I understand they have plans to add even more content soon with no signs of stopping! It's almost kind of ridiculous how much work has been put into this game. The personality of the original Dungeon Keeper games is intact and further refined. This game makes me laugh out loud regularly! If you were a fan of the original Dungeon Keeper games, this game could become an obsession for you. HIGHLY HIGHLY RECCOMEND!

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												I really like this game.  It's more complicated than Dungeon II which I also really like.  I do feel that the tutorial in Dungeon II campaign is better though because it explains each little item as you go.  War for the Overworld does not do this.  For instance on Level 7 you really need to build the bombard traps and lots of them but the game does not teach you that you need foundries to get toolboxes to build defenses.  I had a lot of defenses but none of them were building so I had to watch a video online and not only did it show me that you need foundries but that you can pick up toolboxes and put them directly on the defenses to speed up their building.  The game also did not teach me how to use the screen that lists all your monsters and click on it to pick up guys.  I learned that from watching a youtube video.  On level 7 I found the lack of gold to be my biggest obstacle but using blood money and a big prison and turning all their guys into gold statues did the trick.  Infinite gold basically.  Actually it might be level 9 where you have the gold problems looking at my notes.     One problem I have with the game is that moving around on the screen does not work well with the mouse.  In Dungeons II the mouse moves around on the screen really well but in War for the Overworld you really need to use the arrow keys instead.  It works really well with the arrow keys.  Another problem is the game is a bit dark and so it's harder to see the screen.  I understand underground is supposed to be dark but I would really appreciate a little more light for visibility.  Overall the game does a really good job in that you have many minion choices from Succubus to Vampire , etc.    I guess I should be writing this review from the perspective of advertising to someone who has never played a game like this before.  In that case you build a dungeon to defeat the do gooders that come to destroy your dungeon.  You do this by carving out rooms in the underground and then putting things in them like vaults to store gold, Barracks to attract    low level monsters, Prisons to put enemies in, torture chambers for Succubi to convert them to your side or turn them into Ghosts, Beast chambers to attract beasts, etc.  Then you build an army out of these creatures to attack your enemies.  You can also use traps and doors to slow down the enemy or kill them.  All in all this is a very good game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												I really want to like this game but it just misses the mark quite badly.At first glance it feels and looks (albeit much nicer gfx) then Dungeon Keeper 2, the narrator is a nice touch along with the murky audio.However after a few hours of gameplay it all feels a bit thin, the narrator becomes far too much notifying you of every single little detail and incredibly grating. None of the minions have much personality and all seem to act the same other then scout units who, well, scout and attack from a distance. Unfortunately I have to compare to Dungeon keeper as it was claimed to be the successor to it and I will :In Dungeon Keeper 1 & 2 every minion that entered your dengeon you would carefully select or send back according to what you needed. You would pay attention to them and track their leveling up process and aim to keep them happy. In WFTO it doesnt seem to matter what enters your dungeon as you can just seem to bum rush the enemy from one end of the map to the other as soon as you have a big enough army (which really doesnt take too long), as the unlockable 'sins' or room/spell unlocks chart pretty much throws all rooms at you within 20 minutes of a skirmish game.In DK you would have to make a decision at the beginning of a game, Turtle, tech, aggressive or a mix of the 3 again, depending on the situation, sometimes rushing off to the enemy to fortify choke points and then take some time to unlock tech and build defenses, again in WFTO it really doesnt feel like it matters as long as you get enough minions in your dungeon.Lastly is the actual 'feel' of the game, and theres no real way to properly explain what I mean but WFTO just doesnt feel as kinetic and 'meaty' as DK 1 & 2 did, the units feel hollow and jittery, clipping into eachother while their audio (while very good quality) just seems to either be far to loud or too quiet and cuts off randomly.Even if I were to not compare it to DK I still would feel a tad unsatisfied as nothing seems to have been properly finished or polished off and  misses out crucial finishing touches that makes the game stand out, and instead appears flat across the board.I DO WANT TO LIKE THIS GAME, and I keep coming back to it but it is always unsatisfying to finish a session.I will not talk about stability issues (even though they plague the game and my rig is far better then required..) as that helps no one and I'm sure will ... eventually ... be ironed out.at £10 it could be worth a look but for full price, I am afraid not.(note I backed this game from the very start..)

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												Although I haven't played all that much of this game yet, due to being overly addicted to Don't Starve, I still have adored the parts that I have played. This game is blatantly the remastered version of the Dungeon Keeper series (which is an awesome franchise). You start as a newly awoken 'Underlord' (They didn't want to rip off the Overlord series). As the dungeon master, you must build and slaughter your way through the underground realms, to take over the surface.I may add more to this review once I have played more of it, but the only problem I have is the difficulty. Even in the early game, the gameplay is brutal.If you're new to the Dungeon Keeper games, I expect you will struggle a lot.Apart from that, get this game, you will (probably) not be disappointed.Highly recommended - 8.5/10

content:
Posted: September 4, 2016
												Darkest Greetings, Underlords! OMG! Time to finally get my nose out of this game long enough to give this beauty a review it so richly deserves. This has to be...No kidding...Grab a freaking snack and Lock the frickin' front door...BEST game out there! Everything that makes up 'War For The Overworld', the graphics, the music, the voices with their funny dialogs and the sound effects and noises. All of these aspects create a gloriously mythical, magical blend of delightfully fiendish evilness that I'm sure you will love! Immersive?! You bet this game is! You will forget all time and space. Remember to get comfortable, grab a snack and say 'Hi!' to the family, (or at least wavy at them) before going in-game...'Cause, you'll be in-game for a VERY LONG time! You will have love/hate relationships with every last one of these amazingly funny characters...To The Mentor, right down to the very last, lowly Minion! WFTO will soon become the crowning glory of your game collection!To everyone involved in the making of 'War For The Overworld', Many thanks for your talents! With all your combined talents, this has to be the most impressive work I've ever seen in a game!Now, back to the game. My Minions are wreaking havoc in my Dungeon as we speak!...Oh those wonderful little buggers!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Impatient, non-readers can scroll to end for TL,DRI jumped on this bandwagon about two years ago. I was excited about what they were doing and hoped beyond hope for a game that truly was more Dungeon Keeper. I participated in their discussions and made suggestions. I watched their videos and read their reports. I was all about this game... For about 6 months.In the following months, I became very bored with this game, I admit. I actually felt that things were rolling out too slowly and was concerned that I had bought in to yet another "early access" game that would actually be "forever alpha access" instead. About a year ago I uninstalled the game and moved on, chalking this up to another learning experience.Yesterday, I noticed it's full release. I have no idea why I went to their page and ultimately installed the game to try playing it again (I really had given up on it) but I guess I was bored enough? I braced myself for disappointment.I think that having so many other early access disappointments really made me far too over-harsh on this group and what they were doing. I was giggling in the first mission and I was hooked in the second. This game is exactly what they said it would be. It's DK without major publisher taint all over it. It's DK's successor.Is it perfect? Nope. No game can be. Is it broken? Nope. Everything is playable and fun. Is there a learning curve? Yep. But if you played DK, you have completed the basic tutorial. Are there bugs? Yes. And the team is already all up in that. I don't approve of people giving this game poor reviews due to the multiplayer not being in full function (at time of writing) or because their system can't handle it (I have a decent system at best and have had very little lag when my dungeon was huge) because that's not what these reviews should be about in my mind. DK was mostly single player, and the single player game is awesome. My only real complaint (and it is easy to remedy) is the voice acting for minions can be a little repetitive. Having seen where they started and looking at where they're finishing, this game did not fail at it's task. If you miss your DK and the other dungeon manager games have fallen flat, then this is what you've been waiting for. You won't be disappointed. TL,DRYes. ...What? You skipped the rest of it so I figured you wanted a short answer. Go on. Have fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												It's a rather tough call to recommend (or not recommend) this game, because personally I feel it fits kind of in the middle and much of your enjoyment will come from nostalgia.So, WFTO is essentially Dungeon Keeper 3. After a rough early access and subsequent buggy release, over 1 year later the game still has many issues, but at least the devs have listened and made improvements.That being said:- The "cursor" while stylish is still very unprecise- The game still has some bugs in it (most notably health bars of my minions keep disappearing despite the option to do so not being enabled. This is a serious issue, because the game requires you to use healing powers, so it would be great to know which minions were badly damaged)- The framerate absolutely TANKS, which is unacceptable for such a mediocre looking game. It should not hog so many resources on a powerful systemNow on to the actual review:- Graphics: As said before, the game doesn't look particularly good. It's a better DK2 with improved lighting, better models, higher resolution, flashy effects, etc. But the basic models, etc. still look like 10 years old. Let's not even talk about the animation quality. It's just comedic.- Sound: Oh, where to begin. The voice acting is SUPERB, everything else should be thrown onto a garbage pile. Combat sounds blend together into 1 big mess, while constantly being interrupted by "your minions are being slaughtered" or "xyz has died" or "your minions are rebelling", etc. And not to forget the ever present new years rocket when one of your minions levels up. Or the sound effect of your necromancer killing an enemy. OMG. Just get rid of 80% of the sound overlap or make them less annoying. It's a serious problem.- UI: It's "ok". My biggest issue is with the warbands UI. This is extremely clunky. Unit control is a nightmare in this game. I mean, you don't even have direct control, but oh my...it's just messy.- Gameplay: If you liked DK 2 you will like this one as well I guess. The game consists of separate elements.1. Excavate a proper dungeon and mine gold2. Build rooms to attract minions and do other stuff (rooms with 4 walls are more efficient I think)3. Be sure your minions have everything they need (food, beer, place to sleep more or less is all they require).This is the strategic management part of the game, which is followed by:4. Click on a banner to send all your minions, previously created warbands or a certain type of minion (e.g. beasts) to a rally flag where they will try to defeat your enemy and not get horribly murdered in the process. Your minions are♥♥♥♥♥♥stupid. Combat is chaos. Eh.5. Cast "heal" as often as your mana allows you to6. After 2 minutes "delete" the rally flag so your minions won't rebel, because they are hungry or tired or whatever (if they are still alive).Seriously, low level minions die like flies. And the only other spell I found really worth using was lightning bolt, when I was fighting enemies on my own turf, because it is cheap, does damage and stuns the target. Spells also have no cooldown. Of course there are more spells, but micromanaging spells and picking out single units in the melee is kinda not worth it. Just heal your minions or zap the enemy.Apart from that you can also "research" new rooms, spells and traps. Traps are in my opinion one of the biggest wastes of time in this game. At least in the late game. They die almost instantly to level 10 creatures, even with a fort that heals them and makes them stronger. They are also expensive and "lock" some of your mana away. Rarely worth it. Focus on doors instead. Certain minions need to be working in certain rooms in order to create traps, doors, potions, rituals, or research, etc. You get the idea. If you want these minions safe when fighting or just to resume their day to day tasks, you can assign them to a "peace band", which is fidgety as hell.Story and campaign: Since the initial release the campaign was heavily adjusted. Levels that were apparently a nightmare 1 year ago are now a pushover. I had to restart 2 levels at one point, because they caught me off guard. Apart from that the levels are really easy for the most part. They just take a while to complete usually. A difficulty selector would have worked wonders here.All in all it's a fun little game, but it's definitely something you need to really love, so you can overlook all its flaws. The bad performance and the terrible battle controls make me wonder why anyone would want to play this game in Multiplayer. Also, we have 2016, why the hell is there no auto save feature? Get it for a discount perhaps. If you really want a new Dungeon Keeper. And of course you can still possess your minions, though it doesn't seem very worthwhile to do so most of the time.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												For those who loved Dungeon Keeper, this game is for you. There are a few bugs to be worked out... and I believe the game probably should have stayed in Beta for a few months longer to work them out. It's small things really, information about units/tiles which isn't fully there, no capability for more than 2+ opponents in multiplayer/skirmish and the odd random crash due to things I'm not even sure of. These however are being worked on by the Dev's from what I can read.But the game itself is still pretty good regardless of all that I've mentioned. A plethora of minions, the voice over/game tutor with attitude, the spells and good use of the Unity engine presents the game in a very graphically pleasing way. It's a very worthy spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper that's for sure... and if like myself you still have a bad taste in your mouth from EA's attempt to milk money from the name, this should help wash it away.I'd be lying though if I would call this a "complete game". As I said earlier, it probably could've done with staying in Beta a little while longer and I have a feeling you'll feel the same if you buy this game now. That being said I would still recommend it, it is very deserving of your money, but be prepared to ignore a few incomplete aspects of the game.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												So far, I am pretty disappointed (21 hours played).  The emphasis is too much on waves of invasion.  The humour has given way to this fight, fight, fight mentality.   There is at least one other game which claims to be the natural successor to DK2.  I have it and, yes, it is an infinately better, though shorter, and much, much cheaper attemp at reincarnation of one of the best games ever dropped by a developer after buying the franchise.And, no, my memory of DK2 does not let me down, I have it running in Dos Box. I would not have purchased this game if I had realised that I would be fighting at least 95% of the time.  Worse, the messaging system swamps the player but allows no time to actually read and respond.If you enjoy games with the emphasis on fire-fighting then this is probably a reasonable game.  If you enjoy planning and building and strategy, then, this will not be for you.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												When I first purchased this game I had little hopes of it ever becoming a complete game with a full campaign. Honestly I hadn't even had it installed beyond the point of the first couple weeks.  Recently I have been pleasantly surprised. Not only has the game been given a campaign with a decent story but it did an excellent job leaving us off for further story (which I hope is on its way) Hours of great game play, good story, versatility and control over your dungeons population, a wide varriety of creatures, spells, defenses and rooms. lastly, a mode in which you can personally challenge yourself after you have beaten the story of the current game. Cons      - Whan your dungeon population starts getting a bit higher the game starts running a touch clunky (my pc specs are pretty decent)     - Units will sometimes get stuck on the edges objects in a room. This does not occur often enough for it to cause any considerable grief.Fully recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed DK2 in years passed.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												Everything I had hoped for and more!First off: I'm a very old fan of the original Dungeon Keeper series from Bullfrog - so many games that have been called "Dungeon Keeper clones" or spiritual sequels have just not lived up to the hype, so when this game came out, I was skeptical.Despite this, I do admit to buying Early Access when the game consisted of nothing but square digging and imp slapping. I bought it, set it aside, and waited for the release message to check it out.This is one of the very few games coming out of Early Access that truly realized their potential. It has everything - the exploration, the dungeon building, a large variety of creatures with different looks and likes/dislikes, in depth magic and room progression trees, and - of course - the ability to slap your imps. 10/10 would back again.
