content:
Posted: April 4
												It has good humour, unique voice acting where narrator tries to interact with player and talk about player's actions. Random quotes. Story is not that good, because of that game still doesn't suffers since it offers amazing gameplay over the story. Each gamemodes offer different experience.You freely can build and manage your own dungeon as your dark heart desires. You can also play in first person by possessing a minion and looking at your dungeon up close. See what your minion sees.Level editor is easy to use, sadly you can't do anything advanced with it. Only simple Skirmish maps so far that i figured.Multiplayer experience is not the best. I'd say it's around average. Game is pretty stable if you're not playing Skirmish with 3 AI. AI is pretty good sadly it can make the game lag if there is more than 1 AI in the Skirmish match. Game's optimization is good (not counting AI)Now Coop experience is not really good as saying "COOP" it means you and your friend can fight against AI in Skirmish match or against the Empire (Enemies that wander around the map)Game only offers best Singleplayer experience and average to sometimes boring Multiplayer experience.So far i recommend this game for those who wants  good Singleplayer game. As for those who's looking for a good game to play with your friends then i wouldn't really recommend this unless you and your friend wants  simple Coop, Multiplayer experience by just managing, building your own Dungeon together and attacking the Empire once you get bored. Or picking a fight against AI.Game design is beautiful and improved quite a lot.Reviewed patch 1.5 and 1.6

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Fantastic follow-up to Dungeon Keeper 2 with the same style and charm with just enough new stuff thrown in there to make it worth your while. The game is buggier than it should be at launch, I'll admit, and some stuff just feels a little rough, animations, some of the options, but it's also a hell of a lot of fun for anyone who enjoyed Dungeon Keeper 2 and was looking for a game to follow in its footsteps. If you're hesistant, it may be best to wait for some patches, but the developers are very vocal on the fourms and the entire development process has been so transparent I would have no problems recommending this game even in its current state. It's certainly playable, and the plans for future content are exciting.

												One of those games I regret buying at full price...Its a clean, polished game that requires some thinking and strategy but why the hate you ask well I played Dwelvers (Incomplete game, Dev can no longer support) Its very much the same game but has so much more depth to it. content:
Posted: March 10
												A decent game overall, but the UI just gets in the way of my enjoyment. Everything is either awkward, unintuitive, or oversized. It's really jarring coming from playing games like Factorio or Rimworld, where the UI is less intrusive.The use of unbreakable rock in the campaign is suffocating compared to the original dungeon keeper. I have extremely little choice of where to put my rooms.Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game unless you are a die-hard dungeon keeper fan.EDIT (after developer replied):Let me be clearer of what I meant.- The "hand" cursor is about 5 times bigger than I want. But no way to choose a smaller hand.- The shape of the hand makes clicking small things really painfully tedious. Example: I try to dismiss the (very small) event notifications on the right and the all the the fingertip has to be off the screen to get the right spot, but if I get it a little bit off, I scroll the screen to the right.- I can't make the bulky UI less bulky without also making the keybinding text in the controls screen too small to read.- The original dungeon keeper has really easy to understand though bubbles that appeared above creatures heads. Now, the though bubbles are really small and indistinguishable unless I zoom right in on the creature.- No way to configure the sensitivity for how quickly mouse wheel zooms in and out- Map large map to survey what's going on (like dungeon keeper). All I have is a pixelated thing in the bottom left, which gives me little help. I want a full screen, high res overview of what's going on.- The "Warband" mechanism is really opaque. I spent 15 minutes trying to figure out how it works. I still haven't found a use for it that is worth the tedium of setting it up. If I want to see what creatures are in a warband, I get these extremely hard to recognise (and small, because I reduced UI scale, because otherwise the UI is taking up 1/4 of my screen). This isn't starcraft or red alert groups. Nowhere near that simple.- What's the point of "replacement earth" when, after being fortified, the enemy can still dig through it? Might as well just make a door.- On the first level with the dwarves: I have to essentialy keep my minions on a constant state of being rallied because the enemy apparantly pull limitless soldiers out of their asses to throw at me. This leads to the announcer droning on and on and on about X creature is unhappy because of Y. This starts to get boring fast, as there's nothing I can really do about it.Summary: the developers have a lot of good ideas and have come closest than others in trying revisit the good things in Dungeon Keeper. But they have a long, long, way to go when it comes to quality-of-life features, UI design and making gameplay mechanics intuitive. I stand by my thumbs down.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2016
												This game is cute, charming, and polished.Why the thumbs down, then, you ask?The answer is that the game, while cute, lacks strategic depth and is not worth the $30 price point. The rooms are unbalanced and there is a clear setup to spam in order to win every game. The maps and scenarios are not varied enough to feel like a new game each time. It leverages upon nostalgia for dungeon builders past and does not substantially innovate. There are some QoL issues: for example, feedback loops are tenuous and it is not always clear why a dungeon inhabitant is unhappy.I think that this game may become worth it at the $15-20 price point, since it was quirky and kept me entertained for a little while. If you're into this sort of game, I would recommend waiting for a sale.

Posted: April 3, 2015
												I like how Richard Ridings returned as the dungeon mentor and it returned with telling us we should be asleep when it is a specific time. Now I do recommend this game, for the moment, for those who mainly just want to experience Dungeon Keeper again.However, no game is complete w/ out bugs. Don't worry, you get plenty of them hiding around the corner. And no game is complete w/ out flaws as well. That being the minimap. It tends to be hard to figure out where the enemies are coming from if you have a hard time seeing their position on the minimap. When the dungeon mentor doesn't say anything it makes it harder. There are only 3 skirmish maps and both are small (only 2 players per map). And I don't know if anyone else ha a problem with it but I personally feel there are too many gold tiles and many of which are in large chunks and appear too often in unconvenient spots so it seems as though the game is trying to force you to stick with 3x3 rooms or have a dungeon thats just one big cluster ♥♥♥♥ of rooms that aren't separated. I like to build larger rooms to spawn more minions from that room rather than having to keep building the same room over and over.If you can look pass the flaws of the game, then I would recommend it. If you can't... well... come back later.

content:
Posted: March 10
												Dungeon Keeper is a simple concept. Give us lots of creatures and room types, give us a huge dungeon to build out and customize until our evil hearts are content. Give us interesting enemies to strategically invade and battle. It is literally that simple. Every mission in this game drops you into a dungeon that is already carved out, or is full of water, or is full of lava, or blocks you at every turn with impassable walls, or sends stream after stream of enemies at you that can easily break through your fortified walls so you can't funnel them and get strategic with your defenses. You can't place water tiles (that i know of) and you can't even rebuild a dirt wall without paying gold if you accidentally carved a section out incorrectly and want to fix it. There was no mission where I really got to customize my dungeon and train my army of minons the way I wanted to. There is an absolutely dire mission where you simply guide necromancers around the same looking hero dungeon forever that is one of the dullest experiences I have ever had in a video game. As a massive Dungeon Keeper fan, I appreciate the attempt here, the rooms and creature designs are cool. Graphics are nice. I simply can't recommend this for $30-$45 dollars.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												I'm a long time player of Dungeon Kepper 1 & 2...and am old enough to remember the thrill of loading these games for the first time.Although I've been a supporter of this project since they first started, well before when they had a different team and a different goal, the amount of progress these absolutely hardcore lovers of DK have made is quite astonishing.  This game is stonking amazing...it literally is the third coming of Dungeon Keeper.I've been a backer, but I honestly only played occasionally, feeling that it would be best to play when the game was pretty much feature complete and also since I don't have much time to bugtest it made the best sense for me.  I am absolutely THRILLED at what they've done here...what they have managed to accomplish.I have played up until the 5th mission in campaign as well as some putzing around in the other modes for several hours (30+), and I can truly say that this has been the time of my life.  The heart and soul of DK is there.  Yes, sure, there's a few bugs and glitches, but this is a massive undertaking that they've done here and the end result is quite simply astonishing.  It looks brilliant, and the humor is there.I experienced zero crashes and very few bugs on my playthrough today.  I played about 4 hours straight and had an absolute blast.I've enjoyed checking out every room and looking at the tiniest details in each of their design.  Posession is quite fun and reveals the amount of work put into each of the models and objects.  It's exquisite.I have absolutely no doubt that given a month or so, a ton of the early bugs will be squashed. This developer team is hardcore committed to making this project a success and you can see it everywhere.If you're a fan of the original DK, or are looking for a game where it's good to be bad, please check this out.  It is quite simply a load of fun with an immense level of detail that puts other games to shame.  This is truly an incredible job they've done and they deserve a swift pat on the back for what they've accomplished.Buy it!

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Before I post this, I backed the game on Kickstarter and bought it on two separate accounts. I wanted to love this game, I was very enthused about it, I initially gave it positive reviews and decided to wait and give it a chance to be patched.But now several months in the game lacks a Pet Dungeon mode and the Sandbox Mode is a poor substitute because it has no missions, no objectives, and no real sense of progression. It didn't even have a hero gate on the maps I checked. It seems like a step in the right direction but if nothing more is ever made of it, it's an inadequate half step.The Campaign initially struck me as promising until I noticed that it's full of pre-fab rooms and rushes you to finish and basically punishes the player for trying to  lovingly hand carve a dungeon.Aside from that it's not bad, but months after launch I had hoped it would be more of a spiritual successor than it actually is. Dungeons 2 is actually a closer spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2 than War for the Overworld is, and it has multiple factions to play as, so if it comes down to a choice between War for the Overworld and Dungeons 2 for DK2 fans I'd suggest buying Dungeons 2 instead.I'll change my recommendation later if they add a Pet Dungeon equivilent and revise the Campaign maps to be more about crafting a dungeon and less about capturing rooms and rushing, but for now, I give it a thumbs down on the grounds that this isn't as much like Dungeon Keeper 2 as it appears on the surface. Once you dig past the surface, it's a very different game, and a bit of a letdown.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												Where to begin.. I started playing Dungeon Keeper 2 around 2001 and after that every few years i installed it for the nostalgia trip and last year was the first time i completed Dungeon Keeper 2 but my thirst for evilness was not quenched so i started to look around for alternative games and i fell on this, first i was bombarded with negative reviews but after looking further i found out that the game did the foolish move to release it in a very buggy, featureless state and sadly some big YouTubers started hammering on it.But that was 1 or 2 years ago, today this game is a fully functional true successor to Dungeon Keeper 2 which can almost win the title "Dungeon Keeper 3" if it wasn't EA who holds the copyright to this game and decides to turn it into a freemium cash machine... Few highlights:♦ Exact same controls and features as Dungeon Keeper 2 (Exception with the Casino, RIP Disco Inferno)♦ Further expands on DK2's existing features with new elements such as Rituals, Beasts, more magic, more rooms and more evilness overal♦ DLC with parts of the DLC being offered for free!♦ THE ORIGINAL MENTOR VOICE FROM DUNGEON KEEPER 2 IS BACK, RICHARD RIDINGS♦ Did i mentioned the awesome voice of Richard Ridings?♦ The humor is still there although a bit less up-front, still funny though♦ Richard Ridings♦ Developers are active on Discord to answer all your questionsOh and a important note, if you are a LAN party enthusiast i suggest you look up the DRM Free version on their site, you pay a bit more but you get both the Steam version + DRM free version.So yeah! On a scale of 1 to 10 with 1 being a game i would play just for the gimmicks that has it to a 10 that is just worth the money, is unique, has developers love to it and stands out as a truely unique game (besides being a successor) then i give this game a:8 out of 10 for being addictive, funny, loads of content, has many different techniques you can try, fully voiced campaign with story (which are now 2 if you count Heart of Gold) with a minus point for the UI that is too clunky and large with too much information and another one off for sometimes being overwhelming for either sudden wall breaches or having minions who just don't do their damn job like the cultists or beast masters.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2016
												Right so, 13h into the game and this is included in a small follow up of the game since it was beta. Now the game is fully released and is still getting updates with content and all. +1 for the devs. Must be one of 5 games that I decided to preorder in last 5 years and only one I havent missed by preordering, and now to explain why:I am (was) and avid Dungeon Keeper 2 player. It was a game that I was returing to years after years even after I've tried a lot of games that tried (Dungeons which were, Overlord which was fun after all). Humor of DK2, animations all played into the game including the masterfully done voice acting of dungeon advisor. THESE GUYS MANAGED TO GET THE SAME GUY TO VOICE DUNGEON ADVISOR IN WftO!!!! When I bought (preordered) the game there was no advisor to begin with, you can imagine my inner schoolgirl screams when I heard his voice along with all the comments that gave the game that "extra" I wanted in it.Unfortunatelly my job (where I travel a lot) prevents me of playing what I want when I want, but this will be the game I will return to for singleplayer if not multi. Game has a lot features, it's easy to learn if you ever played DK or DK2, some mechanics are different but all the new mechanics (like Aspects of Evil) are a positive and nice tactical change in the game that affects MP games (think of C&C Generals by picking general, but you can unlock all in due time, but that takes, well, time). Characters look great, visuals are superb, traps, imps, slaps, this game has all!it gets solid 9.5/10. For 10/10 it misses casino and Disco Inferno when monster wins jackpot!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
												For a Dungeon Keeper 2 inspired game, this game copies all the basics and systems. That in itself is a very functional and entertaining system of base building, mining and unit control. However, the port of these things is where the good of this game ends. For starters, the minions do look very uninspired, they lack the fiendish extravagence and undertone of comical wickedness and pure unadulterated evil. Secondly, there are entirely too many different creatures. Some even more useless than the other. There are so many different creatures that roam that the map quickly becomes a mess of creatures in combat or stuck behind doors because the AI is absolutely terrible and because except for the few specific purpose rooms, tons of units overlap in their uses, and if you fight a couple battles and have no interest in dwarven basic soldiers, you'll soon see 60 invisible ghosts flying around the map too.There many different features that could've just been condensed. Why are there two different types of lairs? There is literally no good reason why beasts and 'sentients' have the need for different rooms to sleep in. Why are there two rooms for eating? Why are there many different types of constructs, spells, potions and other magical things, a lot of which perform the same exact effect/purpose or at least overlap in their uses with other spells, potions, buffs or rooms. There is a tech tree forced down your throat because the designers of this game probably felt artificially adding progression is a thing gamers of this genre crave. All of the features that could have been condensed have individual points here, which you gain by putting cultists in a library(or letting them go there naturally, probably the only thing the AI manages to do decently, it can't even keep a group of minions fighting without a few of them standing around staring or just blatently walking past the enemies and attacking a building).I really tried to give this game a shot. I didn't even name all the issues this game has, I just lack motivation to write anything more on this waste of time and I haven't even gone past something like mission 6 and who knows how much more rehashed ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is beyond that. Here's to hoping I can still get my money back.

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Before I post this, I backed the game on Kickstarter and bought it on two separate accounts. I wanted to love this game, I was very enthused about it, I initially gave it positive reviews and decided to wait and give it a chance to be patched.But now several months in the game lacks a Pet Dungeon mode and the Sandbox Mode is a poor substitute because it has no missions, no objectives, and no real sense of progression. It didn't even have a hero gate on the maps I checked. It seems like a step in the right direction but if nothing more is ever made of it, it's an inadequate half step.The Campaign initially struck me as promising until I noticed that it's full of pre-fab rooms and rushes you to finish and basically punishes the player for trying to  lovingly hand carve a dungeon.Aside from that it's not bad, but months after launch I had hoped it would be more of a spiritual successor than it actually is. Dungeons 2 is actually a closer spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper 2 than War for the Overworld is, and it has multiple factions to play as, so if it comes down to a choice between War for the Overworld and Dungeons 2 for DK2 fans I'd suggest buying Dungeons 2 instead.I'll change my recommendation later if they add a Pet Dungeon equivilent and revise the Campaign maps to be more about crafting a dungeon and less about capturing rooms and rushing, but for now, I give it a thumbs down on the grounds that this isn't as much like Dungeon Keeper 2 as it appears on the surface. Once you dig past the surface, it's a very different game, and a bit of a letdown.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												The game has a very interesting premise, but it falls flat because of the interface.  The developers have obviously wasted quite a bit of time on fancy models and graphics but not enough on UI design.  The UI makes even simple tasks quite difficult to accomplish the worst offender being that they replace your mouse cursor with a fancy animated hand that you can never tell quite what is being pointed at without waiting for the cursor highlighting to catch up.  The scale on which things happen also tends to make things difficult.  The overall map is quite large relative to the individual unit and the player base is required to be somewhat large to support any decent number of units and the units themselves are quite tiny.  Zoom in to issue orders to units and you cant navigate the map as easily, zoom out to navigate and you cant issue orders as effectively; there is no zoom level where you can effectively do both.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												War For The Overworld is a real time strategy game, very similar to Dungeon Keeper, both from a gameplay and atmosphere point of view.You view your dungeon from a top down perspective, drag-select tiles to order your imps to dig space for you to construct rooms, which attracts various types of monsters through a portal. Give them food and a place to sleep, train them to improve combat skills, and then send them out to kill the heroes. Some minions can research spells or construct traps. You can hold captured enemies in a prison, torture them to convert them to your cause, or let them die so their corpses can turn into undead minions at a graveyard.There's a fun, dark sense of humour, especially thanks to the advisor, who is the same voice actor from Dungeon Keeper. As a fan of DK, it really does feel like everything I'd want to see from an unofficial sequel.I wish I could end the review there with a positive recommendation. Unfortunately, my enjoyment of WFTO has been spoiled by terrible technical performance. I've suffered from two significant problems.The first is a very frequent "stutter", where everything freezes for about a second. Its not game breaking, but it is very annoying, especially when you're moving the camera around the map.The second - and far more serious - problem, is a progressively worsening framerate, which seems to be related to how much of the map you can see, and how many creatures and traps are active in the map. At the start of a level, everything is covered by the fog of war, so my framerate is a nice smooth 60. But as I explore, the more of the map I uncover, and the more creatures are recruited by myself and the enemy, the framerate starts to die. It doesn't seem to be related to any graphics option - I've got the same problem with every setting at maximum and every setting at minimum. The engine just can't cope with so many moving objects in such a large space.There are 13 levels in the campaign, and as you would expect, the later maps are larger and everybody has a bigger army. During the first half of the campaign the framerate hit isn't so bad, dipping to around 40, which is still playable. But from around level 8, it got much worse, at times being almost like a powerpoint slideshow. I'm not exaggerating when I say my framerate was dipping into single figures.I have a significantly more powerful PC than the recommended specs listed on the store page (Win7 64 bit, Quad core i7 2600k @ 3.4Ghz, 8GB Ram, GTX 770 with 4GB Vram) so I should be able to run this kind of game without a problem. A quick search on the forum and other reviews indicates I'm not alone.Ultimately, in the current state, I have no choice but to give a negative review. Its a shame, because judging by the gameplay alone, WFTO is a good game. But this level of performance is unacceptable. Wait a few months, see if the developers can improve the performance with some patches. (Note: I started playing the day AFTER patch 1.1.15 was released, so 1.1.15, which supposedly improved performance, is still terrible).

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												The game has a very interesting premise, but it falls flat because of the interface.  The developers have obviously wasted quite a bit of time on fancy models and graphics but not enough on UI design.  The UI makes even simple tasks quite difficult to accomplish the worst offender being that they replace your mouse cursor with a fancy animated hand that you can never tell quite what is being pointed at without waiting for the cursor highlighting to catch up.  The scale on which things happen also tends to make things difficult.  The overall map is quite large relative to the individual unit and the player base is required to be somewhat large to support any decent number of units and the units themselves are quite tiny.  Zoom in to issue orders to units and you cant navigate the map as easily, zoom out to navigate and you cant issue orders as effectively; there is no zoom level where you can effectively do both.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5
												Did you ever play Dungeon Keeper 1 or 2? Did you enjoy them? Then you should own this game. Would you still play those games if they weren't so old that compatibility issues prevent them from running? If that's you, you should be buying this game. Right now. Go, do it! Okay, finish reading this review, then go do it. Don't make me backhand you with the Hand of Evil.This isn't a typical RTS; it's a God Game. I don't know how best to describe it because I describe any game with this game's mechanics as "like Dungeon Keeper". This is basically Dungeon Keeper 3, but that doesn't mean it's basic. Did you ever see the promo for Dungeon Keeper 3 way back when? Uh huh, these devs really know Dungeon Keeper. In fact, I am amazed at how often they respond to reviews - both positive and negative - which certainly was a big factor in encouraging me to write a review.PLAY THE CAMPAIGN! It will teach you about your minions and rooms, spells, etc. in a very logical way. The game is different enough, just as Dungeon Keeper 1 and 2 were very different from each other. In my opinion, Dungeon Keeper 2 was vastly superior to the first one. Expect that kind of improvement again with this one.Pros:The in-game help is really impressive. Click on anything and have a spoken (and written) explanation.Create your own maps. Multi-player. Single player vs. an intelligent enemy AI.Still receiving updates. New content continues to come out. + Bug fixes and improvements.It's really funny. It's funny, dark humor without being lewd. The guide is the same voice talent as the previous games, witty, snarky, and oh so articulate and proper.The game can be slowed down and sped up.Some notes on performance:The game runs much better with 8GB of RAM instead of 4GB.I have played a level in the new My Pet Dungeon content twice. The second run began to stutter every few seconds. As feedback, on the second run, I used volcanic bridge a WHOLE lot more, covering whole areas.The game stutters a bit when it first loads into the main menu. Also, the game and mouse will freeze for a few moments when loading a level. Obviously, these don't affect the game, but they feel out of place. The hardware cursor never gets frozen.Cons:There are no cons. The game is great. However, there are some things that could be improved. Many things that would have been listed here were addressed in the recent 1.6 patch.Documentation! Some information is seemingly impossible to find. I've tried to find information on the Veins of Evil (the tech tree). I can see that they at one point were named and had different buffs a you went further in each. They also seem to affect total mana. However, I have seen nothing about this in-game. I see over the course of a level that my mana increases, but I'd like to know the pattern to see if I'm doing something inefficiently.The new 1.6 patch greatly improved possession. I didn't know that my cultists and beastmasters could heal other minions! That certainly changes the way that I will balance warbands.A minion will slow down when the cursor is on them, but it is still difficult to get information about them. It would be wonderful if there was a box that showed very detailed information about a minion if it were perhaps being held.The minimap could use some improvements. When the cursor is on a room, details are given about the entire room, so clearly the game understands that those tiles together form a single room, no matter the shape or size. It would be WONDEFUL if there were a transparent icon or something on the minimap to show me which of my rooms are where.The UI is actually pretty powerful. It would be nice to know how efficient healing a group is by it's icon, but the many things the UI allows you to do are pretty useful. There are a ton of keybinding for the UI, but they are all in relation to each other by position, which changes. That's fine. However, it would be SO helpful if the current keybind for that position was listed in the corner of the icon.Lastly, some of the room could use a little sprucing up. The spirit chamber in particular looks very bland, especially when compared to something like the sanctuary.But feedback aside, the game is wonderful. I highly recommend it. I would certainly continue to purchase DLC containing further campaigns.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access ReviewBelow is my review of the Early Access build.  Left it here as it seems to be the right thing to do.Brilliant game, highly recommened if you love Dungeon Keeper, but just as a caution its still in alpha/beta phase so only buy if your willing to cope with bugs and some missing features.  However the game at the moment does have a few sandbox maps to play on, which is always a good thing.The game is also being constantly updated, and from what I can see they could make this a final release if they wanted, and the developers also coinstantly update their fans every Wednesday.Final Release reviewBelow you'll find the review of the final version of the game.Pros+ Plays a lot like Dungeon keeper 2+ Runs fairly well on lower end hardware+ Brilliant voice acting+ Visuals are pretty good+ Not published by EA+ No Asset flippingCons- Still a few minor bugs and glitches here and there- Long loading times (This may be my system though)- A few frame rate issues here and there. OverallThis is the Dungeon Keeper we wanted.  Something that EA could never provide.  While the game does indeed have its issues and some frame rate problems, it is highly recommended and with the sales coming up soon you might even be able to pick this up really cheap.At its core its Dungeon Keeper, with a lot more.  After playing a few missions in the campaign I found the game is a lot faster paced than Dungeon Keeper 2, but it isn't bad in fact its quite exciting.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												I bought this game hoping that it would be as advertised, a spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper.  What I got, however, was a twitchy fascimile that prevents me from enjoying the game.  I think they did great by bringing in the VA who narrated DK 1 and 2.  Humor was there, sorta...  The gameplay devolves into a frantic rally and heal spam all through the game, and that's where it gets ♥♥♥♥♥♥.  The best part of a game like this is building up your dungeon while defending it, steathily scouting for the most opportune spot to strike.  No where is this less likely than level eleven, where four underlords attack you, (I know it's three, but ♥♥♥♥ the devs for trying to make two dungeonhearts a single opponent.)  It's all spam rally, spam heals, over and over.  I was on the last dungeonheart before I just turned the game off in disgust.  Apparently I also own the expansion, it was money wasted, in my opinion.  I'm going over to GoG and getting Dungeon Keeper from a dev who did it right.

												I'm a die-hard fan of Dungeon Keeper so obviously I wanted the game that claims is it's successor to be similar but War for the Overworld has too many changes to grasp. Especially with habits from previous Dungeon Keeper that don't work here. (fortified walls giving more room efficiency for example, though Devs claim they plan on fixing this here in WftO) You need a reflex and divided attention of a NASA robot to win rounds. Other people might like this game more. I definitely don't. And I'd still rather play Dungeon Keeper 2 despite its age than this.

number of helpful: 12 of 24 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I bought this game in 2013 apparently and since the have not played it while patiently waiting for the developers to finish it.While they did add a lot of rooms, spells, traps, sounds and a voiceover since then... it still feels unpolished.Personally i've got several issues that persisted through every version of the game:1) Cursor is hard to use. Yes, you are reading it right - the cursor. They made it look like a finger from an original game, unfortunately as far as using it in the game it somehow became harder, probably due to increased resolution. Clicking on stuff is mostly "hit and miss" situation since the active part of the cursor is just the fingertip. Combine that with the fact that you have to click directly on the stuff, like treasure chests and tiny imps - you've got yourself an annoying issue.2) Tooltips. Many reviewers already mentioned that they do not make any sense whatsoever and its true - instead of clear information about rooms its just some strings with numbers and abbreviations.3) UI. There is no way to soften the blow - its horrible in every possible way. The buttons are too small. The cursor is too big and hard to use (read 1). The minimap (again, made to resemble an original DK minimap) is completely useless and would've been appropriate in the year 95 - Microsoft paint blocks instead of actual rooms and enemies just won't cut in 2015.4) I've expected that with time and better optimization the game would demand less PC resources but unfortunately the opposite has happened. So just a heads up - you really DO need 6-8gb and more, as well as good CPU.Unfortunately the game has not met my expectations yet (in the basic controls department at least) and i've waited quite a bit already. I might change my mind later on, if the developer updates the UI though.

												I really really really want to like this game.  When it works, it's fun and provides the DK style of gameplay.  The problem is the game just doesn't work.  Worker AI is consistently broken, they ignore the blockers and run where ever they want.  There's no real good way to direct their priorities. content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												It's clear that these Devs love Dungeon Keeper, and really do have talent. This game does have the chance to truly claim the title as the spiritual successor to DK2. But as of the release, it's not there. There is still so much that is only placeholders, a bit of stability issues, difficulty is all over the place (AI in particular), and it really is one of the LEAST intuitive games I've ever played. Even mucking about in the sandbox and I've not even an idea how to find my minion cap. The free skirmish currently only has 3 maps, all 1v1 and horribly small even for that. This game was NOT ready for release. And it won't be for some time. When it is, I'll update my review to say so.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												This game has come a long way but it is NOT a finished product. For instance, I can't load any saved games. I save the game and it seems to happen successfully but when I go to load from a previous save it just isn't there. this makes the game completely unplayable for me. I am not going to start from the very beginning every time I want to play, having to redo the tutorial over and over again. Not happening. While it is a great game that shows a TON of promise it should have never been released in this state. It is beta material. It feels like they are completely misrepresenting the state of the game by selling it in it's current state as a finished product.***EDIT***After a little more fiddling it appears that when Steam is in online mode the game is still saving games locally so after it saves the game and you try to load it it is bypassing the local game saves and only looking at the saves on Steam Cloud. After taking Steam offline I found the saved game I made while Steam was in online mode. Seems like a bug? A pretty big %$@ bug to have AFTER release you think?So to those individuals having this issue you will just have to take Steam into offline mode to play for now until they fix the issue.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Honestly, I'm not very satisfied with this game. I'm about four missions in, and it is essentially the same game Dungeon Keeper was with a graphical overhaul. Feels almost like it's running the exact same engine with higher resolution textures.It's been about 18 years since Dungeon Keeper came out, but War for the Overworld plays essentially the same as it's predecessor. Games have changed and improved quite a bit in that time, but WFTO is stuck in the past.The Good:Same quirky atmosphere you likely enjoyed with Dungeon Keeper. Simple, casual gameplay. Nice voice acting. A pleasant way to spend a few hours.The Bad:AI is generally clunky and bad on both sides. Your minions are not very bright, but neither is the enemy.Many maps are so full of caverns and holes that you can't really design a dungeon the way you want it to look. The map forces your hand in most cases. Combat is a complete mobfest, and usually involves dropping everthing and the kitchen sink onto your enemies heads, spamming heals and shooting some lightening. There is no strategy required.The Verdict:Did you like Dungeon Keeper? Do you want to play it again with unit reskins and higher resolution graphics? If so, then sure, grab this game. If you want a deep and strategic dungeon building game then you will have wait because this isn't it and nobody has made it yet.

												Diffculty for the levels are so easy its boring. Creatures just run to my core and die, or my creatures are 4-6 levels ahead of the empire/other underlords. There needs to be a difficulty mode implemented for players that like a challenge. Also the level designs are somewhat discouraging to futher me wanting to play more. Every single level just has water/lava/small corridors/impentrable rocks everywhere so I'm not allowed to make my dungeon how I'd prefer to make it. The empire traps are very weak, the crossbow you see on the 2nd/3rd level are very inaccurate. It lands a shot 10% of the time. I could go on but you get the just of how a veteran Dungeon Keeper 2 player forms his opinion of WftO as of its current state on patch 1.2. In comparison to this campaign levels/design to DK2, DK2 is better in most aspects, even the difficulty - DK2 had a very casual player difficulty campaign, but there were some maps atleast that even casual players had a time beating. Unlike yours truly. Another side note is the Vein of Evil - The spells you get are so imbalanced, can destroy entire armies just by spamming certain spells in a corridor because there are no cooldowns and do too much aoe damage.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Alright, here we go. If you've played the original Bullfrog Dungeon Keeper and/or Dungeon Keeper 2, then let me just say, this is it, this is what we've been waiting for (and if you haven't played them then skip to the later part of the review). WFTO *IS* truely, more than anything else has ever been, the spiritual successor to the Dungeon Keeper franchise. Its made by DK fans, for DK fans. Don't hesitate (well maybe, see my next point first), just buy the game and play it. Now, before I continue, I must concede that yes, there have been a number of major bugs since release. HOWEVER, the game is most certainly release ready, enjoyable and playable. Many of these bugs have been related to the campaign, cutscenes etc, however the majority of these have already been fixed. The development team are fully committed and have been doing a great job. There will always be bugs on release, especially for a small indie team like this, you cant get around that. Even major publishers often have bugs on release, sometimes massive ones, and they have millions to spend. If you've played the game for two hours, encountered one bug, and called it a bad, incomplete game, you really don't deserve to be writing a review. In a few hours you've played 2, 3 levels? Get some perspective. Almost all of the bugs people have talked about in the negative reviews were fixed within 24 hours of release. So look within yourself, and if you're the kind of person who is extremely nitpicky about their games, and can't handle a few little bugs or a couple of placeholder texts, then fine, just wait a month, they'll be gone. For me, that's certainly not worth giving a bad review over. As someone who has been waiting for this game for almost 5 years, I'm completely satisified with it. Now, for people who haven't played the original Dungeon Keeper games, then you've never played anything like this. Really. The DK games, and now WFTO, are a genre in themselves, once which hasn't truely been seen for 14 years since DK2. Its a mash up of the RTS and God Game genres, with elements of RPG thrown in. Its like mixing a classic RTS like Age of Empires or Warcraft, with something like Sim City or Sim Theme Park, and then throwing in rudimentary elements of an RPG.So it's Sim Age of Diablo, you ask? That's hard to imagine, what do you actually do?Well, you start by building a dungeon, you mine out caverns and hallways around your dungeon core. Then you fill them with different rooms, attract hordes of monsters, minions and beasts into your employment, make them train and work, construct traps and defences, explore and expand your territory throughout the map and ultimately use your army of creatures to destroy the enemy, be it the forces of good, or a rival Underlords dungeon.  There's far more to it than that, but you'll have to play it to see. 10/10, fully recommend.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												As of 1.0.144/6/2014Going to wait for game to be polished a bit better. The game itself is good, but bugs, lack of proper tooltips, and omg memory leaks. I have 16g of ram and on lvl 4 of campain it ate 8g then crashed. Building: Tutorial says 3x3 minimum for builds, but doesn't say if 3x4 is better or a waste of space. 6x6 adds another device so one would have to conclude 3x3 or 3x6 or it's wasted space. Rooms don't need walls so rip it all down except your chokepoint to enemy.Minion AI: lol, have a full 6x9 slaughter pen and a empty 3x3 pen and minions are afraid of starving to death. Workers don't multitask, they all tear down walls or they all convert blocks or they all mine gold (even if gold is capped..lol) or they all sit idle.Scout beasts engage enemy instead of scouting.Tool tips: Some are still displaying script descriptions. Most that are working have data stretched horizontaly so it goes 1/4 to 1/2 way across screen. Most info is irrelevant and needed info is no where to be found.Hand and Camera: [del] key for camera tilt movement...really? that key should be to get rid of unwanted worker that was summoned over cap thats costing mana. Screen edge movement is good, but hard to hit minimize button in left hand corner.As with all rts type games, camera does not scroll out far enough. (Curse you Warcraft 3 for starting that crap.)Enemy AI: lol, healers heal themselves or attack instead of healing the tank. Assasins chase a goblin accross map instead of staying with battle group. Dwarves think they are tanks. Tanks spin around and around till they are dead not knowing who to hit.Traps: What traps? Death blosson is just a wall. Cannons are defense not a trap. It needs traps that do damage once to an unsuspecting mob.Models: Other than the fact that they are all carbin copies (no unique faces, racial pigment or even hair color) The humanoids look good for the most part, but monsters look like a 2000 game (see Sacrifice by interplay). Succubus have wings BTW, do it right or call them S&M chicks. None of the models have a WOW that is cool feel except Shades.Textures: Heh, didn't I already tear down this group of walls? Oh this one is fortified, see the grey smudge on top....really? Water looks like brown poluted water from a city sim game. Madel textures are minimal and not very detailed.Concusion: Dungeon game? No it is a tower defense game that also lets you attack their tower after you get a zerg army together. So far this isn't even a diamond in the ruff, it is a turd with sugar sprinkled on it. Why everyone is so fixated with a 1997 game? Dungeon Keeper was good but expand on it. If you could combine Dungeons(Kalypso) with this game it would be good start. They both had a good thing, but to many want to play DK and DK2. Have it so you keep what you build and expand out into the world taking territory. Whats the point in building a dungeon to not have invaders?At this time I can not recomend this game. Will try again in a month...maybe.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I'm very sad, about the fact that I'm having to provide a negative review on this product. As a hardcore fan of the Dungeon Keeper series, I wanted this game to succeed very, very badly. The sad thing is that, it does! It's just technically unplayable. There are no bugs, or not to my experience at least. No glitches, weird errors, crashes, or anything of the sort. And the gameplay is very, very funny, and exciting!(NOTE: Many players have reported a great number of bugs! I just personally haven't run into any, and made it to lvl 3 of the campaign without encountering any glitches and or bugs.)However, as I approached the end of the third campaign level, in which you VS another underlord, with spells like you posess also, the game went total ape♥♥♥♥♥♥ I haven't been able to fix it, and no solutions are to be found anywhere on the www at all. The level went well, until I came into actual contact with my opposer. The AI controlled underlord, started casting all sorts of spells on my creatures as they pushed the edges of his base back, slowly but surely. The FPS dropped immediatly as the casting began, to 2 - 7 FPS. Now before you all start questioning my specs, and wether or not my pc should be able to handle this title. I run some top of the notch hardware. Two GTX Titans overlocked in SLI , 64-bit, 32GB RAM, Intel Core I7-4930K CPU 3.40GHZ. They have yet to invent a game that my system can't handle, so no excuses developers! I am literally halted in my tracks.  And I can't play the game I payed for any further, until this matter is resolved. Therefor, I advice all potential buyers to WAIT, and not purchase this title, until a fix has been provided officially. Once there is a fix, I'll consider providing a positive piece of feedback.The devs have made several posts on the community hub, in which they state they've 'improved the FPS issues' however, I've had no confirmation of this what so ever, nor any positive feedback regarding this subject from any other buyers.Good game, terribly optimized! Fix this, so we can play this gem in the rough!

												Being a backer, I played through the single player during "release".  The state of the game at that time was a complete mess. content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												This game is pretty much a straight remake of Dungeon Keeper 2 with some names changed and without the handy map function.  That would not be a bad thing, only I have found it buggy and extremely slow.  It has never exited without crashing, room tiles vanish without a reason, sometimes can't pick up creatures from your prison, takes minutes to load on a computer that runs Skyrim with ease, etc.It also badly needs a manual to understand many of the features, which is a shame because a lot of thought obviously went into some of them.  Some of the voice acting is pretty good too.  I feel bad saying this about something trying to carry the flag of a game I love, but I can't recommend it.  It suffers from being too like the original without enough added content or new features, and it seems to run worse than the original did on far older ones.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												I feel this does not capture the spirit of the first Dungeon Keeper, but I also feel like it surpasses Dungeon Keeper 2, but not enough for me to give a recommendation.The main problem I have with this game is the pacing. Every mission you unlock something new, leading to a rather spikey learning curve as you are supposed to juggle the intracies of new rooms and creatures on gameplay while being introduced to new rooms and creatures and mechanics. The game wasn't even challenging. You aren't ever wanting for resources, nor do you need to carefully build defenses, or carefully gauge how much of whatever room to attract various minions.Prisons and torture are pretty useless, but more units never hurt anything. Traps are overpowered, and you can rally click your way to victory without breaking a sweat. I enjoyed the narration though.The entire game feels like a tutorial, and there's never any added difficulty of learning to use your arsenal well. When you finally get all your toys to begin playing with, the game gives you the credits and a thanks for playing! Well, you're not welcome. Ok, maybe a little welcome. It was still Dungeon Keeper after all.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												If you like DK1 and 2, you should definitely give this a go. It sticks extremely close to the formula.Pros:* Feels like other DK's* Similar DK humour (Lol'd at Chunders)* Overall just really good!Cons:* Subtitle text is too small and is pure white meaning it's hard to read on bright backgrounds* All of the buildings have the word 'Prop' in them. e.g. Instead of 'Barracks' it's called 'Prop Barracks'...not sure why.* When you look at buildings/creatures and what they're doing it's not very specific whereas in DK2 it was very specific about what was going on so you could micromanage very well.EDIT: I've been playing it for a bit longer since my initial review.The game is too buggy. Here are a list I've encountered so far (The good aspects of the game still stand, but it's also buggy).- Frequently getting 'Insufficient mana' when trying to cast a spell even if my mana is full.- Imps ignore the boundaries set by the flag to stop them possessing land- I played a skirmish game and nothing happened. No units came at all.- Several graphical glitches- The sidebar buttons are wayyy too small to hit with a cursor. The whole UI is a bit finnicky, I'm not sure if it's just too small?- Placeholder variables in the actual game content. This is unacceptable. Things like 'Identified : False' and 'Team:null' are very lazy placeholders which they need to remove asap. I also encountered one where a beast was going for food and it's status was something along the lines of 'Going to HUNGER_VAR at slaughterpen'...not cool.- When you possess a creature, the movement feels janky and jerky.I think more than anything, they need to seriously review their code. By the sounds of it, they're rushing it and introducing more bugs.Still, If you like DK (not donkey kong) and don't mind a few annoyances, I'd recommend it.

												I purchased this game a few years ago because I was really excited about a new version of Dungeon Keeper. I have tried playing multiple times and every time I run into some game-halting bug. Each time I try playing, I ending up stopping to wait for the bugs to get fixed. When I first started the game was in early access so I decided to cut them some slack. But now it's the full version of the game and I still can't play because of these bugs that basically make gameplay impossible.I really want to like this game. It's a fun concept and the devs have obviously done a ton of work on it and made an almost-great product. But the focus seems to be entirely on adding content rather than making sure the existing content works. It doesn't matter how great your graphics are, how many levels you have, and how many different rooms and spells and monsters you've thrown into the mix. If people can't play because of bugs, your game is bad.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												This is a "Wait-for-Sale" game, as much as I hate to say it. But I say that because by the time it goes on sale, it should have more content and most of the bugs out of the system. But if you've been waiting for Dungeon Keeper 3, look no further than this.At the time of review, I had completed the campaign and dipped a little into the skirmish mode. As far as tech problems, I've only had two of note and both happened on level 10. I had the game freeze for 10 minutes when I did a ritual that revealed the enemy dungeon. And I tried to reload a save for it and it didn't load. Other than that the only other tech problems I've had is really nothing that cannot be solved with graphic adjustments in the options menu. If you're experiencing game breaking bugs, you might want to consider the age of your hardware and upgrade the parts that are over five-years old.Despite the bugs and the lack of content in the skirmish, I've had a fantastic time with this game. The campaign, while a glorified tutorial, is quite good whether you're an old player or new to this type of game. I played Dungeon Keeper 2 for comparison and my verdict is that it is pretty much DK 2 with the polish that didn't exist in 1999 and with addtions that add to overall experience rather than detract. I found the use of Potions and Rituals to be an interesting addtion to the formula. And you'll come to love the Narrator, who is from the original game, as the way that he delivers his dialouge is such a joy to listen to. I would put him the Hall of Fame where they reconigze voice talents like the narrators from "Stanley Parable" and "Basition".This game definately is going to be worth having but it's going to happen several patches down the line. To their credit, they are coming out with patches at a quick rate but this game definately could've used another month in Early Access to polish up their assests. Heck, you can still see the Unity engine titles when you hover over units. I don't know whether it was money and/or the bad reputation Early Access has gotten the past year that prompted them to release it in this state, but it thankfully doesn't detract from the overall game experience and the game is backed by a good studio. We haven't really gotten a good successor to Dungeon Keeper and this is by far a worthy successor to the concept.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												Great gameplay, Unfortunately sullied somewhat by freequent crashes, looking forward to some heavy duty patching for stablity. Other than that, Awesome so far.TL;DR -- The game is not complete, Altho being very fun, Needs ALOT of work. If you don't mind playing what is essentially still beta, Then you won't be dissapointed, If not. Wait 6-12 months for it to be properly ready.UPDATE: Since writing the Original review, the game has Launched. Unfortunately, It is still far from what I would consider "complete" The Single player campaign has frequent issues (server slowdown/freezes/crashes/Bugs out and after completing the objective nothing happens). These can be gotten around by re-playing the level but you really shouldn't have to do that. There is a servere lack of content beyond the single player campaign too. There is alot of stuff "comming" but a released game should be COMPLETE. If it's not ready, leave it in early access. If this was still in early access I could definitely recommend it. The game has alot of potential, and in 6 months to a year, I think it will be a really great game. Unfortunately, It's just not complete. IF you don't mind playing a "released" game that is basically still in Beta, then you WILL NOT be dissapointed. However, if you are after a complete game. You will be.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I can vouche this one.  Was a backer (even though the title wasn't given due to the fact that my pay method wasn't accepted for it).  In the last 2 days this game has been patched with steadfast determination.  I have followed this game for YEARS.  It is one of the very few games out there that promised and delivered after a ton of ups and down within the production.  The game in itself is made with the Unity engine.  The DK series was a favorite of mine from the beginning, and was a kick to the balls when EA bought it and did what they do best.  Round filed it.  These ppl saw a community who was begging for more from the DK title, and took it upon themselves to dev WftO, even though they had to cover their azzes to keep the game in the spirit of the DK genre while making it their own.  This group never promised anything it didn't deliver.  Not once in the promotion of the game did they make it look like it was anything but what it is.  I have faith in this product to be a quality piece.  I have played many games that were top titles that were released in WAY worse shape, and WAY more expensive.I give this game 10 thumbs up and played it for about 66 hrs.  It had some laggy issues with the AI pathing which seemes to have been patched out, and 2 bugs with completion which also has been fixed.  If you want a blast from the past with a new twist, this game is a definite buy.  If you are worried about the bugs, give it a day or 2 to let them sort out the release and then buy it.  This is a must for anyone that is a fan of the DK series, or the "god" game genre.  I have been reporting and watching the WftO forums, and I must say that not once have they not replied quickly to any reports or comments.Hop to see you soon Underlord!

content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Unfortunately, the game slows to a crawl and then crashes when lots of stuff is on-screen, requiring a hard-reset (and a disk-error integrity check). At the "Keros" level, the game becomes unplayable.  Sadly, the game seems to have its heart in the right place, but the technology just doesn't work.  It appears the game was rushed to release early, on purpose, since the developer's tool tips are still in the game and appear when you hover your mouse over anything (complete with error and bug notices).  One must assume the early release was out of fear of the competing product, "Dungeons 2" which is due out in a few days.  The rush to beat a competitor to market resulted in a  broken game.  Maybe the game will be finished and fixed through patches.  It looks like it has great potential when finished.  But it is still in beta stage, and releasing it like that is awful.  Don't buy this product.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
												TL:DR at end.Well, I'll start by saying that I love this game, it really is a modern dungeon keeper. I'll continue by pointing out some downfalls: compared to the first 2 there's not many improvements in my opinion; it seems to be made to be a lot easier too, hence 10 hours to complete campaign (with 5 crashes); It feels like it's still in beta, which i will now expand upon but first let me point out i have not read what the developers have to say about current state & patch roadmaps because I shouldn't have to, Someone releases a game and you expect it to be ready for release: This is not.I'll be light on this subject because if you dont care about these things, you'll enjoy the game, I know i did. First, too many towers crashes the game; that's right, a dungeon defense game and if you build too many defenses, it will crash. One mission in particular, campaign mission 9, you have to defend a bottleneck which is of course perfect for towers but no, build them and after 2 mins you'll be restarting. Secondly, it's obviously not finished, mouse over a minion and it will tell you their current task which almost always is psuedocode, for example (and I'm paraphrasing here ) you will see current task do_GOLD_prop(dugeon.heart)  instead of 'get paid'  or get_raw_food_prop(pigfarm) instead of 'eat micropig'; further to this the interface doesn't work as it should, want to see your list of minions? it will often forget to turn the boundery of the list into scroll bars so you can only see the first 6 or 7 types of minion.Thirdly it takes an insane amount of RAM, I'm not sure if there's a leak in there or whether it doesn't use GFX dedicated ram properly but 4.5Gb of RAM to run? Dont get me wrong, I have enough RAM but DAMN, that's more than any other game in my library (and i have a lot).So yes, plays well if you dont build towers or use the ritual ro reveal the enemy dugeon (yup, that's a crash too!), nothing too immersion breaking on the interface apart from being able to only see half your force and taking 2 seconds to see what your minion is doing instead of 1/2 a second and if you dont have much RAM you may have performance issues, apart from that, a 9 hour sp experience(if you dont crash), only 3 skirmish maps, all very small & multiplayer/survival is still not working right now.TL:DRslapped a micropig, it squeeled and popped and made me smile, 12/10 now stop reading reviews if you cant be bothered to read.

Posted: October 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing.....I never got to play the Dungeon Keeper games, but have always been looking for a dungeon management game that appealed to me. After going through many of the popular games out there and them all being duds, I found this one! This game has very little content thus far, and was still entertaining. I can't wait for this game to be fully released as I imagine I will be logging alot of hours. The only flaws I could even think of was that some of the user interface aspects could be a little more clean and user friendly, as well as workers sometimes taking forever to build doors. Either way this will be an epic game and im 100% on board!Side note* its very rare to play an early acess game with no noticeable bugs, and thats what you get here. This game is really polished to be at such an early stage of development! Keep up the great work Devs!

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Disappointing, I know this is an indie project but when you sell it as the successor to Dungeon Keeper you hope for a bit more. The graphics are serviceable but lack some of the edge and charm of the original. The balance is super patchy - some levels feel too easy some levels hard in maddening ways. One example being a later level where you can chew throw two foes quickly only to find the third has an infinitely spawning group of high level forces, workers and mana - even with half of their base conquered!  It feels like a competent update but the magic isn't there and the frustrations push it over to a no for me. Really I was looking for more than an update to the old game. Playing this after Keeper RL and having seen the trailers for Dungeon 2 also push me to think they really could have done more.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												The game had a lot of potential.It's horribly put together and is riddled with issues; AI pathfinding is atrocious and your minions are nigh on impossible to control. This wouldn't be a problem if this was a relaxing romp through the joys of building a dungeon and repelling would be invaders or seeking out objections in your own time. The crucial problem, and the deal breaker for me, is the excessive focus on speed and micro management that seems to underpin every aspect of this game. It's like somebody took Dungeon Keeper soul and flayed bits off of it and crammed it into a Starcraft tournament.I kept wanting to like this game but I cannot in good conscious recommend it. I am not enjoying it.The developers seem a good bunch and are dedicated to getting the game running as best it can but owing to the inherent game design issues I have with this game it wouldn't be enough.I may come back in a few months when it's actually finished.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												After the debacle of another game I bought into for Early Access, I had my doubts about this game.  I re-installed today after reading the notes and came upon a pleasent surprise.  Dungeon Keeper 1 is among my top favorite games to play.  This game, while not quite there, does fill the void that game left after DK2 appeared to be it.  After some time to play, I want to give some more information about the game for those out there.  Notable Problems: 1. Sluggish Gameplay: At the moment, they just quashed a major problem by fixing the issue with the memory leak.  This helped deal with some of my slowdown issues, but it hasn't fixed them all.  I'm not on a state-of-the-art model computer.  At the same time, I am running a decent setup that can handle a good chunk of modern games at higher settings.  I haven't tried out my laptop, yet I will get around to that for a final detailed review. 2. Place Holder Text: A majority of this did get fixed.  Some place holder text does remain however.  Also, there are times when text will break and return to a placeholder setup.  This happened to me on the second to last level with some creature texts.  Minor Issues: 1. Saved Game issue - Encountered this one today where my saved game files were out of arrangment.  I had to fish around to find the one that I wanted.  2. Tactics:  At the moment, the computer can be downright stupid at times.  It'll do nothing or do a simple, one direction, brute force attack wave that can be counter with ease.  3. Level Design: Each level feels similar to the next with little change in design.  Only one level really caught my eyes, standing out from the rest.  With all of that said though, this is not a Caveat Emptor/Buyer Beware notion.  Instead, I recommend it as a buyer being aware this game still needs some fine tuning.  I applaud the developers for sticking with the game vs. simply releasing it then splitting with some extra $$$ to line their pockets.  Several updates have been released since launch to fix notorious issues, and, in a week or two imho, the game will start to work even better than expected.

												I had high hopes for this game and at times it was very, very, good but there were a few things that I didn't like. Even with the game still being fixed and with all the bugs it was enjoyable, but the fact that the bugs make the game unplayable at times made it really annoying.While playing the game I felt it was pushing you to complete it, rather unlike DK 1 and 2, were you could build your dungeon and plan and plot. Placing traps in DK 1 and 2 were useful, in this game not so much, as when heroes or enemy creatures hit level 5 then the traps prove useless and ineffective. Overall, out of the whole game, there were only 3 or 4 levels where you could just build your dungeon and then expand outwards.Also in the last mission the cinematic was really disappointing, it was predictable and so short I felt cheated.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												War for the Overworld (WFTO) is the spiritual successor of Dungeon Keeper 2.  The campaign is similar to DK2 with a heavy focus on RTS elements and aggressive gameplay.  Fortunately, the game has a speed setting so that you can play slower (or faster) - I found the campaign highly enjoyable on the slower speed.Criticism:I think the UI is far too cumbersome for an RTS game - there are too many UI elements.  Also, there are several redundant types of units, rooms, and spells.  These redundancies just make the game feel bulky.  Fortunately, there are hotkeys for everything - it just takes a while to learn them.TL;DR  This is Dungeon Keeper 3

content:

												I found the AI of this game makes micromanaging impossible. Its basically a starcraft (without the shortcut keys) where you got to not only feed your units, but keep them happy and always have to waste time looking for them since they wander and its impossible to control them (outside of your floors).I ended up deciding to not continue play after not even 10 hours since goal is mostly always to destroy one or many buildings and the objectives wether single or multiplayer is to destroy the "core" of a player and didn't felt like playing a mix of moba and starcraft spamming a building with units.Altough I was tempted by the customizeable tree of upgrades and its various units, I just can't keep up with the gameplay, just my first missions took me around an hour or two each to do since there are so much elements and mechanics in them constantly tossed you while trying to make the campaign itself, that I lost one or two games trying to master basic mechanics and new units.I'd say its probably an incredibly good strategy game once you get the hang of it, but I'm not too fond of the genre myself and just wanted to have a better look at it.Any fan of strategy game and classic RPG elements will be pleased with this title, its a good one, just not for me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2015
												COMPARISON OF OVERWORLD TO DUNGEONKEEPER I bought the game despite the negative reviews, and suggest you do the same. I am a diehard fan of DK, having an emulator on my PC for the sole purpose of playing it (and have done so a lot). I am so happy I found a game that brought me what 'Impire' and 'Dungeons' didn't. This game exceeded my expectations enough I may uninstall my emulator for DK.PROS:+True DK successor- saturated with eastereggs  that even veteran players may miss (micropiglets have invaded your dungeon)+Better storyline than DK. You aren't a random keeper trying to get out of hell for implied reasons.+Perfect voice acting-  Better execution than in DK, which was exceptional to begin with.+Well balanced.  Good luck finding a cheap exploit against a good player.+Multiple strategies for victory. DK was won by having a hoard of creatures and that alone. Overworld has many, if you're clever enough to find them.+Technology tree that allows for rushing, booming and turtling strategies that didn't exist in DK. +An AI that is actually challenging. +Elite, boss like creatures that put dark angels to shame+More meaningful combinations with traps. DK had many traps, but they weren't actually useful like they are in Overworld.+Constructs for sapping, replacing earth (I wanted that so bad in DK), and more+More strategy with spells. In DK, pragmatically you could only use the same 2-3. While you aren't forced to be spell happy, spells can be a main strategy for victory.+Dungeon molds to your playing style more than DKCONS-UI needs to be more polished- If you select a potion, you are unable to change your mind; You have to use it. Selecting a ritual to perform is clunky, and is easy to cancel out of by mistake without knowing.-Was under pressure to ship to market too soon. Fortunately development has been responsive.-Possesion mode doesn't make it clear what you're targeting, or if you're hitting anything as well as DK does.-Creature dialogue can distract from gameplay. I know some other players find creatures overtly chatty. Only the Cultist bothers me. -If there are secret creatures to be gained by combining rooms, I haven't found them.-None of the minigames that gave the original DK some of it's flavor. But I never played those much anyway. No comical video shorts either-No invincible, horned reaper. But let's be honest, it probably doesn't belong in there unless they're literally cloning DK.-Your dungeon isn't filled with yoghurt. The floor isn't lumpy either. No need to order your minions to jump up and down.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Ok so fun story your gonna love this/. Its about one in the morning after my mate gets off skype and goes to bed. I see a patch for underworld. So I download it and look at the notes and said the memory leak should be fixed and I was like oooo.So tried it out.Loaded it up and instantly the menu says "isn't it past your bedtime underlord". I was like what the ♥♥♥♥. Is this my girlfriend telling me to go to bed since its 1 in the morning? Haha anyway load up my save from one of the campaign levels that had been lagging like hell it ran smoothly I was loving it. After completing the level I instantly moved onto the next one, feeling int the zone. Next level after defending for 30 mins I held strong. I then counter attacked and lost my army but they had nothing left so I built up another army. I built this army up for ages and it got massive.So this is where it gets funny right? Just as I have spent 1 hour building this army up and half an hour defending so I have spent an hour and a half on this l level. I had a insanely complicated dungeon with defenses everywhere and ward so I could see everything inside their base.I knew how Many troops they had and where they were etc I had built a massive army and waited till they were all like level 8. So after 2 hours playing the games and an hour and a half being spent on this one level.... I sold a tile to build a lair on it as my army was so big then I was gonna attack and win the level. So I sell the tile and........freeze. I wait and I wait and I wait and it comes up with games not responding. I say wait for game to respond and this goes up for a bit where it keeps saying it's not responding and I keeep saying wait. Eventually I realise the game was dead so Clicked close program. I load up the game straight away to see if. I have anything left on the level I had spent an hour and a half doing. It loads up. Menu proceeds to says "Underlord. Go to bed." At this point I'm thinking ♥♥♥♥ you. You did not just crash my game and my dungeon and my level that I had spent ages doing and now your telling me to go to bed? ♥♥♥♥ you. So go into save games. Nothing there. I will have to restart the level. At this point I close the game and go to bed.I hate it's guts but due to the addicting nature of the game I will end up redoing the level tomorrow. Even though this game has frustrating moments like this, It did cause me to stay up until like 3am playing it. It is massively fun and the bugs are rare. It was my fault I had not saved. 10/10 would rage again lol 10/10 would play again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Finally!  A true successor to Dungeon Keeper, or so I thought.  Well... it started well, then they gave up.  There was a good patch that made it playable but it didnt get over the basic problem. It is very linear and none of the game modes seemed to give it any real variety.  Graphically, it has all the things I liked about the original dungeon keeper but in a graphical environment which is fit for current PCs and doesnt leave you thinking... mod.  Nice ideas and just enough variety to, if not overwhelm one with the possibilities, not to be annoying by itIt t has the open sandbox and Multiplayer capability that DK really didnt do properly even with mods but somehow, the sandbox didnt really work. It is just too limited. Not really the intense epic set pieces I like to fight out.  This is a good, nay, a great game in principle. When it first went to general release it went slightly too early, so scored way lower on metacritic but it isnt terrible. It just isnt good enough either sadly.  Too linear, too limited.  Somehow, just a bit unsatisfying all round. A light weight version of the game I would have really wanted. I liked it a lot for a while but I am switching a thumbs up to a thumbs down as what I thought was a work in progress never went any further in unlocking the potential.

The game just throws you in and expects you to know what to do. Overall, this is a poor spiritual successor for the old dungeon keepers. Stay away from this game.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Disappointing, I know this is an indie project but when you sell it as the successor to Dungeon Keeper you hope for a bit more. The graphics are serviceable but lack some of the edge and charm of the original. The balance is super patchy - some levels feel too easy some levels hard in maddening ways. One example being a later level where you can chew throw two foes quickly only to find the third has an infinitely spawning group of high level forces, workers and mana - even with half of their base conquered!  It feels like a competent update but the magic isn't there and the frustrations push it over to a no for me. Really I was looking for more than an update to the old game. Playing this after Keeper RL and having seen the trailers for Dungeon 2 also push me to think they really could have done more.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												The game had a lot of potential.It's horribly put together and is riddled with issues; AI pathfinding is atrocious and your minions are nigh on impossible to control. This wouldn't be a problem if this was a relaxing romp through the joys of building a dungeon and repelling would be invaders or seeking out objections in your own time. The crucial problem, and the deal breaker for me, is the excessive focus on speed and micro management that seems to underpin every aspect of this game. It's like somebody took Dungeon Keeper soul and flayed bits off of it and crammed it into a Starcraft tournament.I kept wanting to like this game but I cannot in good conscious recommend it. I am not enjoying it.The developers seem a good bunch and are dedicated to getting the game running as best it can but owing to the inherent game design issues I have with this game it wouldn't be enough.I may come back in a few months when it's actually finished.
