content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												The game is laggy and glitchy.  The minimap is a pixelated mess.  Overall, not really all that fun and very time-consuming.  I wish I hadn't spent the money that I did on it.  The mouse is even an annoying hand.  I mean, do yourself a favor, and instead of playing through the levels on this where you really can't build your own dungeon (the campaign are all missions which tell you specifically what to do, and I can only assume the multiplayer would be even worse glitch-wise) and get something good like Command and Conquer if you're all about the overhead gameplay.  This leaves very little room for your own style of play, which is what really made it a negative for me.  I culd try to assume maybe it was my alienware that wasn't running to spec, but the glitches are numerous, it takes forever to load, the graphics leave something to be desired, etc.  It's just a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to play, and when I go to attack with my minions and beasts, half of them don't pay attention to the rally flag, hich is another negative as you can only command your people to go to one place.  There is also no group selection or anything of the sort.  Either tell ALL of them to go HERE or leave them to their business.  This leaves no way to strategize about letting production continue and defend with certain minions, etc.  Overall, this is a piece of♥♥♥♥♥♥game in my opinion, and a waste of time if you're looking for something that allows for real RTS.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												I admire every effort put to this game. It's a tribute to Dungeon Keeper. Feeding vampire in prison, changing prisoners into gold, setting torture chamber mode (execution or corrupt), creating dirt tiles, making potions that effect group of creatures once released, casting spells on group on minions, spirit workers, etc.It's like Dungeon Keeper on steroids... but unfortunatelly overdosed :(Maps are too large to grasp. You can have so many minions you don't see what's going on in the battle. Minions have too much health. I don't feel the bond with minions as much as in old Dungeon Keeper. I don't feel any loss when they die... well, I might feel this way because of my age and gaming experience, but dear developers I hope my complaints will help you in future releases/sequels. Minions are complaining about food, salary and lair too much. When they are "railed", they should focus on fight, no complaints ;) And also when you possess your minion, you could make his vision adjusted to his race (vampire - red sight, spider - 8 eyes somehow visualised, etc.).  Like in good old Dungeon Keeper (1997).Only technical thing I dislike is minimap. It should be more intuititive.Overall conclusion, I like innovations introduced in this title, and it's pretty efficient considering so much AI working at the same time, but I think the gameplay requires more polishing and balancing. It's still the best modern title similar to Dungeon Keeper.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Just finished the single player game. Difficult to give a thumbs up here, as much as I want to give one to the spiritual successor of some of my favourite games, which I loved so much that I actually bought WFTO once on Kickstarter and once in Steam. In terms of mechanics it mostly works all right, except for that weird bug where prisoners keep dying as they are dropped into prison (just save and reload) and that thing where Revelation never ends so you can't use another ritual. Mostly all right. Performance and graphics wise it's decent. Just don't expect nifty extras like the special torture animations for different characters, here they are all the same.But the single player campaign missions... so simplistic and skeletal compared to Dungeon Keeper 1 and 2 both. Whoever designed the missions have not benchmarked their work against the predecessors and told themselves they must do better; it is more like they have never tried the old ones. It is a real shame to see all the working mechanics but such poor missions. By the time the game ends you probably won't even have tried half the spells/traps/rituals/potions/ on offer and easily never use several room types and minion types, the mission are just that insipid and easy. Everything is "kill everything". Balance issues abound as well. It is simply too easy to convert enemies quickly, DK 1 and 2 had the same issue but not quite so strongly. This makes supposedy tough missions trivial - defeat the first enemy wave and you immediately have enough minions to steamroll all the objectives. This goes hand in hand with the bizarre abundance of infinite gold resource on so many single player missions - it makes the game trivially easy! I finished it all and never even tried ghouls, or spirits, or vampires.. because you don't need it when you have 50 monsters fighting a handful.I have not tried the multiplayer. It is difficult to give it a try when the single player was always wonderful in DK1 and DK2 and so different here. Overall the campaign felt painfully abbreviated vs DK1 or DK2 and the ending was emotionally a big letdown as well. You should NEVER have a situation in a game where the boss died in 10 seconds and his taunts then play one after another for half a minute! Seriously devs.. I guess it's worth buying if it's on 50% sale, or if they have some kind of free expansion with another 15 missions. REALLY hope this game becomes moddable so people can step in with proper single player mission designs and rebalance things like how easy torture conversion is. Don't need your voiceovers. Just good missions.

												I always loved the Dungeon Keeper series and hence, looked forward to buying War for the Overworld. I bought the Gold Edition and luckily, it retains all of the atmosphere of the originals, while at the same time adding new elements to it.I like the new races and their trivia during the loading screen, it's even more descriptive than the information we got from the creatures in the originals(!) Likewise, the Cultist and the Succubus better fit the dark theme of the series than the Warlock and the Mistress did, in my humble opinion.Overall the game has great enjoyability, with the singular exception of the time achievements. Which to be fair, are still being recalibrated by the developers in order to keep the game fun and balanced.

												A few bugs and crashes still, but overall a solid successor to the DK games. I've been following the project since the early days, looking forward to it, but I ultimately held off due to its somewhat rocky release. The game in its current state is still a bit rough around the edges but pretty good. Management is a good balance between micro and macro and gives enough tools in both toolkits that neither gets tedious. Pacing is good in the levels and challenges are reasonable.The narrative is well-written and the characters are interesting, though the ending is atrocious. Still a worthwhile experience.

												This game is like the old dungeon keepers, but with only two forms of strategy. The only hope for the keeper is to attack or keep monsters around the heart by flagging the heart. content:
Posted: February 9
												If you were thinking "God I love Dungeon Keeper II, but it doesn't work on my modern computer," then here is the solution for you. This game is almost the exact same game.If you were not looking for Dungeon Keeper II, then you may want to keep moving (though if you have never played it before it is excellent).The Skirmishes feel identical to the orignal game, though the campaign is a bit more combat-focused and less puzzle-focused. The "Sin" system also feels a bit different than anything I remember from DKII, but it works well to dole out your spells and achievements in a way that feel satisfying until end game when you have far more sins than you could ever use.Sorry this isn't helpful to anyone who hasn't played DKII, but this is basically a clone of that game.

content:
Posted: April 6
												Well, I bought this game a few days ago and already have about 16 hours into it. So I am going to write this review from that standpoint.I played Dungeon Keeper 1 and loved it (tried 2 but for some reason it was really slow). I have no idea why EA never released another true dungeon keeper game, unless you call that travesty of a mobile game a true game.Anyway, this game is fantastic, you build your base with different rooms each serving different purposes. The game looks great and you really feel as if you are a god trying to build his base to crush an enemy. The only negative think I could say at the moment, is that as I build up my base, my game either slows down or freezes for a second before going back to normal, this makes it hard to actually control your alies in first person and attack who you want.The only thing else I could want is a random map generator, so that I could fight AI in a random map every single time, however I realize that would be a LOT of extra work for obvious reasons, so I am willing to give it a pass.So, are you ready to delve in overlord? Are you ready to crush your enemies under your book and slaughter your enemies. Well then overlord, buy this game!Edit: Playing some of the maps can be difficult. Normally the game works great, that is until an hour or two passes when yourve expanded your main base, unlocked more spaces to your dungeon, and added new rooms. This causes several dozen units to move around simutaniously and it really slows the game down. It gets to the point that on most scenario maps, I cant play anymore after 2-3 hours because when anything happens the game drops to less than 10 frames a second, making fights annoying, and making possessing a troop impossible.

content:
Posted: April 22
												Do you like being evil? This is a RTS that was fashioned after the "Dungeon Master" series, and it does very very good job at it. The battles feel a little wonkey as it is hard to understand who is losing and who is winning when you are litterally staring at 150-200 minions, but I digress as it is my only ♥♥♥♥♥ about the game. I am writing this after completeing both campaigns (normal and Heart of Gold) and the game was a blast. I remember the last map of heart of gold I needed to trap my hero as he kept finding a way to kill himself when wondering into the enemy base with no prior instructions to. Pros:Pretty FunBe EvilSmack minions to make them quicker, some times its just fun to smack the succubi (they love it)Not to taxing on your GPU, it ran well on my nvidia580mFunny Dialogue the first timeCons:Some wonky Critter HP gaugesDialogue is repeated and after hearing it 20 times it becomes not so funny.Not enough levels/or campaignsTLDR: Fun, Evil, and will probably play on a toaster. A good RTS for those who loved dungeon keeper or those who think being the evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is awesome.

Posted: April 15
												It is a great game with a dungeon keeper feel. It is somewhat easy towards the beginning, then gets incredibly hard, then goes back to easy for the final mission. My chief complaint is the level design didn't feel creative. Most levels play the same way. Which is not bad, but some variety would have been nice. For instance, we have a possess creature spell, why not make a level where we have to use that spell continually to win? That said, this still a good game, and worth buying.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 18
												Despite being a massive fan of the original Dungeon Keeper games, I decided to hold off on buying this game at release because of the mixed reviews it was getting, saying that it still wasn't finished etc. but eventually I gave in a bought the game a little while after Heart of Gold was released, and all I can say is that this is definately the spiritual successor to Dungeon Keeper that I have always asked for.A lot of the the early problems that I saw have been fixed for the most part and there's is now plenty of content that has been added to the game to keep you coming back, and it suits all of the play styles. You have the main campaign which despite being relatively short, is good at introducing the new features of the games such as Sins, Beasts and Potions and such, and there are plenty of side objectives you can go through for repeat playthroughs to keep you going, same goes for the Heart of Gold campaign, which improves in a lot of ways on the original campaign.There are also the other game modes including Crucible, a survival styled mode where you have to fight against oncoming hoards of enemies. Skirmish for playing online and against AI. Sandbox for just having the freedom of building your dungeon. Also the recently added My Pet Dungeon mode which had taken the elements from the original Dungeon Keeper 2 game, and improved upon it by adding basically a small campaign with multiple maps and objectives to complete at your own time.Though this wouldn't go without a few faults with the game I feel there still are, though recently improved upon, I still find the possesion to be a little finicky when it comes to attacking enemies. Also there is a little bit of a lack of variety when it comes to creatures for your dungeon, but Crucible did help this by adding new varieties, and you can also convert a lot of the enemy hero units. Overall I'd say if you were a fan of the original game give this game a go, and even if you're interested in the genre try it out. Though it may not be for everyone I still had a great time and couldn't reccomend it more.

number of helpful: 19 of 40 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												Dungeon Keeper 2. The game that captivated the attention of many a gamer and left a solid mark in their minds for all eternity. It was a game that left a monument difficult to match - with a fun campaign, great pacing and truck loads of charm. With its sequel cancelled and EA hogging the rights, people waited and waited for a spiritual successor.So in came War for the Overworld. A game promising to be Dungeon Keeper without being Dungeon keeper. You've got your rooms, your dungeon heart, your minions, your imps... everything is there. Traps, doors, spells, gold... and a deviously evil yet satisfyingly supportive advisor. The charm is there. The atmosphere is there... but one can't help but feel like... something is missing.Gameplay just seems... lacking. The pacing feels all... wrong. The campaign feels a little offly-paced and building up your own dungeon feels... a little unsatisfying. Minions seem less... personal than in Dungeon Keeper as well. You don't get the 'oh look, there's one of my goblins having a good time with a rogue!' feeling you get with DK2... nor do you have the urge to take control of one of your favourite minions to do scouting, fighting or just exploring your dungeon. Your troops feel more like... insignificant insects. Foot-soldiers.So just what is missing? The game has the content. It has the charm. It has the atmosphere... but it just doesn't have the soul. And until it captures that soul... I dunno... I just don't feel satisfaction from playing...I'm going to have to thumb this one down, as much as I really don't want want to. Because it's a game that has huge potential.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												As much as I looked forward to this game for ages, and would like nothing more than to give this a positive review...I can't.It's just a hollow shadow of what Dungeon Keeper 1 and 2 were.  There's no character to it.  No real in-depth anything.  In DK2, I felt like I knew each and every one of my minions during a mission.  Felt like each one was their own unique person and I knew all their strengths and weaknesses.  In this...I just chop out large rooms, slap down stuff, and drop a battle-flag on the enemy room until it dies.  I could just tab out and win doing that.  There's no real strategy.  "Build a bunch of traps, then drop a flag down and wait".  This is not fun.  This is tedious, boring and disapointing.   DK2 had style.  I can still remember certain key missions that were just so memorable because of how amazing they were.  Like the one where you use the hidden doors to slowly take over a hero fortress from within.  This game...all of the maps are the same thing over and over.  "Get a bunch of faceless minions (doesn't really matter which ones, just get a bunch!) and drop a flag where you want things to die, then surf the internet on your phone until you win.  The only memorable map so far I've had so far was memorable because of how stupid the gimmick was.  You don't get to build a dungeon (which is what the whole damn game should be about...).  You get 4 necromancers AND JUST LEAD THEM AROUND THE MAP WITH ♥♥♥♥ING FLAGS UNTIL EVERYTHING DIES!  There's no skill, there's no difficulty.  Just a long tedious slog through the map until you have enough skeletons with them to swarm the end room.  Tonnes of gimmicky unbreakable doors to make it so you have to literally slog all the way around the map all over the place, and all it does is stretch out the time it takes to finish, and not for any good reason.  I'm going to go play DK2 again.  Horny's calling.

												Its glitchy, its buggy, and even at the lowest graphic settings, the frame rates chugs along like a steam boat. Not uncommon for the game to freeze for a few seconds after you click and drag to mine or build a new room, which given its Dungeon management play style, gameplay is OH so enjoyable. Also, spells crash the game. Never been able to cast one. Every time I select a spell and cast, the game freezes. And then crashes. Whatever 'update' you had me download, it messed up an already buggy game. Its somehow worse in full release than it was in early access. Save yourself the trouble and get Dungeon Keeper 2 off GOG or something.

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												TL;DR version:I can not reccomend the game, even tho it is the closest you will get to a Dungeon Keeper sequel. The stuff that made DK fun just is not done right. It simply is no fun.This feedback is not about bugs. Devs are doing an awesome job at fixing everything up. And if you read this review most of them will most likely be fixed already. Really they are pushing patches daily.I also won't go into detail about what i like or love about the game, because that does not help much. What i want to do here is go into detail about what i DON'T like. You can judge for yourself if these issues actually affect you. If not: BUY IT.Game paceThe campain missions feel like a constant rush.Waves after wave clashing at your walls, timer that have to be met ect. This is no fun for me. It sure makes sense for a mission or two, but it sure feels like every mission is like this.To explain my feelings a bit easier: After a mission i want to log OUT and not play another one, due to feeling stressed.Number of features - too many? Another strage feeling i get is the feeling of having to deal with way too many features.They all feel so unrewarding that i more often then not choose to not use them at all. Spells, Potions, Rituals, Research,... special stuff to build like walls or bombs ect.Combined with the game pace that makes me rush and stressed i don't like to be bothered with so many options. Strange indeed, because i always think more is better. This is the first game that makes me want LESS. I guess both issues combined are the actuall problem. Id love to get to know each feature and USE it, EXPLORE possibilities. But missions rush by so fast that i just don't bother.Tooltips and general lack of informationsNot knowing how your dungeon actually works is annoying. Simple as that. Bigger rooms? What do they do? You don't know, you can only guess. In a dungeon management game it is strange to not know what will happen if i do x, or go for y.How do i sum up my feelings as a player?I simply expected to have more fun. But i don't have fun (at least not much). It is hard to describe why and obviously "fun" is a very personal feeling. I replayed DK2 just now and have to admit: I have played MORE hours of DK2 since this game released then i played this game. It makes me want to play the "real deal". I also seem to use the word "strange" a lot to describe this game. That is because it gives me all sorts of strange feelings that i can not really explain. I expected a dungeon management game. I feel like i got a game that puts me under pressure to rush while giving me dozens of features that are not explained and / or don't feel worthwhile or rewarding. How do i sum up my feelins as a developer myself?This is actually easier to do. I know the feeling of being able to put in features, just because i can. But more is not always better. And i am quite sure this is what happened here. MP being the biggest problem / time waster (i still don't think the time investment is worth it for the general DK player / fan). So many features, without enough testing if they actually provide value and fun to the gamer.They should have put up the campain in early access. Let the people test how all the little gears work together. I am sure they would have gathered much valuable feedback and maybe shifted ressources in a more rewarding direction.It is actually sad to see to be honest. I see a team of VERY dedicated people that love a game and want to ressourcet it. You where on track but seem to have lost that track and got lost in the endless possibilities you have as a developer. They lost the view of what is FUN just to implement everything that is POSSIBLE. So no, i can not reccoment the game to a DK2 fan. Even tho it is the best current alternative, but it still fails to deliver on the aspects that made Dungeon Keeper fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												*EDITED* 15/9-2015I still really want to love this game because of what it wants to achieve, but instead i find myself in an unhealthy and abusive relationship with a game that constantly rapes my hopes and dreams. I start it up every now and then and try my best to find the spirit of the dungeon keeper series but it simply isn't there. The campaign seems like something that the developers just wanted done quickly. Every level is about rushing. There's no planning, no lovingly construction of your dungeon, no clever use of traps or spells. Only; get creatures -> plant rally flag -> win level -> repeat. And it really sucks because of all the other work the developers has put in this game. It overflows with GREAT ideas, AWESOME effects and simply a cornucopia of tools that beckons your inner evil overlord to come out and play. BUT HE IS BLUEBALLED EVERYTIME BY THAT FEKKIN RUSH MENTALITY!!!!As a bonus, your "home realm" in the campaing still suffers from a bug that teleports your creatures to the bottom left corner of the map, making them unable to be picked up, and makes the level inacessible when you try to re enter the level.___________________________________________________________________________________*Old review*To many bugs, i am currently unable to complete lvl 4 due to the game CONSTANTLY crashing and making savegames corrupted...I backed this game in the very early bedrock beta. Loved the ideas it had. Loved the potential. And in all fairness, the developers did a great job to carry on the spirit of the GREAT dungeon keeper. HOWEVER!!!!! Why on EARTH! would you leave the level design to a guy with utter and complete claustrophobia!? The levels does in NO way encourage dungeon building as much as it promotes a kind of shabby colony expansion on islands where every "room" (if you will waver your every definition of what constitutes a room) has its location and usefulness pre deciced FOR you by the shear lack of land to develop on.Furthermore...whats the use for reinforced walls in your dungeon when a normal dwarf can plow through it in seconds with NO way to save it...I would love to see this game ressurect my favourite game of all time, but first the game has to be playable...

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												What to say about this one? well I can't really say I was too disappointed by this game because it is the true Dungeon Keeper successor and I was never able to play that game due to it being too old and too finicky with modern systems to get running but I really wasn’t impressed by anything in this game either. It has good intentions but it's really not all that interesting, even going along the campaign and unlocking new abilities, traps and room types the game never got more exciting than the 'oh yay new dungeon management game, im sure this will be good!' thrill at the start.Here are categories on why I was barely able to enjoy the game:Storyline: 3/10What storyline? It's so bland and forgettable I'm pretty sure it's there so the devs could say 'we made a storyline!'. I can sum it in afew sentences. Your evil and stuff, you get betrayed by alot of other evil people you have kill on the way to the top, once you kill all forces of good and become the most evil dungeon lord you get betrayed in a very obvious way you could have predicted way ahead of time and poof game done, yep… seat clenching. It is a shame because surely someone can think of a neat storyline for an evil dungeon lord coming from the bottom all the way to the top of the world? Even if it was taken non seriously like a joke, “They made fun of your really cool hat, knocked over your letter box and keep killing your zombie collection for fun, they must pay!” might have been better. Meh, not a big gripe for a game like this but it never really feels like I have any incentive to killing all these 'good' characters and ruining their world other then, your bad mkay? kill stuff cas the game gives you no other options, ugh. What did they look at me wrong? call my mum a bad name? Not put the toilet seat down?! Why do I hate them to the point of torturing them!? The game never explains that, if it even could, it's not very fulfilling at all and it just made me want to end the game as quick as possible.Campaign: 4/10It took me barely 8 to 10 hours to get done, not alot of depth, not alot variety, a very linear experience from one click spot to the next, I don't know what more to say about this that wouldn’t repeat the storyline section, with no engaging storyline to follow the campaign felt pretty bland and meaningless. I was only doing it to get my monies worth out of the game about half way in and it just left me so unsatisfied at the end I ditched the game right after finishing it and never plan to come back to that waste of time and effort. If you’re looking for an amazing single player experience in this I’m sorry look somewhere else...Graphics and Visuals: 3/10Oh boy is this a major gripe. This must have been made on an old Unity engine cas as far as advancing gaming graphics goes it looks terribad, and I really wish I was exaggerating. Great models and textures but not the right game engine to show them off in! Even the lighting in this is nothing special, there is no real visual evidence that your dungeon is as evil ,dark and monster filled underground hell as it is supposed to be, I was never really fully immersed by it and that's such a disappointment. Oh yea and don't even get me started on the joke of an anti-aliasing option... it's either have sharp visuals with jaggies for days or mega FXAA that blurs the whole game to such a degree you can barely make out the details of a single object or texture *shudders*. Just, no, if you appreciate graphics like me you will have a depressing time here, again all this is to blame for the crappy Unity engine they chose.Performance: 2/10Performance, oh boy! You can imagine a game that's not open world with not much going on and poor visual fidelity will run great right? Well no, not at all, no hopes, again the Unity engine strikes to make this game run dreadfully on my gtx980 with 16gbs of RAM semi top of the range rig. On the last few missions my frame rate got down to a solid 12! I crap you not, 12!! If I was lucky I got 17 fps. With no optimization to be heard of this game will run like the alternative name for a donkey as soon as your dungeon gets to any decent size. I could have turned down the graphics maybe, but it already looked bad enough with no blurry AA on I didn't dare try, and on a gtx 980 why the heck should I have to?! Top of the line graphics cards aren't cheap for a reason right?Variety: 7/10Moving off the biggest gripes, the variety is pretty good, a large range of different room types which also equal a different minion type for most of them, spells, traps, side powers you can call on to help you out abit and even little ease of life constructs. The enemy sends you a decent variety of enemies to annihilate and you even fight other underlords at afew points, this is all great, if it weren't for the insanely boring combat that you have to endure with to progress...Combat: 3/10About all you can do is possession control a minion for some FPS interesting involvement but that gets boring quick due to a single minion never being able to make that much difference even while played by you. The only other thing you can do to help combat is the healing and rage spells and zapping enemies with lightning if they go on any of your territory and slip by, other than that it's just misc helpful spells to run the dungeon and spamming the attack banner around so your stupid minions actually move and attack everything else, nothing goes much deeper than that. Maybe I wasn’t being creative or was missing something? But I doubt it because I tried everything I was given, waiting for a crud ton of minions to spam then just blob charging them at the enemy was the only thing that seemed to work so I went with it for the whole campaign, not very engaging. =/CONCLUSION: Total 4/10I guess after all that the only final conclusion can be... don't waste your time and effort on this, really just don't. This is quite frankly the most boring dungeon management game I’ve played so far, it does nothing new from Dungeon 1, Dungeon 2 and Impire, I can actually say that Dungeon 2 is more fun purely because of interesting mechanics and a playable dungeon lord that always gives you something to do! This game however will consistently show you how bland an unengaging, unsatisfying management game can be. Other than building 5x5 basic 'blocked' rooms and doing some spells and building traps I never really felt like I had any reason to be in this game 'helping'. A disappointing shame but it happens, bad engine and not enough thought and depth put in by the devs. Even the management in Overlord 2 was cooler lol, the minions in that game had personality and where so loveably evil and fun.Buy this when it's majorly on sale if you really want or find something else because this really is a hit and miss for me and mind you I have played every dungeon management game I have found so far so hopefully everything I said holds enough water for you to believe me, because this review is in -your- interests.Thanks for reading, game smart, game on.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Plain and simple reason as to why you shouldn't play this game is that it isn't really finished. Minimap is useless. Constantly spams the units are under attack message. Countless bugs, (like minions never attacking). Difficulty spikes. The difficulty of each level in the campaign is either far too easy to be fun or borderline impossible to achieve. Torture chambers do not work. Certain rooms don't seem to function properly (beast lairs sometimes don't spawn monsters)Enemy mobs seem to be either killed far too quickly (rendering them pointless), or are far too powerful (making them frustrating to fight). The balence never seems to be fun. Games options menu is useless. Game performs poorly even when set to minimum graphics settings on a pc that really should be able to handle it. If you, like me, are stupid enough to buy this game in it's current state, then you are in for a massive let down. Give your money to a game developer who actually deserves it by not releasing unfinished games.

The only other thing you can do to help combat is the healing and rage spells and zapping enemies with lightning if they go on any of your territory and slip by, other than that it's just misc helpful spells to run the dungeon and spamming the attack banner around so your stupid minions actually move and attack everything else, nothing goes much deeper than that. Maybe I wasn’t being creative or was missing something? But I doubt it because I tried everything I was given, waiting for a crud ton of minions to spam then just blob charging them at the enemy was the only thing that seemed to work so I went with it for the whole campaign, not very engaging. =/CONCLUSION: Total 4/10I guess after all that the only final conclusion can be... don't waste your time and effort on this, really just don't. This is quite frankly the most boring dungeon management game I’ve played so far, it does nothing new from Dungeon 1, Dungeon 2 and Impire, I can actually say that Dungeon 2 is more fun purely because of interesting mechanics and a playable dungeon lord that always gives you something to do! This game however will consistently show you how bland an unengaging, unsatisfying management game can be. Other than building 5x5 basic 'blocked' rooms and doing some spells and building traps I never really felt like I had any reason to be in this game 'helping'. A disappointing shame but it happens, bad engine and not enough thought and depth put in by the devs. Even the management in Overlord 2 was cooler lol, the minions in that game had personality and where so loveably evil and fun.Buy this when it's majorly on sale if you really want or find something else because this really is a hit and miss for me and mind you I have played every dungeon management game I have found so far so hopefully everything I said holds enough water for you to believe me, because this review is in -your- interests.Thanks for reading, game smart, game on.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Kudos for remaking Dungeon Keeper. It was really time for a new game using this brilliant game principles. The Kickstarter campaign made clear, that there is a huge demand for this kind of game. WftO has two problems though: abysmal QA and completely missing the pace, that made DK great:Updates tend to break the game, make certain levels unplayable because no one seems to test how an "rebalancing" idea they implement actually fits into the single player campaign. I don't know if they don't test at all, are only interested in multiplayer game or someone who already mastered the game tries it out briefly. But when you are new to this game and think about investing money into this: Don't! You are not their target audience. They are themselves their only target audience. This would fit to an free, open source game, but not to a product that sells for money.DK had a brilliant feature, that made this whole "evil overlord" concept possible: you could play at your own pace. You could play aggresively with early attacks, before the enemy builds his base, or you could fortify, build up everything and flood the enemy with your über-army. You could be as unfair as you wanted to be. I agree that this is very hard to implement, but WftO fails miserably. It dictates the pace all the time: Timers don't give you time to build up your dungeon, Enemy attacks disrupt you all the time. There is either an oversupply or far to little gold. It treats you like a kid with a short attention span, constantly forgetting what your task was. And in doing so it just expects a certain playing style. It's not hard to play a level: it's hard to find out, how the developers expected you to solve the level, without giving you a chance to develop your own solution and this feels strange.Would be a good free game, doesn't feel like anything someone makes a living with.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												I was unable to go beyond the fourth campaign level as the game crashes at the same point every time, just as i destroy the enemy keepers heart. As your goal is to destroy what he is guarding i tried fixing it by lining it up so that i would blow up the wall needed to win the game right after destroying his heart, but the wall bomb was bugged and unable to be placed, even though i had taken over the tiles where i wanted to place it.Other bugs:When you want to load a game it "resets" the campaign progress so that the narrator starts over and visual bugs appear as the game wants you to do things that are already done.The imp flag to make your imps attracted towards it is again a nice mechanic, however i was unable to actually place the flag on the map, regardless if i owned the territory.If you start dragging out spacing to place a room, but regret it foces you to build a 1x1 tile, not being able to right click and regret placement.Besides that there is a few suggestions to making a better game overall.The flags you can put down to attract minions is a good mechanic, you would expect this would make the monsters "attack move" in starcraft fashion towards the flag, but instead it sort of makes the monsters sometimes ignore enemies and incomming damage to walk towards the flag.The imp flag to make imps not take over the territory is also smart as you can stop your imps from suiciding and going places you don't want them to, but it makes them not take over an area around the flag and so the imps will walk by it and still suicide. The map  is confusing compared to DK1. There is no option to size up the map and unlike DK1, there is no flashing on the map to indicate where you barracks and etc is placed. It also resets your camera angle when you want to jump somewhere on the map. This is made worse by allowing little space for constructing rooms and forcing, atleast in the early campaign levels, you to divide your dungeon onto little places. The rooms themselves seem to be disfunctional unless placed 3x3 tiles which punishes this.These are just some random things i wrote down, i waited to buy into the game until release hoping to avoid these sort of problems, but apparently not so. Let's just hope the developers haven't be satisfied with the money already made by early access and kickstarter campaign as it has potential, but still needs a lot of work. Be aware that if you buy this game it is about as functional as you would expect an early beta to be. I waited to post this until i had given that campaign level another few more tries.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												While War for the Overworld does a GREAT job in giving that nostalgic feeling of dungeon ke....I mean a dungeon game it is FAR from finished and should not be out of beta yet and here's why:- Basic assets are missing, 25-50% of monsterportraits show some form of "info missing" message meaning either poor packaging of assets or nonexistance- Wall'Hack' : minions, mainly monsters often glitch through doors and portcullises- Memory loss: this might just me my lowgrade pc, but some missions literally slowed down to 1 frame per several seconds- worker glitching: Regularly workers glitch in and out of objects placed and built indefinitely- Campaign missions have timers etc. but despite this still wave enemies in during wait times- The crypt mission bugged out so the necromancers stopped summoning corpses after defeating the big healer boss- If you have more minion types than your bar supports? bad luck brian, because thats all you'll see for direct controll- During mission 2 the helper says to place something so your workers dont run into the enemy camps, I still havent found out what since theres nothing on the HUD for that- Skirmish bots so far just die randomly. When I view their dungeon heart for example they die.What I missed:- label things with hotkeys so not everything has to be moused and label them so when you mouse-over you see the hotkey bound to it, really miss that feature.- Stats or anything describing the monster types to me in close up.- a sence of management issues like hungry or grumpy minions etc. They always seem content.- better timing of events in missions, while they seem fun if done right, most missions are either an unclear race or a slow grind.- no real use for alot of the spells and rituals etc. because the mana is simply better spent on healing and lighting most of the timeWhat i Loved;Dont get me wrong they are definately in the right direction- Kewl new monsters taking new roles while giving all the old roles their new counterpart for us nostalgia freaks- Good amount of chambers and monster types- Good narration and feel- Lovely soundeffects and ambianceI hope they work at it some more so they can polish my issues away. If so I might re-review, untill then I'd say don't buy it, unless you want to support the folks making this seeing its indie and all that.

												I'm enoying the game and yes there maybe some issues but it's not un-playable.  It's given me 2 - maybe 3 hours? of fun already. content:
Posted: April 8, 2015
												Never should have left early access/alpha. Frankly, the game is a mess and the further you dig into it the more that mess reveals itself. I can't finish a level without the darn thing freezing up.Also a lot of the additions to what is basically a remake of Dungeon Keeper 2 don't hold up. I don't know why I need to have to manage spells, rituals, constructs, potions, artifacts...the list goes on. There's just too much bloat; I don't think it will ever be a very good game. I'm still drawn to it because it's the closest we're gonna get to DK3 but the designers should have put more thought into how much these fiddly bits impact the game experience, and they should have squashed a few hundred more bugs before they pushed this out as a release game. War for the Overworld is the perfect example of what's wrong with Steam right now: supposedly a love letter to a lost genre, but with nothing of value to actually add to that conversation...and a willigness to fleece people with an unfinished game. Avoid.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2015
												I have waited a very long time for a new Dungeon Keeper game. A game that I did not ever get. I was so happy to see the video of Dungeon Keeper 3 in the copy of DK2 I had. I waited and waited and it never came. So I came to terms with that I would never play a game that awesome ever again. Then one day, I came across this game. I was in shock and awe. I couldn't believe it, a spiritural successor to Dungeon Keeper. I know I had the time to play the Beta but I never got it because I wanted to wait. I wanted to experience this game in full when it was done. So I avoided buying the beta and I did my best to avoid any news about the charcters in the game because I wanted to be surprised by it. I just got it a couple of hours ago and I am beyond happy with this game. This IS Dungeon Keeper. The narrator, the ability to slap your minioins. Everything about it screams Dungeon Keeper. I love every second of this game. I need to put more hours into it when I get some free time but you better believe I am going to play this game until my hands fall off. Even then I will play this game with my feet. I am happy that I waited on this game and I am happy with the results. The game has that dark humor like good old Dungeon Keeper. It has everything that I  loved about DK and I am beyond thrilled that it is this awesome. If you loved Dungeon Keeper in the past buy this game. If you've never played DK this is a good game to start off. The only thing I can say about this game is remotely bad is thatt I want more. More of everything. That isn't the creators fault, its just my lust for this game.  I wish I could meet the developers and throw my money at them in real life. Thank you creators. Thank you for picking up a game style that hasn't been really played in a long time.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2015
												I struggled to decide whether or not I would recommend this game.The problem I have with this game is that it tries so hard to be a successor to the Dungeon Keeper legacy.  In some respects, it succeeds.  For example, the gameplay itself is very much like (and somewhat better than) Dungeon Keeper 2.However, this game fails in a few important ways:1.) The levels themselves feel like watered down versions of their Dungeon Keeper equivalents.2.) The mentor equivalent in War For The Overworld sounds like the mentor in the Dungeon Keeper games (actually, IIRC, it's the same voice actor), but the lines delivered in War For The Overworld are nowhere near as witty and sarcastic as the lines delivered in the Dungeon Keeper games[dungeonkeeper.wikia.com].3.) When I last played the game (in September, I think), it still had its fair share of bugs.6/10.

												I've been waiting for this came for a long time, I even sat steady and waited after the terrible reviews of the early access to ensure my experience would be untainted, and it is safe to say I am massively disapointed in this game. I've put in 11 hours and I can't be bothered to finish the thing. The AI is terrible, the game is boring, the lag is painful (even when you put it to the lowest texture and pixel settings). As a lover of the first DK and a player of the second I want to make it clear that my thoughts on this game, are written in the absract, I didn't get this game out of nostalgia, I bought it because I thought it might actually be good. Also - nice try on the comedy aspect with your narrator - but after a while it gets stale and then just irritating. Honestly I'd struggle to pick something positive to say, because all the positive things about this game are just OK, their not great or even good - just OK. I just didn't have fun.Honestly I'd like my money back.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Thats it... I have officially had enough of this joke of an industry.I wont go into too much detail on the many problems this unfinished release has, as it is mentioned numerous times by others (tooltip problems, crap AI, game breaking crashes etc etc). In addition to all of this their latest update has now made the game run in a cinematic 3fps! I kickstarted this game, and I am now totally regreting that decision and this has now put me off kickstarter altogether. How many times do developers in this industry need to release buggy, unfinished, broken messes before they get the message that we are tired of this♥♥♥♥♥♥ No other industry would allow for companies to release products that dont work, with a "Oh dont worry, we'll fix it later" attitude. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to that. In that case why dont you refund me and you can "get my money later, you know, when the product is actually done!"They have shot themselves in the foot with this. This is a long way off from being finished, and by the time all the issues are fixed, we would have all moved on. People have busy lives, and I for one don't appreciate my spare time being wasted with broken products that I have paid for. When you start charging for a product, you have responsiblilties to meet, and if you can't meet those then dont release the game until it is ready. But no, there is this inpatient greedy mentallity behind companies today where they want it out now, to get money asap, and it's us who ultimately pay the price by paying for broken games.This game ultimately has great potential and could have been the terrific dungeon keeper sequel we all wanted. But in the end, this works about as well as a bottomless bucket. So well done devs, you screwed it up. I am not going to waste any more of my time on this, and i am moving on to other things. If any of you are thinking of buying this game, don't. And if by some miracle this game has not fallen off everyones radar by the time it is in a working state, get it then.This downright sloppy, dishonest, greedy, and money grabbing practice needs to stop. Its crap like this that will ultimately lead to another video game crash, and maybe that is what needs to happen for all these devs to get the damn message. Disappointed and robbed.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												This is not a completed game. It has bugs ranging from subtitles not showing to the one time I was trapped looking at a minion because it spawned in (for the first time which triggers an explanation of the minion in question) and the explanation audio for the scene didn't load, which apparently stops the game from letting you do anything because even the usual skip button for this game (spacebar) didn't function. "Display options" has maybe a total of seven things that can affect framerate, if you count what size you want the game window to be and whether you want windowed or fullscreen (I don't) and three more are binary options (no I don't count "force-enable" as different than enable), the remaining two are "pixel light count" and "texture resolution" which you can bring down to a stunning eighth of the original value, which is higher than it needs to be for a game where I will spend the entire time zoomed out too far to notice any of the character models regardless. The sound options are between acceptable and as expected. The gameplay would be better if there weren't massive framerate drops every five minutes on the dot and if I didn't have 4 untouchable minion corpses and another four minions in the "shadowlands," or rather innacessible in a corner of the map blocked off by bedrock (no way in, no way out.) Those are all my problems thus far, and they don't make the game *absolutely* unplayable, just very, very difficult to enjoy. This wasn't in early access when I bought it. I was promised a completed game, this isn't it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												I wanted this game to be great.  I still play DK2 I love the franchise so much.This game is a perfect example that there's more to making a good meal than throwing in all the ingredients you can think of.  That mysterious thing "fun" got lost somewhere along the way.  It's a shame really because I think some fine tuning could really make this game a winner!Other than the mish-mash of elements that somehow don't work the graphics are not good.  The original game with far "simpler" graphics was actually much clearer.  With this reboot the background graphics are too detailed so the minions seem to get lost against them.  They don't stand out the way they should.Also the narrator is more annoying than funny.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												I bought into early access release of this game because I believed in the credibality of the developers promises. A month prior to the Dungeons 2 release this got released from early access due for what I believe to jump on the market. A terrible decision. I would rather this game spend as much time as needed in development like DayZ then be rushed out the door.I spend my hard earned money on early access games because I WANT to support the developers, because I believe in their dreams, and again I am let down. This time from a more trusted developer who I wanted to see succeed. Yet another harsh lesson that early access games are never worth it.If WFTO will be worth buying it isn't now, and not until it is the game it should be.Don't buy it, if you want a dungeon keeper-esq game, buy its competitor, Dungeons 2, which is a more complete game.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												So, I gotta say the devs really care about the game. Just see the low below :)Old review:Like Dungeon Keeper 2. Just a bad version of it.The game is still buggy as hell. Worst of all is the cursor, you just never know where exactly it is pointing. That is especially frustrating when trying to place prisoners in the torture chamber.Edit 29.07.:Hi, LeeFirst of all, cool that you guys took the effort of replying here. Never saw a dev do that before!I looked into what you told me and you're right. There is a light beam, I just never realized as it is very hard for me to see. So there is no real problem and sorry for claiming there would be one!The bug happened in the introductory level for the prisons (2nd level of the red circle to the right in campaign mode I think). I enlarged the captured prison and later tried to move prisoners from the second one (with the lvl10 bard) to another, which resulted in the new prisoner being killed. The same happened for me when I picked up the lvl10 bard and dropped him in the same prison again. All the other prisoners ganked up on the new guy and killed him for good. As I never did this in later levels, I tried that as well and it doesn't appear to be a problem there, so I don't know if that was a special problem or not.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												This game is a rehash of Dungeon Keeper 2, so if you enjoyed that game, you'll enjoy this.  The added systems of 'sins' and new rooms don't add a lot to the game so you might be better off just getting an old copy of DK2 and playing that.There are numerous bugs still present even after the enormous update that rolled out a few days ago.  For instance, I had to manually change the screen resolution within a text file because it was permanently set to 600x400 in game.  Also, most of my minions couldn't cross the bridge to fight the final boss.  Add in the very low framerate when you have more than 15-20 creatures on the same screen.The end of the game cliffhangs to get you to buy the expansion.  The whole game took about 8 hours to finish.  The skirmish mode, while complete, isn't really hours of fun.Really, just get Dungeon Keeper 2 online and save your $20.

content:
Posted: April 21
												When this game was released, I had a great time playing it. It ran seamlessly on a fairly old computer, the graphics were brilliant, the characters entertaining, and I was really pleased with it overall. After the 1.6 patch, and the introduction of the 'My Pet Dungeon' expansion, as well as a new computer...invisible menus, in-game crashes, lots of instability, resulting in a lot of time wasted trying to find solutions to why it's just all gone♥♥♥♥♥♥up. I've found eventually a webpage link duried deep in the discussion boards that lists what looks like an hour or two testing and fixing this, that and the next thing, and the excuse given is that some part of the middle-ware seems to not work with some computers...and that's my spare time for a bit of gaming down the pan. Seems a crock to me. I paid full price for the game, which did work once upon a time, and now it's unplayable. I shouldn't have to be scratching my head and fixing errors. It should be in a playable state if you're charging money for it. That said, I was with card at the ready to buy this new expansion, but after this let down, I won't bother. You've already had enough money off me for a game that now doesn't run for me at all. In this state, I can't recommend it. I will say that it has enormous potential and needs the Dev's to fix it.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												I've been a fan of Bullfrog's Dungeon Keeper games since the first one was released in 1997, and so, when I heard that a spiritual successor called War for the Overworld was in the works, my interest was piqued to say the least.  I followed the development of WftO during the past year or so, and when I saw its release date finally come around, I excitedly offered up my $26.99. After all, the hundreds of reviews for the game in early access were "very positive."  How could that many people be wrong?  Right?I've never been impressed with the concept of "early access" games.  If I wanted to pay for the privilege of using broken, buggy, unfinished software, I could just install and boot up Windows.  This is why I wait for official releases before I start playing any game.  I don't need the added frustration and tedium that early access games bring to my PC, so I respectfully abstain. Or at least that's what I thought before I bought War for the Overworld.When I first launched it, the game told me that it was version 1.0, the official release build, but damned if I can tell from how it plays.  And this game isn't easy to play, by the way.  As soon as I got to the third mission, the game's video began to freeze for what had to be ten to twenty seconds at a time - an unplayable mess. From what I read now, I'm not alone in this.  The mini map is completely useless, looking like some pixelated mess dredged up from two decades ago.  When I first saw it, I had the idea that this must be what people who read tea leaves see in the bottom of their cup.  One would have to be some kind of mystical seer to divine any useful information from it.I'm tempted to go on, but it's all been said in other reviews.  You should read some of them.  I should have waited to read some of those reviews BEFORE I made my purchase, not AFTER.  I've got only myself to blame for wasting my money.  Please don't waste yours on this unfinished game.  Don't stand for "release now, patch later (if you're lucky)" business practices.  Vote with your wallet, and maybe game developers will start to realize that they're not doing themselves any favors by pasting a v1.0 on an obviously unfinished product.

												Yeah, its Dungeon Keeper!Sadly i can not recommend it :(Minor problems:Game engine: - Grafic look silly up close and gets ugly up far (might as well play DK)                        - handling of the mouse is clunky                        - menus seem to run in a different task -> feels clumsy-> Its just not a good game engine, but its "indie" so well ...Unfinished state: - the game lacks a lot of stuff and actually still (12 patches in) hold placeholders                             - some toolstips are still missing e.g on every structure or NPC that has 2 or more stages/modes                             - a whole lot just got patched in for release and was never tested in early access-> unwise desitions and masking of errorsBigger problems:Unfinished state: - some parts of the game are still missing and are already annouced as DLCs                             - critical features (e.g. 4 ppl mp) are still not in the game                             - the (so far 12) patches seem premade: they focus on balance and small features to keep the dev                                                team in a good light but do not focus actual ("after release") problems-> sloppy and decieving workbugs and glitches: - spells do not work, rooms do not work, minions vanish-> know issues carried over from early access that are not adressed in teh reasent patchesgame features: - rooms do no longer need walls and do not feature wall-items                          - monsters do not interact with one another over more then need of food-> makes a good (completly unoriginal) gameplay lesser"Do not buy" problems:RAM useage and lags: - after building a big dungeon (you or anyone else on the map), the game lags and becomes                                         unplayable-> was "ok" in early access but not finishing this is a joke for a releasedisconnects in mp and need for open ports: - topic-> makes the expirience no fun and combined with the lagging its unplayableFinaly:Its 3 days after teh ninja-release and we are 12 patches in, but still have all the major problems from teh early access. The new content (at least 70 %) was never tested and the patches focus on balance and grafic solo. Still we can get news about upcomeing DLCs ....Not only should you not buy this, but you should avoid buying from these ppl ever again.I am open to change this to recommanded when it starts working and i do not feel screwed over, but i realy do not think that that is proppable.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												I wouldn't reccomend this game to people who likes strategy and sandbox games, as there's next to nothing of these genres in it.Every now and again I open WFTO to see new changes and stuff. Everytime goes like "wow, this is cool", then "THIS IS IMPOSSIBLE TO PLAY!"There's so many bugs (lots of people have complained, I don't need to spell them out), but the worst one, if I shouldn't just call it poor design, is: Mission 6. Your dungeon heart is just next to the enemy's dungeons, you're supposed to build a beast den, sure, makes sense, but you can't build a beast den with no money, not to mention no room! There was no tiles with gold anywhere either, and the entire screen was covered in fog of war. I had to check tiles by highlighting them in the dark. So no gold, no minions, no war. I could just stare at the screen and be confused and frustrated.So I try to take over the prison and the game complains "Build a beast den!". Immediately after releasing the creatures from the prison it is payday. Great. And no money - tada! Also, there would be no food for tired warriors either. How would you like the odds of defeating an entire army with five tired minions? It forces you to drive headfirst into a long battle until it's either won or lost.Other than that, every level starts with your dungeon heart right next to the enemy's dungeon (mind I only got to lv 6), enemies come crashing in constant waves, you have no room to build a decent dungeon with square rooms because you start every game with a carved out dungeon, ready-placed rooms and or tiny islands everywhere for your own enjoyment. Your defence systems aren't worth the gold because the enemies just plough right through them.I would much rather have enjoyed the slow-paced "get to know the game" campaigns, which campaigns are supposed to be like. Like in the DK2 (didn't play the first): you start with a few available rooms and you play around and get to know them and the play style as long as you need or want to. The Developers could at least have created it so people could use whatever play style they like. Slow paced or fast paced. Like... build, play around in how much time you want to or get a ton of minions and crash the enemy's party.Overall I don't enjoy this game. I start out with a feeling of awe, then after a few minutes I get frustrated, disappointed and extremely annoyed. It's not strategic and gets to be more like a "hack n' slash" tower defence.As someone else said - it's just a shadow of an old game. Nothing more. There's not much new in it, but there's not much of the old game either. It's just a template with no soul.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2016
												I think this might be my first review ever.  I was a huge fan of Dungeon Keeper and Dungeon Keeper 2 and was so excited about this game, I was a backer for the game and have followed it for quite some time.It isn't nice to play, I know it is meant to be evil but the problem is the units don't work well.  When fighting they bounce and float around, they all stack and pile on each other, deselecting things is sometimes quite hard (potions for example) and you can't cancel build orders for potions either.The game feels like Dungeon Keeper in a lot of respects but not just in the good ways, it feels like a game from 10 years ago.  I was hoping for a new & improved game with lots of awesome extra little things, information and a game that really got you involved.  This game is not that, I wouldn't recommend spending the money on this semi finished fairly lame attempt at Dungeon Keeper 3 which ended up being Dungeon Keeper 1.5.  If you've played DK before skip this game as there is nothing that feels new or exciting and if you haven't then skip this game as it will feel outdated and buggy.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												While I do enjoy this game I must give it a thumbs down because while this game looks like Dungeon Keeper... it is not Dungeon keeper.  While this game has all the trappings of DK series, the goofy monsters, the dungeon building, the game voice narrirator,  this is not a true DK3.The glaring difference between this and the previous 2 DK games comes in the level of level creativity and ability to explore.  This game quickly becomes a giant dogpile of troops rushing to the end.  It lacks the exploration element in DK 1&2 that are so essential to the overall feel of the game.  The zerg rush of the game gets so bad that rooms like the workshop are utterly useless.  You can't build doors and traps because you are constantly summoning your monsters to engage the enemy or rush the end lair.  You can't take any time because the AI is too agressive or the level is under a timer.  Unlike the games predecessors that allowed you to meticulously plot your dungeon, explore every nook and crany for all the secrets and craft the army you want you are in an RTS scramble to build as quickly as you possibly can and that saps alot of the enjoyment out of the game.I hope that if they release DLC (a 2nd campaign) the creators really sit back and change the whole tempo of the game.  While the game looks like Dungeon Keeper it plays more like the Warcraft franchise.  If I wanted to play Warcraft/Starcraft I would have picked that up instead of DK3.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												5/10Over the years I've heard about the Dungeon Keeper franchise and from what I read, War for the Overworld is considered the third installment of the series. Being a fan of strategy games and seeing it on sale, I decided to go for it and snagged myself a copy. Honestly and despite giving it a fair chance, I just couldn't get into it. The strategy is so one-dimensional that I didn't feel engaged or challenged and quickly grew bored. However, the graphics though are solid and I didn't encounter a single issue with the game, it's smooth and the user interface is well designed. But, the voice acting - holy s--t it's awful, but I'm sure tongue-in-cheek comments were a lot funnier in the studio.

content:
Posted: April 4
												Excellent game - a brilliant follow on from Dungeon Keeper, that really retains the feel of the originals while adding in a LOT of new features. It's also less micro-managy - there are a lot of different units, and it won't tell you their stats, so you kind of have to just build based on what production you want, and hope they can fight if necessary. It's an interesting take on the concept - that your priority is building up an awesome dungeon, rather than fighting the enemy. I like it though, it's a neat twist and works well - certainly a lot better than any competing dungeon management games.Note that it is still (3+ years after release) buggy, and will crash and lose your game occasionally.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												The game is similar to Dungeon Keeper I and II but its not it completely. BUGS are killing this game... Literally. I DO NOT RECCOMEND BUYING THE GAME UNTIL THEY FIX SOME OF THE BUGSThere were countless bug fixes but there are even more to fix. I have been stuck on the last mission for a couple months because save/load is not working properly. The basic function of the game such as save/load does not work. If I were you I would not make same mistake like I did and bought the game before they fixed bugs. Think about it this way 4 months since release and yet they did not finish save / load function of the game. Thats besides multiple creater AI problems, lack of monster progression.Overall this and Dungeons II were 2 of the better replicas of the good old Dungeon Keeper II. And while the Dungeons II humor and overall feel is a bit lacking compared to War for the Overlord its still a better game because it has a more polished product, different races / sides and more in depth character progression... Even though War for the Overlord had a potential to become the best DK II replica...Lack of Sense of Monster progression. In DK and DK II when your monsters level up they become more powerful especially when they reach level 4, 8, 10. The progression in this game is very limited - creaters do get some lesser abilities but their HP pools overall stay the same. In DK 1 level 10 creater was very hard to get but once he is level 10 he can slaughter multiple level 1s. In this game different between level 10 and 1 is roughly 10-20% of overall strength. Whi this is a bad thing - well it encourages treating your creaters like sensless armies and send them on their death time and time again rather than makign sure they are happy with your dungeon and progress in levels.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
 A True Disappointment I cannot for the life of me fathom how it has taken the developers years to produce this terrible game. What disappoints me is that I supported the game from the beginning and feel I've been patient over the years with its bugs and faults. But over 2 years on and it's still a complete mess.It's impossible to list everything that's wrong with the game, I actually tried but my review was too long for steam, so if that doesn't tell you enough then by all means buy it and see for yourself...If I had to choose one thing that got to me the most, it would be the animation. I mean they haven't even tried, the characters can walk and perform a basic attack, and that's more or less the extent of it.I can only reach the conclusion that the developers have used the money paid in by its supporters and ensured that they have been given decent wages with lots of perks, because it is clear that very little of the years they have had to develop this game has actually been spent doing so. To top it off, I have seen that they have the audacity to release an exanpsion to the game! The game is utterly and laughably incomplete, it's a joke and I would under all circumstances not advise anybody to purchase this game, your money will not be well spent and any hopes that it will be efficiently used to improve the game is unforeseeable. I would accept a refund in a heartbeat, following the progress and seeing the end result has been a complete waste of my time.Save your money, play Dungeon Keeper again, it's a much better game that was developed a decade before this one was.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								War for the Overworld -Pre Release ReviewGameplay & Mechanics-The game play is pleasant, the developers did a good job on the fluidity and ease of controls.  The camera is locked into a overhead mode, this sometimes is annoying when trying to verify your dungeon layout and design.  I did not notice any skill hotkeys; however, I might have overlooked this feature in a menu/sub-menu. This game offers the player four types of usable skill mastery's. Building magic, Attack magic spells, Minons, and Defensive structures.  Playing through the first three campaigns offers little insight to the end game viability of building magic and/or defensive skills.  defensive skills as you quickly learn in campaign 3 take up a specific amount of MP based on the structure from your mana/energy pool.  This limits the amount of defensive structures that a player is able to build. I did notice however; while tinkering around in skirmish mode, advanced walls do not take up MP/energy. Unfortunately once built, the walls cannot be sold or taken down.Value--------------------------Currently keeping in mind that the game is in pre-alpha, I would not purchase this game again if I had the chance.  The negatives outnumber the positives on this one.  My advice save your money until game hits 50/70% off.Pro's-----------------------------------Wity humorDungeon design tools are solidNon game destroying bugs "this is a good thing in my book"Solid minion diversityCon's-----------------------------------------------Camera is locked in overhead without a way to rotateMinion's are capped (in skirmish I was only able to get 9 in each type of minion roughly 40-50 minions)Defensive structures limit spell usage and have a low cap (about 15 Mix & Match)Worker minions are limited (if you go over "via build spell" limit they take MP away like defensive structures)Minions are inefficent, for example they leave tiles unclaimed when making rooms that are not square. (dont forget you cannot rotate the camera to correct this)Minion AI is inefficent when fighter minnions are rallyed to a specific location (with complex dungeon design)Review------My review is based off of 5 hours of campaign and skirmish tests of a alpha/pre-alpha game. As such the released version of the game may differ greatly from its current state.  My review is only meant to offer my opinion of the game as it stands today 04/01/2015.  I believe this game has potential however; several other emerging games might offer more $/hr of enjoyment value.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												The prospect of a new Dungeon Keeper made me back this with little hesitation back in 2012 when the Kickstarter ran. Videos from the beta I watched about a year ago gave me some trepidation, but I had hope that it would turn out alright given that there was still more time to improve it. Now that time is up and version 1.0 is out - and I'm really sad to see what the project has come to: This is a woefully unfinished game, not at all ready to be released! It's not just about lack of polish: Animations are jerky and rough or simply missing (slap a piglet and it simply disappears), creatures in combat move around chaotically making it hard to know what's going on, glaring bugs are aplenty - gamebreaking bugs - some game modes are unfinished, the minimap is nigh useless and on top of that the game is poorly optimized. I've never seen such an incomplete game pushed to release and can only surmise that it has to be desperation move by the developers. I suspect this project has been seriously mismanaged and poorly planned out from an early stage. There are many additions beyond the mechanics of the original games and many good ideas among those. The textures are pretty nice and it has the same narrator voice as the originals. How then are basic features like a proper minimap not in place? Why does the core gameplay feels so erractic and why is the relevant feedback on what's going on in the dungeon so sparse? After all this development time? Poorly balanced fluff features? And from the steam achievement you can see that the campaign only has 13 missions (compare that to the 20 of DK1)I must conclude that the developers didn't have the experience, skills and resources to make the game we all wanted and thus failed to deliver. "Game will be patched." "More content to be added." "It has potential." Yadada-ya! - These are the funeral hymns failed games usually receive. Maybe this game will be completed at some point in the future. I wouldn't get my hopes up though, and based on the development speed up to this point it definitely won't be soon. Don't buy this game before you hear convincing reports that it actually has been completed!Instead, get the originals from GoG if you're craving for a dungeon sim.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												In many ways this is a game with great potential. I only got 2 days ago, and after playing for a bit I figured out that ok, it's an early access game and there's a lot of work ahead. Today is the 1.0 release, and I am hoping this is a late april fools joke, but it's true. I'd say the game is still in mid-beta stage. It's a fun little game, but by no means a full fledged game ready for release. As many people mentioned it borrows heavily from DK, and anyone who has played it back in the old days will feel at home. The UI is in many ways exactly the same, and it has a few cool new features like alchemy or tech tree. But as I said it's still an underdeveloped beta game. There are major bugs in the campaign, in-game textures are very poor, skirmish offers only 3 maps (all for 2 players only), battle animations are wonky and/or look like temporary placeholders, with a 5x5 study you plow through the entire tech tree in 4-5 minutes tops... Don't get me wrong, THIS WILL BE A GOOD GAME. In a few months. Todays release is a mistake, and if you're considering buying the game hoping for regular gameplay, keep in mind that as of today, you're still signing up for beta testing. Buy a copy of DK2 somewhere and fiddle with it for a month or two, then come back. Maybe it will be a full game then.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This has been my first experience of 'War of the Overworld' and Steam in general and it has not been a favourable one.Upon starting up the game I am greeted with a black screen as it attempts to load. The endless blackness drew me in and opened my mind to such deep philosophical questions as 'is it ethical to allow people to buy a product that clearly does not work?', 'how can releasing an incomplete game even be legal?' and 'how the hell do I get my freakin' money back?!'. Upon resolving myself with the less than satasfactory revelations these questions posed, a flash of blinding light released me from the hold of the load screen and I read the words, 'WFTO has stopped working' - which is quite a feat considering it never worked in the first place.This game does not work. And when, by some miracle, it does work, it still does not work; it is too slow to be played and I can barely navigate the tedious menu. The only way to make this game work is to find a previously downloaded file called 'Dungeon Kepper 2' and play that instead.I am very unhappy with WFTO. I am very unhappy with Steam. And very unhappy with the stain the combination of these two "products" have placed upon the gaming industry in genereal. It's like paying upfront for an apple and then discovering it's rotten. And also that it's a melon.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. DO NOT SUPPORT STEAM.
