content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												After a prolonged period of early access time, the game's finally been rushed out and it's still pretty god damn awful despite numerous updates and attempts to add more content.There's a mission where the game decides to throw a constant stream of 180 dwarves at you with only 15 minutes of preperation time beforehand.Regardless of what you do, you die.There's not enough time to rebuild your forces even if you go insane with prisons and torture chambers. (It probably doesn't help that your succubi die far too quickly for them to be of any use. The best part is when your creatures become tired and then try to go to sleep in their lairs on very little health (there's never enough mana to heal everything), so what happens is that your creatures get murdered in their sleep by the invading 180 dwarves. The best thing however is when your creatures aren't being attacked for a nanosecond and then decide to go to the treasure room for payday, and conveniently the dwarves have a nice big wave coming in at that time. Oh boy oh boy oh boy. The main problem with this game is that it tries to copy dungeon keeper 2 way too much, even though it's the second worse dungeon keeper game. This game has a really crappy atmosphere and all the creatures are a load of wank and there doesn't seem to be enough depth in the right places. Sure it's got the ~veins of evil~ but that's just a messy list of tech upgrades that just give you more useless/highly situational abilities that you'll use once in a mission that requires you to use it and then you'll never use it ever again. There's also no level editor which really sucks because these dungeon keeper style of games would be really great with level editors. Instead of trying to balance the campaign so that it's actually playable past mission 7, the developers seem to be making a survival mode instead which I assume is an even more poorly designed version of mission 7. It's a real shame that every game that tries to emulate dungeon keeper's success/style just ♥♥♥♥s it up completely.

												This review based on single-player campaign only. I bought the game just before launch and then waited several weeks for the big patch before playing. The reason being that in the beginning the game menu and save/load screens were very laggy. The patch has improved this though there are still long load times.  I didnt have any problems with performance during gameplay until towards the end of the campaign where the large maps and number of enemies made it almost unplayable on some levels. I pushed through to the final level only to be stopped cold by a bug that wouldnt let me finish. (the invisible barrier...sigh)I was a big fan of the old Dungeon Keeper and so wanted to like this game but in the end I just felt more frustration then fun while playing. The graphics are good and the old narrator is back but the charm for me is missing. Since there's no neutral rating I'm going to have to give this a No.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												It looks like a cool game, but I can't play it on my 2015 iMac. WftO crashes consistently on the loading screen for the first level of the first campaign. In addition, there are glitchy garbled rectangles in the app loading screen, and a few places where the UI is briefly unresponsive and audio cuts out before returning to normalcy. I suspect the game was not well-tested on Macs. I'm normally more charitable with buggy software, and tend to talk to developers through private channels to resolve issues. But since there is no free demo or shareware to try before taking the leap and buying the game, I'm the one that loses here, and potentially other Mac gamers. Please fix your serious bugs.

number of helpful: 4 of 14 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												This game is NOT Dungeon Keeper. If you aren't looking for a modernized Dungeon Keeper then maybe you will enjoy War for the Overworld, but if you are I'm sorry to say this is another dud.  It's clear that the creators of this game wanted to make a clone, they even got the same voice actor for narration. but they didn't execute it well enough.  The visual and narrative style of this game takes itself way too seriously, and overall the game seems like it's trying way too hard to be cool.  Every level is a gimmick and is geared towards the AI having a distinct advantage.  The campaign is annoying and tedious, with almost no standard destroy the opponent missions and many timed objective based ones instead.  In addition this game is poorly optimized and regularly skips during play for no reason. I could go on about my complaints but the bottom line is that this game is no Dungeon Keeper, if that's what you want you should boot up DK2 and replay it...that's what I'm doing.

number of helpful: 1 of 8 people (13%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 4, 2015
												Campaign is awful at the minute, levels are far too linear and some are near impossible until you lose and know exactly what will happen, there's barely any freedom in levels to actually build your own dungeon, 70% of the levels you're given 5-15 minutes to build an army or defences then bombarded with enemies.The number of useful traps, spells and creatures feels a bit lackluster - I found myself only using a handful of the creatures, traps only when I was forced to and the only spell I used was create imps. Rituals and constructs are a nice touch but rituals also feels pointless, once again never used them unless I had to in campaign. Definitely needs more useful rituals, spells, traps, etc.Skirmishes and multiplayer are meh, found myself giving up on multiplayer because it's a mess and skirmishes are good but needs more options.I can honestly say I wouldn't recommend this game even to my friends who like dungeon keeper/starcraft/etc, which is unfortunate because i've been following this game for a few years and while I didn't have my hopes set that high, I expected a bit more.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												I am a huge fan of the original Dungeon Master game, and so kickstarted this game hoping for a similar feeling. It seems like they managed to recreate everything except for the "feel" of the units. It reminds me of when games first transitioned to 3d, and everything was unclear and awkward. The movement of the creatures feel like there is no weight - they seem to glide more than move, and I can't really distinguish the attacks that they make when they are fighting, and the sounds don't really engage me. I'd say this is definitely decent for an indie game, but it really doesn't have the same magic as Dungeon Keeper.

number of helpful: 0 of 6 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2015
												I have had this game since it debuted as early access and as I write this it's now been several weeks since the "release".Regretfully for someone who loved Dungeon Keeper II, this game is simply not good on several fronts. First off, it's far from anything remotely deserving of being called "released". It's barely playable, the framerate is in the single digits (and I have a beefy computer). The interface is entirely inadequate, there are a bunch of rooms that Ihave no idea what they do or how to use them and it isn't explained anywhere.For a game that set out to improve on DK2, on that count they have failed. The gameplay is bland, the maps are poorly designed, the missions are boring and drag on and on (made worse by the abysmal framerate). Of all the amazing traps of DK and DK2, this game has like four. Which all suck. Perhaps in an attempt to disguise that, the traps have toggleable "modes" but I have no idea what they do, the interface doesn't tell and I forgot what the tutorial said when they were introduced 5 missions back.If you're feeling nostalgic for DK2, just play DK2 again.

content:
Posted: May 2, 2016
												I would like to state that my whole review will be extremely biased, offensive and discriminative against game types, publishers and developers so if you become easily offended please do not read this review. But I believe the hard-core gamers will understand me even if they will not agree with me.First: I don’t think that there will be ever any middle level or above Dungeon Keeper (DK) fun that will be pleased with this game. You know that for most of us, our scariest nightmare is either the developer or the game itself to be bought by the company gamEs for retArts (gEAy games). It is usually means either the death of the series, or the idea, or the product or the any original thing in that production or the producer group. We are already not expecting any creative or exotic or extreme ideas or games from a company who only focuses on sales thus only produces football, basketball and f. king racing games that have no atmosphere, no story, no emotion, no idea, no intelligence,  for shosers. Yes these people are not gamers they are definite anti-social shosers who are not able to pick a ball and play at their garden, (or they can be minors but again same brain age) whatever… Hence we were not expecting anything that can satisfy us from the gEAy or any company controlled by gEAy as a sequel of DK, or Black and White (BW). That company is created for rounded games and for rounded people to kick so no offense for them.Second: On the other hand, you emerged from nothing in order to revive a cult game. Yes DK is a cult game with no similar and especially the first one was not designed for everyone. With the music, difficulty, ideas, strategies… it was unique. -	It was far serious than the DK2-	Even the names of the spells and the narrator were the part of the dark atmosphere-	Game was not too short and there were strategic options on the map.-	Blood-gore level was far more higher-	The player and its dark army was the evil part however was not the strongest, there were characters like Avatar who can take your whole horde down at least 3 times. -	The game was difficult. It was not possible to finish the game in few days.-	The map and the ongoing story were far more darker and had a perfect atmosphere-	Music were dark and suitable to the environment-	The creatures were giving the feeling of the intelligence-	Even there were conflicts between some creatures such as wizards and vampires, bile demons and skeletons...etc. so it was difficult to organise the dungeon.-	There were many details for captives, it was required different procedures to make them ghost, skeleton, vampire.. etc.-	There were more torture machines and screams than the WAR for Overword and this was the main concept of the game so F… you.-	Was not automatically finishing the level when you win the mapThird:  Yes DK2 was different. It has not got some of the above characteristics however it had some other things that made it acceptable as a sequel and successful for fanatics like me.-	This time we had black humour and the deep darkness of the game was a bit broken by the jokes and short clips.-	However the gore was there with more colourful wars, aggressive atmosphere and action.-	The music was gone crazy. It was best experience I ever had with intelligence system that changes the music with increasing aggression in the game. The music was sometimes the war atmosphere itself. Many times forced me to possess and join to the bathe with them.-	Ok spells were not mystical and powerful like DK… No plague, no armaggedon, no shield.. but still they were colourful and functional. Yes they really lack when you compare with DK but yes as long as you can have bile demons behind you and go to battle as a dark knight or dark angel aside with horned reaper…. Yes still acceptable-	Horned reaper become an exceptional creature/character with a call function but hey that was fun. It was amazing to feel that artificial intelligence of heroes make you feel their fear they felt against horned reaper.-	The game was not short again. She story was more colourful and rich. There were lots of levels with various difficulties.-	Narrator was more active bit funny but was not NPC of the game who intends be the secret antagonist in the game.-	Was not automatically finishing the level when you win the map-	The king with two blades and stone guardians were epic at the end of the game. And it was a real feeling of shame when the game ended. We all wanted and desired for more.-	Still we were the evil side there were no “corrupted king” that yells as “kill me hahaha take the flesh on me set me free because developers are bunch of story f…ing unintelligent midiots”Fourth: Ok we all know about copyright issues, difficulties of being an independent company, trying to develop something on a heritage of a good game etc. However If you are going to use the name “War for the Overworld” it means you have come up with something that can really be a continuation of DK games with higher quality and more offerings. Otherwise you can change the name of the game as “Dungeons” do not claim anything from the DK heritage, make a funny and rubbish game like this than we never blame you. On War for the Overworld-	We haven’t see any war above the ground. That name was intended for that purpose, you remember? DK3 was planned to be the story of rising over the ground from the dungeons… Even the funny game “Dungeons 2” made it with a way which combines Warcraft 3 and DK2, but you… nope sorry…-	Game was ridiculously short.-	Other underlords and their jokes were disgusting.-	The creatures… Yes you have to offer new ones I can completely understand. And a succubus was a good substitute for the mistress. And ogre was a good idea. Beast master was different but not functional. But what the f… is a Chunder? Do you think that what you placed a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ troll in game and make it fart like a bile demon it will become a substitute for both of them? It is not even a Bileroll or Trol Demon.-	Yes it became really fancy to summon a vampire and to feed them. Necromancers were good too and that ghouls may replace skeletons. But sorry you still lack of black knights and dark angels (or something that can be substitute of them)-	Bile demons and horned reaper were signature creatures. I understand that you cannot replace them easily with something else. But you had chance to reference them in game. They were the atmosphere of DK and DK2. Not even a easter egg … f.. you! -	Titans…. No, sorry. They are neither unique nor add something to the gameplay or the atmosphere. Neither scary nor have a character.-	Music? F… you! What music?-	Story? F… you! What story? “the story of evil king that emerges suddenly and explodes all you dungeon and a traitor narrator voice”…. wow-	Atmosphere? F… you! What darkness? What aggression?... none of them were available in this game.-	That torture chambers are just a disappointment. You are the disappointment…-	Spells… F… you!-	Traps… I hope you someone sticks that blade lotus in your…. Nose.-	… just tell me what do you offer more than DK and DK2? You see if you are not able to do something good without Peter Douglas Molyneux why in the world you are over forcing your brains to do something that they are not capable of and ruin all of the product, idea? You see that that guy was in same conditions with you and created a game which is called GODUS and with that he may not be trying to revive another legend which is Black and White series however he created something at least as beautiful as B and W and made the fanatics happy.So please go find and internship somewhere close to the Peter Douglas Molyneux and don’t touch the DK series again.

number of helpful: 0 of 8 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
												A terrible disappointing follow-up to the masterpiece that is Dungeon Keeper 2. I have been playing the Dungeon Keeper series since the pre-release demo of the 2nd game so I went in this game with fairly high expectations. Unfortunately, developer oversight has let me down as this game is horribly balanced, has poor tutorial and mechanic explanation and in general feels unpolished and not cared for. The learning curve for this game is way too high for the early game, you have to effectively break the game and do the complete opposite of what you're being told to actually complete the game. You're not here to have fun and build a dungeon, you're here to play the linear meta and spam OP defences that make your "dungeon" impenetrable.The developers have taken all the fun out of a Dungeon Keeper game to create their own miscalculated, unfun formula that makes for a frustrating and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t experience where scripted story segments can screw you over - and by doing what the game has told you to do nonetheless! This game is not the Dungeon Keeper 3 people have been saying because it's actually a lot different from Dungeon Keeper 2, which this game is clearly trying to emulate in its own fashion, and a lot of what made 2 great is just not present here.In this game, you either have too much or not enough of everything. Be it gold, space, bedrock, minions, defences, shrines etc. The levels do not feel balanced and crafted in a way that allows me to express how I want to make my dungeons, rather, the way the developer wants you to take a certain paith. Goodbye fun, goodbye creativity and goodbye balance, say hello to linear, boring and overpowering formulas that you HAVE to take part in in order to stand a chance in the campaign.Avoid buying this trash if you're a Dungeon Keeper fan and instead I recommend Dungeons 2, or better, stick to Dungeon Keeper 2.

Early Access Review
								I was going to slate this as being woefully unbalanced in the campaign and leave it at that as I couldnt get past stage 3 I think it was but then I played the sandbox and I think if you can stick with it campaign wise it will probably give you some enjoyment eventually but the sad truth is that with the soon to be arrival of  Dungeons 2 this game will seem like a pale comparison and I didnt like Dungeons but they seem to have listened and maybe created a game to carry on the DK spirit which is bad news for Overworld.Its just all taken too long to get from A to B and there is a lot in the pot all mashed together. They would have been better off concentrating on the core game that was so great with DK/DK2 then releasing all the rest as add ons but here we are now and without even a finished product they find themselves up a shiny new toy in the shape of Dungeons 2.I suppose this game is now the example of what happens when there is too much input from the community and good people try to please everyone all at once. I'm glad that the game still has very positive reviews but I cant recommend this to anyone......I just played DK2 on the emulator and enjoyed it more. My advice play DK2 until Dungeons 2 comes out and if that turns out to be a turd like the first one then wait around for Overworld.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients: 1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs3 tablespoons sugar3 tablespoons melted butter40 ounces softened cream cheese1 cup sugar3 tablespoons flour1 tablespoon vanilla1 cup sour cream4 eggsDirections:For The base:.If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375.Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on.Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter.For the batter:.Make sure everything is at room temperature.Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this.Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition.Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours.Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight.Release the sides of the springform.Eat.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is a Dungeon Keeper clone. The rooms are being designed to be different it seems but along similar lines as well as the creatures. The game shows promise and is receiving regular updates however in its current state i would not recommend the price tag. It is extremely early in the development with only a handful of rooms and spells developed giving a very limited number of different creatures. Key features are missing or not yet implemented for example the minimap and creatures tab meaning you never know how many creatures you have or what ones you have. unfortunately the number of bugs in this early stage is also large and at times makes it unplayable examples being, losing cursor, cursor stuck in selection mode. The game shows promise and hopefully in the future once it progresses it will deliver something that any fan of dungeon keeper will enjoy. If you want to support the development by all means purchase the title now but if you are looking for a game you can play here and now you best wait as this is not for you....yet. Happy gaming!

I just got this game a few days ago and played it on my mac the first issue is it crashes every time you finish a mission or sandbox game so I went to the games company for help turns out theres a major bug for the mac version of the game and they don't know when it will be fixed. Another bad thing about this bug is it makes you only have half of the features windows has. For instance dungeons,some characters, and I believe some sand box modes are not in the mac version. But other then that the game is awesome there is no lag and it never crashes while your in the game intill you try to go back to the menu or close the game. I 100% think you should purchase this game if you have windows or linux you will very much so love this game for you have all the features that are released, no lag and best of all no crashes! So if your a mac I think you should get this game only if your willing to be patient enough for them to fix the bug if your a windows or linux buy this game right away it is worth it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								A faithful, intentional sucessor to the Dungeon Keeper franchise. It lacks some of the quirky charm, but is very impressive regardless. There have been very rapid developments in the past month or so which have left it feeling more like a game than a beta, and even if there is still a way to go, things are looking good.- The design is frankly, beautiful. it captures the feel of the classic dungeon keeper games perfectly.- The UI is... less impressive. It's functional, but feels somewhat rushed in places.- The creatures are interesting, but lack some of the character that the Dungeon Keeper creatures had.- Sound effects are a little repetitive, but tend to be very nice.Overall, it's a beta and it shows. Some things seem missing - animations occasionally feel like bland placeholders, there aren't a great variety of levels to play and so on and so forth... That said, it's already an impressive game and I can only see it improving as times goes on.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Really Enjoyable. If you enjoyed playing Dungeon Keeper then you'll enjoy this. Its very similar but it does have its own quirky levels. I still play DK2 fairly frequently now but since buying this a few days ago it has been taking all of the little free time I have.I've found myself yelling at the characters a few times when they seemed dumbstruck and just let themselves get hit without damaging back. The camera shape on the map doesn't seem to represent the area you are viewing on the screen either, it just feels off. This makes using the map to click to a different area very hit or miss.The levels do feel like they force you to complete them before you really want to. Quite often I'll hardly have established any base and I'll already be fighting the enemy and once you start they just continue to keep rolling in. I wouldn't mind but its starting to feel like this is EVERY level but aside from those bits it seems to play really well.Level 9 is probably the hardest level of them all.EDIT: Having now completed the game and onto the add on campaign. There is a quite big flaw to level 12 on the main campaign. The drawbridge - you can't cross it and neither can the enemy (even after youve got the levers to drop it. Now I still managed to complete it as the enemies were kind enough to come to the edge of the drawbridge and the flying demons managed to hit them. took a bit longer then it should have but I got there in the end.Also THE LAG ON LEVEL 12!! its unplayable at points, it actually crashed on my first attempt at the level (and I hadn't saved, RAGE) I haven't had any lag issues with the game until this point and my computer stats should easily run a game like this. It doesnt have issues with much more demanding games (I saved and quit to relaunch the game which seemed to help a bit)

												Dungeon Keeper 2 was and is still one of my favourite games, I've reinstalled that game mulitple times to replay it but its always unstable and now as a Mac gamer I also have to run it through Crossover/Bootcamp, its a hassle. I've hoped for a new Dungeon Keeper for years so when I saw the kickstarter for WFTO I jumped straight onboard. I didn't play it while it was in beta, I wasn't interested in guiding the game through its development, I just wanted it made, I didn't play it when it first went Gold, I heard it was buggy, and read the message from Subterranean Games, so I waited a bit longer, until today...This has been sooo worth the wait, I'm only a few levels in but absolutely loving it, it looks fantastic and plays brilliantly and hearing Richard Riding's voice brings me straight back, thank you Subterranean Games for bringing this classic gameplay back to life with such love, I can finally throw away my DK 2 install disk!

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												As a huge fan of the Dungeon Keeper series I found this installment to be quite fun and reminiscent of the original games. Pros: Engaging and familiar construction options         Some new twists on the old formula, such as sin points which unlock rooms and powers         Some creepy looking roomsCons: The pacing is generally pretty fast for every level which to me is a con because as you're really getting into the design of your dungeon the level concludes.I highly recommend the game if you want to revisit the dungeon keeper series but are not too bothered with the fast pace or ultered mechanics i.e. sins.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Recent Patches made the game playable! Finaly i could enjoy the campaign and the new creatures. The game graphics are nice, but i still want to talk about some features, which i didn't like as a DK1 fan. WftO is much as Dungeon Keeper 2 and made the same failures as DK2. Easily Destroyable Walls, Weak Traps, Creatures with only a few spells to cast! (I think 4 is the maximum for my lvl10 wizard-cultist)   :'(  If you think back to the very old DK1, the minions had many many more spells and it was so much better to watch them fight. I miss Dragonfire, Lightning and IronMaiden Lifesucking Spells, i miss "Indy Traps", Gas Trap, Lightning Trap, Hellfire Trap. The new creatures are all very nicely done, but if you expect a long awaited game close to Dungeon Keeper 1, this is not the right one. If you expect to buy a game as Dungeon Keeper 2, you will have fun with WftO!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												This is a review coming from someone who rarely plays these types of games. So this is my perception of the gamefrom what I have played so far. - ITS FUN!It felt like time flies when I was playing this, from designing the layout of my dungeon to strategically designing layouts with maze like defences for enemy minions to fall into was satisfying.- Look and feel is greatthis game gave a look and feel of what the life of being a dark overlord would be like... - Easy to get a hang ofThe campaigne tutorial gave me a good idea on how to play the game, before I even hit level 3 I already had a basic idea of how the whole upgrade system worked.- Just the right amount of difficultyIt's not like where you get to a point where it is just frustrating, if you know wha you are doing you can really have a blast and enjoy unlocking upgrades in order to boost defences and minion powers. I think they did this really well.- Voice acting is annoyingfrom the minions to the narrator. it's entertaining at first but the voice acting is very limited and repetitive and gets annoying after awhile, but aside from the lame puns and the bad voice acting if you can overlook that it's just fun!- Sandbox mode and skirmish modethe different game modes are great and gives flexibility if you get bored of campaigne's I think the variety is important for keeping the game fun. They even added a survival mode which is a great time killer.- Game modes can get boring after awhileAs much as I actually enjoyed playing this game after a few days the game modes get boring, maybe because there isn't that much of them? Overall I'm giving this a 7.5/10 :)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												I have played 9 campaign missions so far. This game feels like the real successor to the Dungeon Keeper series.+ Once again you feel like the evil overlord, slapping around your minions.+ Graphics are a lot better than those of DK2, but not too awesome.+ I like the new gameplay concepts such as beasts and constructs+ Campaign is fun so far, quite some variety in missions (capture this, destroy that, defend your base).- Switching between menus feels tiresome, where are my hotkeys?- I only use the healing spell, can't bother to click the others and find a suitable target (again hotkeys would help). I think they should have gone for a quick cast radial menu (can't think of an example). Right now it feels too fiddly to decide which spell you want to cast and then try to find a target (and then hope your spell had any effect).- The UI is not very clear. When I hover a room I expect to see a summary of capacity/size/usage etc (which Dungeons did right). They should also organize the event log by event type- The DK series felt a little more polished, but hey, this is an indie game, so they may fix the rough edges in future updates (I hope).Overall a pretty solid game, lots of fun new concepts, but a little rough around the edges.Edit: Currently the game suffers from frequent crashes. I hope they patch this around soon. Couldn't get past the 10th campaign level...Edit: It seems the latest patch resolved some memory leaks \o/

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												One of the best RTS/God Game I have ever played.* The interface is good looking and easy to use.* The game is content rich with multiple game modes and an online mode as well.* The graphics are marvellous and the attention to detail is stunning for this kind of game.* The music and all the sounds are of high quality, and so is the voice acting.* The gameplay is fantastic. The level of control it offers, whilst keeping things managable, is very appealing.* The game offers various levels of difficulty. You can also slack off and just have fun with your dungeon. Those who want an extra challenge can try the Survival Mode.Overall, this is a pretty awesome game and fullfills nearly all expectations affiliated with this genre. Can't wait to see what they have planned for future updates!9/10

												I love Dungeon Keeper games but I don't love this. It's set together pretty poorly with a bad story and immense lag issues, or RAM issues, rather. During loading and during some of the later campaign maps it took 5-10 minutes for it to load, during this time the computer being completely unavailable, since WFTO is leeching all RAM, making it nearly impossible to even open up a new tab on Firefox. Furthermore, on the later campaign maps there would be constant small lagspikes making it very hard to properly manage the battles and what not. Many other minor problems here and there as well, lacking names and structures in rooms actually having 'Prop' before it's name...

												Performance issues and more stuttering than Jimmy from south park, huge memory leaks that slow down your entire system, the most brainless AI i've seen in a while, TONS of bugs and incomplete UI, uninteresting campaign consisting mostly of rush tactics and nothing else... It's a fun game when it works, i've dumped plenty of hours into it already but its too broken and hollow to truely recommend it in the current state that it's in. For all the funding it got from hopeful players of the original DK series there's no reason why it should be in this condition and just continues to prove that kickstarters and the like are wastes of money and only lead to disappointment.

												Progress with patches has been frequent but the bulk of the game is still unplayable or imbalanced and as far as I can tell will remain that way for a significant amount of time. Multiplayer matches are simply about making blobs of monsters by spamming rooms in an open style dungeon before setting a one-click rally to your opponent's core. Posted: January 25, 2015
												** UPDATED REVIEW ***I must say that I am very impressed with the turnaround made in the past couple of months.  The developers have made a tremendous push to fix the performance problems that were plaguing the game.  To be honest, I didn't think I'd be able to play the game without replacing my hardware -- however, the recent updates and the game is absolutely playable for me now (I'm still on my original hardware).There have been many additions to the game since I last checked it out.  The introduction cut-scenes were are happy surprise, a lot of Voice work has been done, tons of little UI improvements.  I'm looking forward to playing the full single-player campaign.In short: I'm very pleased with the game now.  Great Job to the development team!*** END UPDATED REVIEW ****** OLD REVIEW BELOW ***Do not recommend -- performance problems with unoptimized code make the game unplayable due to severe lag on lower end hardware.  Just one example: opening the "Veins of Evil" can take 5+ seconds on my hardware which is better than minimum spec -- note: that is just to open the VoE, selecting something is another 5+ seconds, etc.I'm a huge fan of DK1 & DK2 and have high hopes for this game.  I will change this review if the game is fixed or options provided to workaround the performance problems.  I refuse to upgrade hardware that plays other games perfectly fine.*** END OLD REVIEW ***

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												I have been looking for years for a remake of Dungeon Keeper (1 or 2) because it was one of the most fun games I have ever played. I found some similar, but never quite on par. This game however hits the nail on the head. So familiar (though I wish they could use the same characters) it is hard to tell the difference! I am glad they got the same voice actor as the narator for the campaign. The game is not only an amazing revamped version of Dungeon Keeper 2, but it is far improved! The unlock system from the archives is very cool. I also like the skill trees with a big bad creature you can summon at the end of each tree. I did not play this prior to the patch 1.11 everyone is talking about, but I can tell you now this game is polished and awesome with many modes of gameplay. I had been trying to port a stable version of DK2 for a while on my PC, but it would crash and whatnot so thank you for making this!!!!Everyone buy this so we can battle dungeons!!!!

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												So I've been playing this game here and there since Beta.  I am amazed at how far along this game has come over the past year.  I was honestly worried for a little while that this would end up being just a "cash grab" for the Dev's however, they have religiously kept us all updated on the progress of the game and have really put in some long hours and hard work to make this game what it is today.  I finally played through the entire campaign and I LOVED the ending. Very fitting for a game of this type.  Now I'm ready to delve into some Multiplayer action although, it seems that there is not much to be had as I sit in a lobby for as long as I can stand (with no one joining) and then just give up and go off to play something else.  We need more players so we can have fast multiplayer matchups. This is something that the Dev's can't do, and it is up to you to give this game a shot. See you all in the underworld.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												** Update**  Since my last review the Dev team has clearly been very busy - I fired up the game last weekend and to my surprise, I was no longer having any of the previous performance issues. Game is now smooth, and more what I was expecting when I initially purchased it.Thank you dev team!For the dev team - the issue I was having was severe performance issues.  I have a fairly powerful machine, capable of running most games at high resolution.  When I would open the game, it would take about a mionute beforfe the main game screen would load.  Once in game, overall the performance was slow, but it would become unplayable on big maps with lots of units.  I even tried reducing the graphic level to low but it did not make a difference.Now, the game runs nice and smooth, as I would expect.  I hadn't played it in a while so I can't say exactly which patch resolved the issue.  I also upgraded to windows 10 - don't think this was the fix but it is the only significant change to my system.Initial review - This game is a poster child for why you should not buy games before they are completed.  Dev's are scrambling to release patches, 3 weeks later game still unplayable on windows 8.1

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 9, 2015
												I honestly don't know if I can recommend this game in it's current state. the gameplay was good. very reminiscent of the Dungeon Keeper games, with a few bits added in, and of course a few bits taken away - and many that directly mirror the games themselves with renames or reskins, the campaign obviously wasn't as long, about 13 levels compared to DK2's 18. The narrator doesn't an excellent job, but there's minimal cutscenes, and what bothers me the most is the performance issues and bugginess of the game - several missions I retried because my game crashed so many times, and often saves would corrupt and you'd have to start anew. This was more of an issue on the last handful of missions where levels were much longer.In terms of difficulty I can't really say I struggled at all, the A.I. are particularly lassaiz faire, with the exception of Level 12 where you fight 3 'underlords' (referring back to a very similar mission in DK2, but their dungeon structure followed a straightforward pattern that I noticed very quickly (playing the level several times due to crashing and admittedly 1 or 2 restarts), however the last mission is very lacklustre, the enemy has a big base, but they throw very small raiding parties at you of size between 8 and 12 creatures of levels 6+, which is basically just a level farm for your minions, and you can attack whenever ready. The last mission was very glitchy though - loading in from a save just before a defeat (I was attacking and didn't notice a party) there were creature models missing, and the drawbridge was invisible. Also the ending is complete and utter bullcrap.Aside from this, the gameplay was fun, I did enjoy it as I love RTSs and it also had funny moments. I have yet to play any other modes or skirmishes but it was a shame that it's so buggy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												Can I recommend it? Yes and no (as of April 2015)Yes:Wow, they really did it! This honestly looks, feels, sounds, tastes (well, maybe not that last one) like everything you liked in the original Dungeon Keeper series. This is a proper and real successor and I recommend any fan of DK to throw away anything in their hands and try this game. I cannot applaud the developers enough, well done!No:Not yet, at least.The game is simply not really done and ready for proper release just yet. On the positive side the developers are working like crazy releasing patches so I have my hopes up. The current state feels like a beta. A lot of things works very well, it's certainly playable, but you're constantly reminded of the game state by unpolished edges. To name some:- Performance bugs: Even with a PC above recommended specs, every now and then you'll experience extreme slowdowns making the game unplayable. For now, a workaround for me is to exit the game and restart after each finished level. That seems to fix most of it.- You'll see developer placemarkers for text, debugging or the like in the descriptions of creatures and rooms, instant immersion break right there.- The campaign works but is quite unpolished. The campaign has a lot of different types of objectives and introduces new features steadily but often the education of new players gets lost, and they'll never get to try out their newly acquired knowledge before having lost the level and forced to start over.- Another thing in the campaign is that your trusty mentor will often tell stories or talk to your enemies, though regularly these get mixed up and are played in the wrong order.- The campaign level difficulty is rather random. You can play the same map twice in a row. The first time might be a hectic, stressful experience, trying to figure out how new things work, getting to know your enemy, etc., only to lose because it's almost impossible. The next time you play the same map, it's a rather peaceful experience, you got lots of time to build your base, explore and react.I might add more when I remember it but these are, for me, major things that need to get fixed before the game unofficially can get out of beta.Still, despite all of this and all the frustrations, the game is awesome. It just needs a bit more time to really shine.

												The War For The Overworld is a decent and fun game, those who haven't played the classic Dungeon Keeper should give it a go since its the closest game that comes close to that style of strategy genre. You could say Dungeon, is similar but it maybe have elements of it however it tries to be different by adding RPG elements into it, which Dungeon Keeper isn't in anyway although it does have creature leveling.What I'm saying is that if you want a really close experience that is the same unqiue feeling that you got from Dungeon Keeper, this game is great, if you haven't then its a great experience.However even though I would recommend this game, it does not quite as well outshine the classic but by its own rights, it is a great game.Here check out my video below for my First Impression

content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												I loved the original Dungeon Keeper series, so brought this in the early stages. It has been enjoyale seeing the game progress, however I feel the game should not be available to buy yet as there are many bugs that still need to be ironed out. I tried many times to complete level 12, which is quite hard, only to have it crash every single time. I then came to my senses and realized that I could save the game. This said, once the game was loaded from a saved position, it's like the enemy AI had completely disappeared, and i could charge in with almost no resisitence.I completed level 13 with almost nobody in the enemy base. I still don't know if that was a bug, or the way it was designed to be. After completing it I was looking around for the next level, before realizing that the game was over. I keep waiting for the multiplayer part to be completed, but as of yet nothing.In saying all this, I would still recommend the game as when it does work, it is enjoyable to play. Most levels require very little effort to complete, and most features, eg: half the potions, are completely unneeded, but if you are a fan of the old Dungeon Keeper series, I believe you would still enjoy exploring the levels.Hopefully the game will be improved upon soon, at the moment I would estimate that the game can be completed within 30 - 40 hours maximum (if you save your progress so you don't have to start again each time it crashes)

Posted: June 21, 2014
												I have read a lot of negative reviews about WFTO - and they have a point. Certainly some elements of the game are not finished or polished, and it still suffers from a few bugs.What you have here is the spriitual successor to one of the great game franchises of the past couple of decades - Dungeon Keeper. A modernised version of a classic, and so far the developers have been very active with constant updates and fixes, which is a major plus point.The game is far from perfect, but for fans of the genre and of the DK series, WFTO is a nice way to reminisce about the good old days, its only missing the Horned Reaper himself.As things stand I recommend the game despite its shortcomings.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2015
												Recent Patches made the game playable! Finaly i could enjoy the campaign and the new creatures. The game graphics are nice, but i still want to talk about some features, which i didn't like as a DK1 fan. WftO is much as Dungeon Keeper 2 and made the same failures as DK2. Easily Destroyable Walls, Weak Traps, Creatures with only a few spells to cast! (I think 4 is the maximum for my lvl10 wizard-cultist)   :'(  If you think back to the very old DK1, the minions had many many more spells and it was so much better to watch them fight. I miss Dragonfire, Lightning and IronMaiden Lifesucking Spells, i miss "Indy Traps", Gas Trap, Lightning Trap, Hellfire Trap. The new creatures are all very nicely done, but if you expect a long awaited game close to Dungeon Keeper 1, this is not the right one. If you expect to buy a game as Dungeon Keeper 2, you will have fun with WftO!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												I have played 9 campaign missions so far. This game feels like the real successor to the Dungeon Keeper series.+ Once again you feel like the evil overlord, slapping around your minions.+ Graphics are a lot better than those of DK2, but not too awesome.+ I like the new gameplay concepts such as beasts and constructs+ Campaign is fun so far, quite some variety in missions (capture this, destroy that, defend your base).- Switching between menus feels tiresome, where are my hotkeys?- I only use the healing spell, can't bother to click the others and find a suitable target (again hotkeys would help). I think they should have gone for a quick cast radial menu (can't think of an example). Right now it feels too fiddly to decide which spell you want to cast and then try to find a target (and then hope your spell had any effect).- The UI is not very clear. When I hover a room I expect to see a summary of capacity/size/usage etc (which Dungeons did right). They should also organize the event log by event type- The DK series felt a little more polished, but hey, this is an indie game, so they may fix the rough edges in future updates (I hope).Overall a pretty solid game, lots of fun new concepts, but a little rough around the edges.Edit: Currently the game suffers from frequent crashes. I hope they patch this around soon. Couldn't get past the 10th campaign level...Edit: It seems the latest patch resolved some memory leaks \o/

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								A faithful, intentional sucessor to the Dungeon Keeper franchise. It lacks some of the quirky charm, but is very impressive regardless. There have been very rapid developments in the past month or so which have left it feeling more like a game than a beta, and even if there is still a way to go, things are looking good.- The design is frankly, beautiful. it captures the feel of the classic dungeon keeper games perfectly.- The UI is... less impressive. It's functional, but feels somewhat rushed in places.- The creatures are interesting, but lack some of the character that the Dungeon Keeper creatures had.- Sound effects are a little repetitive, but tend to be very nice.Overall, it's a beta and it shows. Some things seem missing - animations occasionally feel like bland placeholders, there aren't a great variety of levels to play and so on and so forth... That said, it's already an impressive game and I can only see it improving as times goes on.

												A well thought out clone of the original series, however this release game has too many bugs, issues, memory leaks, performance issues, and other niggling problems to allow me to recommend it.This game is no longer "early access", it isn't in beta, it's not a public test realm. The state this game is in does not warrant purchase.My 16GB of RAM machine hit 100% thanks to a memory leak. Pay Day causes machines to lock up for numerous seconds. Many levels cannot be completed due to bugs. Save files do not load the game up as you left it (enemies respawn).

												I just love it...Brings me back to Dungeon Keeper 2 ... So basically DK3 ... Join the dark side we've got a Succubus... Sadly they are not using their own toys anymore when not assigned to a specific task... Training creatures above level 4 in the barracks is interresting as well... I kinda miss prisoners turning into skeletons ... but well it's a new game and everything has it's ups and downs...Seen some small bugs so far... invisible enemys getting stuck and the entire army trying to kill them but not beeing able to... my own minions getting stuck in the wall after a power attack from a Behemoth... a rare game crash when playing home real... converted enemys don't heal back to full healht... My own Vampire attacking my core and no way to stop it from killing it even after it's lair was destroyed... Ghouls beeing stuck in the crypt after Necromancer leaves the room (after reaload)... Generally it's only minor things...My view: 8/10 points

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												A worthy spiritual succesor to one of my all time favorite games, Dungeon Keeper. A lot of fun and familiar factors to add to the experience. One thing I would like to point out though, is that the dungeon doesnt feel as much 'alive' as it probably should. The game is inevitably compared to Dungeon Keeper, where the creatures always seemed to be going about their business, training, eating, having fun, guarding, etc. This is something I am missing so far in War for the Overworld. Sure, they move around, they prepare for combat and they keep themselves alive, but it doesnt feel like a living and breathing 'society'.I am greatly looking forward to future imporvement, a lot of bugs and issues have already been removed. I have total faith in the potential of the game and the talented developers.

												I would recommend this if you're looking for a basic Dungeon Keeper with a few niche extras, but it still needs a lot of work.I have a list of things I'd like to see happen throughout development, other than obviously fixing bugs and planned updates. 1. Slower and larger levels in the campaign, seems very fast pased atm, which is fine for some levels, but not all. 2.  More 'options' options, rebindable keys etc. 3. Improved UI - updated tooltips etc. 4. Improve AI - minions are all over the place, not reacting to enemies, commands etc. 5. Animation of struggling minions when they're picked up. This is just a few things, will probably think of more later.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												There are many great things in this game. Most of them stem from the Dungeon Keeper influence. The humor, voice acting, and artwork are all superb.There are also a few design issues that are a bit annoying. The campaign's tutorial sections are mandatory and can cause issues when loading a saved game. Not allowing the player to build anywhere but the glowing area is annoying and problematic.As much as I loved DK1 and DK2, and see much of the spirit revived in War for the Overworld, it just isn't ready for release.With some time to polish, I'd happily jump back into this charming little title. Until then, there are too many annoyances getting in the way of enjoying the game, the majority of it coming from technical issues.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												I have read a lot of negative reviews about WFTO - and they have a point. Certainly some elements of the game are not finished or polished, and it still suffers from a few bugs.What you have here is the spriitual successor to one of the great game franchises of the past couple of decades - Dungeon Keeper. A modernised version of a classic, and so far the developers have been very active with constant updates and fixes, which is a major plus point.The game is far from perfect, but for fans of the genre and of the DK series, WFTO is a nice way to reminisce about the good old days, its only missing the Horned Reaper himself.As things stand I recommend the game despite its shortcomings.
